DIVISION 2. - VOLUNTEER FIRE DEPARTMENT[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Fire companies, N.J.S.A. 15:8-1.1 et seq.; municipal support of volunteer fire companies, N.J.S.A. 40A:14-33. 

Sec. 2-133. - Established. 
    There is hereby authorized and established the borough fire department which shall be a volunteer company within the borough exclusively authorized to engage in firefighting activities within the borough. 
(Ord. No. 742-96, § II, 8-16-1996) 
Sec. 2-134. - Location. 
    The location of the borough fire department shall be 221 West Merchant Street, Audubon, New Jersey. 
(Ord. No. 742-96, § III, 8-16-1996) 
Sec. 2-135. - Membership eligibility. 
    No person shall hereafter become a member of the borough fire department unless said individual is at least the age of eighteen (18) years, a citizen of the United States, a resident of the borough and of good moral character. Said person shall be physically fit to perform the duties of a firefighter evidenced by a certificate of physical examination from a licensed New Jersey practicing physician. New members shall be admitted in accordance with bylaws adopted by the borough fire department. 
(Ord. No. 742-96, § IV, 8-16-1996) 
State Law reference- Certain persons prohibited from being members of fire companies, N.J.S.A. 15:8-1.1. 
Sec. 2-136. - Application for membership. 
    Every person seeking to join the borough fire department shall make application to the borough, through the borough clerk, to join the borough fire department. Approval of said applicant's membership by the borough commissioners shall be required and thereafter his/her name shall be entered on a roll of firefighters maintained by the borough clerk. 
(Ord. No. 742-96, § VI, 8-16-1996) 
Sec. 2-137. - Officers; elections; term and removal. 
(a)  Within the borough fire department there shall be the position of chief and there shall be two (2) assistant chiefs. The initial appointment of the chief shall be made by the director of public safety. After appointment, the chief shall appoint two (2) assistant chiefs subject to approval by the borough commissioners. Within forty-five (45) days of appointment, the members shall appoint other officers deemed required for the efficient management of the department subject to final approval by the director of public safety. No appointment made by the chief or members shall be deemed effective until approval by resolution of the commissioners. The initial terms of all officers shall expire two (2) years from December 31 next following their appointment. Appointment of officers thereafter shall be in the following manner: On or before November 1 in the year prior to the expiration officers' terms, an election shall be held within the department and the names of officers selected will be forwarded to the borough commissioners no later than November 15 of that year. 
(b)  Each and every officer of the borough fire department may be removed by majority vote of the borough commissioners, for good cause, after being given appropriate notice and opportunity for a public hearing consistent with the laws of the state and the borough. 
(Ord. No. 742-96, § V, 8-16-1996) 
Sec. 2-138. - Equipment. 
    The equipment of the borough fire department shall be such as may from time to time be acquired and determined by the board of commissioners, in their opinion, to be proper for the protection of the health, safety and welfare of the borough. 
(Ord. No. 742-96, § VII, 8-16-1996) 
Sec. 2-139. - Duties of fire chief. 
    It shall be the duty of the fire chief of the borough fire department to take full command and control of all borough fire apparatus at all fires, or in going to or returning from the same, and to give directions and provide leadership. He/she shall have sole and entire command of fires and alarms and over all members of the company, apparatus and equipment belonging to the same and any persons aiding or assisting at fires and drills. He/she shall order the department out for drill or inspection at such reasonable time and place as he/she may designate and whenever he/she may deem it to be necessary for the efficiency of the department. 
(Ord. No. 742-96, § IX, 8-16-1996) 
Sec. 2-140. - Fire marshal. 
(a)  Office created; appointment; removal. There is hereby created and established in and for the borough the office of borough fire marshal. The borough fire marshal shall be in charge of the bureau of fire prevention in the fire department of the borough. He/she shall be appointed to his/her position by the governing body on the basis of his/her qualifications and experience. He/she shall serve at the pleasure of the governing body, but unless sooner removed, shall hold office for one (1) year. 
(b)  Duties; annual report. 
(1)  The fire marshal may detail such members of the fire department as inspectors as shall from time to time be necessary. He/she shall conduct such investigations as may be necessary or expedient for the purpose of eliminating, avoiding and abating fire hazards. He/she shall act in an advisory capacity to the fire companies. He/she shall perform such duties and exercise such powers as are vested in him by other ordinances of the borough and by the fire prevention code duly adopted by this municipality. 
(2)  A report of the bureau of fire prevention shall be made annually and transmitted to the governing body. It shall contain all proceedings under this code, with such statistics as the fire marshal may wish to include therein. The fire marshal shall also recommend amendments to the code when appropriate. 
(c)  Salary. The borough fire marshal shall receive such salary or fees as may be determined by the governing body pursuant to the provisions of duly adopted salary ordinances. 
(Code 1992, §§ 31-1-31-3; Ord. No. 389, 7-10-1973) 
Sec. 2-141. - Duties of firefighters. 
    It shall be the duty of the firefighters to operate all equipment, defend and endeavor to save life and property from fire in the borough, and defend elsewhere when an occasion should arise and to properly clean and repair all equipment to the best of their ability. 
(Ord. No. 742-96, § VIII, 8-16-1996) 
Sec. 2-142. - Chain of command. 
    In the case of a fire alarm or scheduled drill, in the absence or disability of the fire chief, the next ranking officer shall assume command and have the responsibilities of the fire chief at that time. 
(Ord. No. 742-96, § X, 8-16-1996) 
Sec. 2-143. - Required reports. 
    The fire chief shall prepare and submit to the board of commissioners, for its regular meeting each month, a report. This shall include fire alarms, fire drills, the value of property involved, the amount of loss and also the name, rank and address of any officer or firefighter injured in the line of duty, including the date, time and place of his/her condition. In reports of mutual aid calls, the value of buildings and loss are not required. 
(Ord. No. 742-96, § XI, 8-16-1996) 
Sec. 2-144. - Junior firefighter's auxiliary. 
(a)  Established. Pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40A:14-95, there is hereby established an auxiliary to the borough volunteer fire department, to be known as the "junior firefighter's auxiliary." 
(b)  Eligibility; permission required. No person shall be eligible for membership in the junior firefighter's auxiliary who is less than sixteen (16) or more than eighteen (18) years of age. Applicants for membership shall be required to obtain permission to join the auxiliary from their parents or guardians. Such permission shall be in writing and acknowledged or proved in the manner required by law for deeds to real estate. 
(c)  Membership limited. The maximum limit of members of the auxiliary shall be twenty (20) for the fire department at any given period. 
(d)  Application; probationary period. All applicants to the auxiliary must present a duly executed application form, and said applicant shall not be approved until after acceptance by the fire department and subsequently by the governing body of the municipality. After the applicant has been approved for membership in the auxiliary, he/she shall be placed upon a six-month probationary period, during which time he/she shall be observed by appropriate members of the fire department for his/her interest, activity and behavior. Before being given permanent status in said auxiliary, the fire department shall review the report of the probationary period. 
(e)  Medical examinations. All applicants must have properly certified medical examinations, including chest X-rays, prior to their acceptance into the probationary period. 
(f)  Training requirements. The rules and regulations for the training of the auxiliary shall be as set forth in the state safety basic training manual. The training subjects to be covered are as follows: 
(1)  Oil burners and electrical services. 
(2)  Resuscitators and inhalators. 
(3)  Portable hand tools. 
(4)  Basic first aid. 
(5)  Scott and M.S.A. air packs. 
(6)  Application of fire streams. 
(7)  Driver's education for those at least seventeen (17) years of age. 
(8)  Proper nozzles. 
(9)  Hose laying and advancing. 
(10)  Portable hand extinguishers. 
(11)  Ventilators and ladders. 
(12)  Fire-pump operations. 
(g)  Duties. 
(1)  Auxiliary members will be educated, trained and observed while being drilled and will be eligible to participate in appropriate firefighting operations. 
(2)  No junior firefighter shall be required to perform duties which would expose him/her to the same degree of hazard as a regular member of the volunteer fire department. 
(Ord. No. 742-96, §§ XII-XVIII, 8-16-1996) 
Secs. 2-145-2-171. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-11, adopted Nov. 10, 2015, amended Div. 3 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former Div. 3, §§ 2-172-2-187, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 950-09, § 1, adopted Feb. 17, 2009; Ord. No. 972-2010, §§ 49-1-49-15, adopted May 18, 2010; Ord. No. 974-2010, adopted Sept. 21, 2010; Ord. No. 2012-9, §§ 49-1-49-15, adopted Sept. 4, 2012; and Ord. No. 2014-07, Art. I, adopted July 15, 2014. 
State Law reference- Municipal police departments, N.J.S.A. 40A:14-118 et seq. 

Sec. 2-172. - Establishment; general duties. 
(a)  There shall be a full-time police department in and for the borough. 
(b)  The official name of said police department shall be the "Audubon Borough Police Department." 
(c)  The police department shall: 
(1)  Preserve the public peace and preserve order at all elections and public meetings and assemblages. 
(2)  Protect life and property. 
(3)  Detect, arrest and prosecute offenders of the laws of the United States of America, the State of New Jersey and the ordinances of the borough. 
(4)  Provide proper police attendance and protection during emergencies. 
(5)  Provide appearances in court when necessary. 
(6)  Direct and control traffic and enforce the provisions of the Traffic Act. 
(7)  Cooperate fully with the law enforcement agencies and prosecuting authorities of federal, state and county governments. 
(8)  Maintain such police training programs as may be necessary and proper for the efficient and effective organization of the police department. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, 11-10-2015) 
State Law reference- Municipal police departments, N.J.S.A. 40A:14-118 et seq. 
Sec. 2-173. - Appropriate authority; chief of police. 
(a)  The appropriate authority, as said term is used in N.J.S.A. 40A:14-118, shall be the borough commissioner appointed director of public safety. The appropriate authority, with the consent and approval of the board of commissioners shall adopt and promulgate rules and regulations for the government of the police department and for the discipline of its members. 
(b)  Except as provided in N.J.S.A. 40A:14-118, the director of public safety shall initially act in all matters relating to the police function, except where action of the governing body is required. The administrative responsibility for implementing the determinations, policies and decisions of the director of public safety shall be with the borough administrator. 
(c)  The chief of police shall be the head of the police department and shall be directly responsible to the director of public safety for its efficiency and day-to-day operations. Pursuant to policies established by the borough, the chief of police shall: 
(1)  Administer and enforce the rules and regulations and special emergency directives for the disposition and discipline of the department and its officers and personnel. 
(2)  Have, exercise and discharge the functions, powers and duties of the police department. 
(3)  Prescribe the duties and assignments of all members and officers. 
(4)  Delegate such authority, as may be deemed necessary for the efficient operation of the police department, to be exercised under the police chief's direction and supervision. 
(5)  Maintain the good order and discipline of the department. 
(6)  Report at least monthly to the director of public safety, in such form as the borough administrator shall prescribe, on the operation of the police department during the preceding month and make such other reports as may be requested by the director of public safety. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, 11-10-2015) 
Sec. 2-174. - Composition. 
(a)  The police department shall consist of a police force and such other non-sworn or civilian personnel as the borough commissioners shall appoint. The police force shall consist of one (1) chief of police, one (1) captain, one (1) lieutenant, no more than five (5) sergeants, and such number of corporals and patrol officers as the borough commissioners shall authorize from time to time. The designation of rank or position shall not require the board of commissioners to appoint a person to such rank. The employees of the police department will carry out and obey all orders and instructions of the chief of police or, in his/her absence, his/her designee. 
(b)  In the event of an officer in any of these positions being on leave immediately preceding an announced retirement or a suspension with intent to dismiss, the director of public safety may, for the efficiency of the department and subject to his/her discretion, appoint an interim replacement to serve in the vacant position, subject to that person meeting the qualifications for that position. Alternatively, the director of public safety may leave a position vacant in his or her discretion. 
(c)  The borough commissioners may decrease the force for reason of economy pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40A:14-143. In case of demotion from the higher ranks, the officers or members to be so demoted shall be in the inverse order of the dates of their appointment. When the service of members or officers is terminated, such termination shall be in the inverse order of their appointment. Any member or officer who is demoted or whose service is terminated by reason of such decrease shall be placed on a special employment list, and in the case of subsequent promotions, a person so demoted shall be reinstated to his former rank and, in the case of termination of service and new appointment, prior consideration shall be given to the persons on the special employment list. 
(d)  The borough commissioners may also appoint such clerical, secretarial and administrative employees, community service officers, school crossing guards and police technicians as they deem necessary and prudent. These employees shall not be members of the police department within the meaning of any provision of N.J.S.A. 40A, tit. 14 (N.J.S.A. 40A-14-1 et seq.). These employees shall carry out and obey all orders and instructions of the chief of police or any other officer having supervisory authority within the department. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, 11-10-2015) 
State Law reference- Decrease in police force for reasons of economy, N.J.S.A. 40A:14-143. 
Sec. 2-175. - Qualifications for employment. 
    Members of the police department shall have the following qualifications: 
(1)  Be a citizen of the United States. 
(2)  Have sufficient good mental and bodily health to satisfy the Board of Trustees of the Police and Fireman's Retirement System of New Jersey that he/she is eligible for membership in the retirement system. 
(3)  The ability to competently read, write and speak the English language. 
(4)  Be of good moral character and free from conviction of any crime constituting an indictable offense or any crime or offense involving moral turpitude. 
(5)  Passed any written, oral, physical and psychological examinations as determined by the borough administrator. 
(6)  Have the ability to perform all essential functions of a police officer. 
(7)  Graduated from an accredited high school or possess a graduate equivalency degree (GED). 
(8)  Possess a valid New Jersey driver's license. 
(9)  Meet all other requirements contained in N.J.S.A. 40A:14-127. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, 11-10-2015) 
State Law reference- General qualifications for employment of police, N.J.S.A. 40A:14-122. 
Sec. 2-176. - Hiring procedures. 
(a)  Investigation of applicants. No applicant shall be appointed to any position with the police department until after the applicant has been fingerprinted and the fingerprints filed with the state police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. No applicant shall be appointed until after there has been a thorough background and character investigation of the candidate that will also determine the candidate's fitness for the position. 
(b)  Required training course; probationary status. 
(1)  All members of the police department shall successfully complete the basic police training course given at an academy or facility approved by the state police training commission pursuant to Mandatory Police Training Act (N.J.S.A. 52:17B-66 et seq.). 
(2)  The director of public safety may waive the attendance of a police training academy for those applicants who have previously been certified as a municipal police officer by the state police training commission and if satisfactory certification of previous accredited schooling under the Mandatory Police Training Act (N.J.S.A. 52:17B-66 et seq.) is presented. The director of public safety may permit an applicant to undergo a modified course of training with the prior approval of the state police training commission of such training. Police officers hired pursuant to this section shall be classified as probationary employees with the police department for a period of one (1) year from the date of hire. 
(3)  During the period of required training, the employee shall hold the rank of probationary officer. Employees shall be entitled to a leave of absence with pay during the period of the police training course. Following the completion of an employee's police training course, he/she shall be classified as a probationary employee with the police department for a period of one (1) year. 
(4)  Probationary officers will be evaluated on a monthly basis throughout the entire period of their probation in an effort to determine their suitability for continued employment. Probationary employees will be advised of their progress and counseled when necessary in an effort to correct any deficient performance or behavior. 
(5)  No later than thirty (30) days before the expiration of an officer's probationary period, the chief of police shall submit a written evaluation of the officer to the director of public safety regarding the fitness of the officer for permanent employment. The director of public safety may retain the employee, dismiss the employee, or with the agreement of the employee, extend the probationary period for an additional six (6) months, at which time the chief of police shall reevaluate the probationary officer and submit a written evaluation no later than thirty (30) days before the expiration of the extended probationary term. The director of public safety shall either retain or dismiss the employee. 
(6)  Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions, the chief of police may recommend the dismissal of a probationary officer at any time if he/she believes that the officer does not have the ability, aptitude or willingness to adequately perform the duties of a borough police officer. The director of public safety may accept the chief of police's recommendation and terminate the officer or may decide to continue the officer's employment on a probationary basis. 
(7)  Whenever the chief of police recommends the dismissal of a probationary officer, the probationary officer shall be given a copy of the chief of police's evaluations and shall be permitted to present his/her response to the director of public safety within ten (10) days of receipt of the evaluation. The response may either be written or given orally, at the discretion of the director of public safety. 
(8)  All non-sworn employees of the police department shall serve a probationary period of six (6) months before becoming regular employees. 
(9)  Probationary employees will be evaluated on a monthly basis throughout the entire period of their probation in an effort to determine their suitability for continued employment. Probationary employees will be advised of their progress and counseled when necessary in an effort to correct any deficient performance or behavior. 
(10)  No later than thirty (30) days before the expiration of a non-sworn employee's probationary period, the chief of police shall submit a written evaluation of the employee to the director of public safety regarding the fitness of the employee for regular employment. The director of public safety may retain the employee, dismiss the employee, or with the agreement of the employee, extend the probationary period for an additional six (6) months, at which time the chief of police shall reevaluate the probationary employee and submit a written evaluation no later than thirty (30) days before the expiration of the extended probationary term. The director of public safety shall either retain or dismiss the employee. 
(11)  Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions, the chief of police may recommend the dismissal of a probationary employee at any time if he/she believes that the officer does not have the ability, aptitude or willingness to adequately perform the duties of the employee. The director of public safety may accept the chief of police's recommendation and terminate the employee or may decide to continue the employee on a probationary basis. 
(12)  Whenever the chief of police recommends the dismissal of a probationary employee, the probationary employee shall be given a copy of the chief of police's evaluations and shall be permitted to present his/her response to the director of public safety within ten (10) days of receipt of the evaluation. The response may either be written or given orally, at the discretion of the director of public safety. 
(13)  None of the foregoing provisions shall be construed as providing any employee with tenure status. 
(c)  Oath. Every member of the police department and special police officers, before entering upon the performance of their duties, shall take and subscribe an oath or affirmation to bear true faith and allegiance to the government established in this state under the authority of the people, to support the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of New Jersey and to faithfully, impartially and justly discharge and perform all the duties of their offices, which oaths or affirmations shall be filed with the borough clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, 11-10-2015) 
Sec. 2-177. - Promotions. 
(a)  The commissioners of the borough desire to promote the most qualified candidates to positions of higher rank. This section establishes the eligibility requirements and the process for promotion to all higher ranks. 
(1)  Promotions shall be made on the basis of merit, experience, education, demonstrated ability and competitive examinations. In accordance with N.J.S.A. 40A:14-129, the promotion of any officer must be made from the membership of the department. 
(2)  No person shall be eligible for promotion unless he or she have served as a full-time police officer in the Audubon Borough Police Department for a period of three (3) years as required by N.J.S.A. 40A:14-130. 
(3)  No person shall be eligible for promotion unless he or she has previously served as a patrolman in the department as required by N.J.S.A. 40A:14-130. 
(4)  Promotions shall be open to members of the next lowest rank, unless the director of public safety, in the best interest of the department, chooses to test a wider pool of candidates. Generally, a pool of less than three (3) eligible candidates will not be considered "in the best interest of the department." 
(b)  Upon receiving instructions from the director of public safety to do so, the chief of police shall announce the promotional process to members of the department at least five (5) days before any interviews are to be given. The announcement shall be posted in common areas of the department accessible to all members and shall also be sent in writing to each eligible officer's home address. The announcement shall contain, at a minimum, the rank to be filled, the date(s) of the interview(s). Candidates who qualify shall notify the chief of police of his/her interest in taking the examination by submitting a letter of interest no later than three (3) calendar days after the promotion announcement. This time period may be extended at the discretion of the director of public safety. Failure to submit a timely letter of interest will make an officer ineligible to participate in the promotional process. 
(c)  Where two (2) or more candidates are ranked equally pursuant to the promotional procedure set forth herein, preference shall be given to the candidate with the most seniority in service pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40A:14-120, or a resident of the Borough of Audubon over a nonresident pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40A:14-122.6. 
(d)  The director of public safety shall make all department promotions and may appoint a reviewing committee to assist him/her in the process. 
(e)  Promotional procedure. The promotional testing procedure for the Audubon Borough Police Department shall consist of an oral interview in which all candidates will be given the same pool of questions. A review of the candidate's service record, education, merit and experience shall also be conducted following the oral interview. 
(1)  Oral interview. The oral interview shall consist of questions regarding leadership and management skills, knowledge of police practices and procedures, knowledge of the laws applicable to police work, knowledge about Audubon Borough and its form of government, knowledge of the police department ordinance, and knowledge of N.J.S.A. 40A:14-118. The director of public safety, and the reviewing committee if selected, shall grade each candidate on a 100-point scale. 
(2)  Record review. The director of public safety, and the reviewing committee if selected, shall: 
a.  Examine the length and merit of candidate's service. The process shall give specific weight to performance evaluations, experience, military service, demonstrated leadership ability, education and disciplinary history. 
1.  Corporal, sergeant, lieutenant or captain. 
Type Weight (percentage) Oral exam 60% Performance evaluations 20% Leadership evaluation 10% Experience 5% Education 5% Associate's degree or 60 college credits = 2.5% Bachelor's degree = 5% Two (2) years of active-duty military experience (including Coast Guard) or six (6) years' Reserves or National Guard can be substituted for associate's degree or sixty (60) college credits, if honorably discharged. If associate's degree or sixty (60) college credits and the two (2) years of active-duty military experience (including Coast Guard) or six (6) years' Reserves or National Guard will be worth five percent (5%), if honorably discharged. Discipline shall be a minus depending on the seriousness and timeliness of the infractions.  
The director of public safety, and the review committee if selected, shall rank each candidate based on the total score as outlined above. The candidates shall then be ranked from the highest to lowest based on score. The list shall include the candidates' names and the final scores. 
(f)  The results of the promotional process with the final scores of the candidates and any other information that may be pertinent shall be submitted to the director of public safety. 
(g)  The director of public safety shall meet with the board of commissioners and inform them of his results and his recommendation for promotion. All promotions shall be executed by municipal resolution. 
(h)  The scores shall remain valid for a period of two (2) years and subsequent promotions may be made based upon these scores. However, the borough may call for a new promotional process at any time. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, 11-10-2015) 
State Law reference- Police promotions, N.J.S.A. 40A:14-122.6, 40A:14-129, 40A:14-130. 
Sec. 2-178. - Chief of police; qualifications; promotions. 
(a)  The commissioners of the borough desire to promote the most qualified candidates to positions of higher rank. This chapter establishes the eligibility requirements and the process for promotion to all higher ranks. 
(1)  Promotions shall be made on the basis of merit, experience, education, demonstrated ability and competitive examinations. 
(2)  No person shall be eligible for promotion unless he or she shall have served as a full-time police officer in the borough police department for a period of three (3) years as required by N.J.S.A. 40A:14-130. 
(b)  Upon receiving instructions from the director of public safety to do so, the chief of police shall announce the promotional process to members of the department at least forty-five (45) days before a written test is to be given and at least fifteen (15) days before a written submission is to be submitted. The announcement shall be posted in common areas of the department accessible to all members and shall also be sent in writing to each eligible officer's home address. The announcement shall contain, at a minimum, the rank to be filled, the date(s) of the exam(s), source materials or reading lists from which exam questions will be taken or topics from which questions will be formulated. Candidates who qualify shall notify the chief of police of his/her interest in taking the examination by submitting a letter of interest no later than ten (10) calendar days after the promotion announcement. This time period may be extended at the discretion of the director of public safety. Failure to submit a timely letter of interest will make an officer ineligible to participate in the promotional process. 
(c)  Where two (2) or more candidates are ranked equally pursuant to the promotional procedure set forth herein, preference shall be given to the candidate with the most seniority in service pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40A:14-129, or to a resident of the Borough of Audubon over a nonresident pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40A:14-122.6. 
(d)  Candidates for the position of chief of police shall participate in a promotional procedure administered by the director of public safety. The reviewing committee, which shall be made up of the director of public safety, the borough administrator or his/her designee(s), the current chief of police (unless he/she is involved in pending discipline or litigation with the borough) and two (2) police executives from other agencies. The reviewing committee shall consider the following: the candidates' knowledge of criminal law and procedure, police science and police administration, leadership and management ability, general knowledge of Audubon local government and N.J.S.A. 40A:14-118, knowledge of budgeting and personnel management, the candidates' poise, alertness, ability to communicate clearly and effectively, ability to effect good working and public relations and moral character. To be considered for the position of chief of police, the candidates must hold the rank of captain, lieutenant or sergeant. 
(e)  The director of public safety shall appoint the chief of police and may appoint a reviewing committee to assist him/her in the process. 
(f)  Promotional testing procedure. The promotional testing procedure for the borough police department for the position of chief of police shall consist of a written examination (and/or narrative) and an oral examination in which all candidates will be given the same questions, a personal interview with the board of commissioners, a review of the candidate's service record, education, merit and experience. 
(1)  Written examination. 
a.  The written test shall be supplied by a professional testing company, professional law enforcement organization or such other written examination approved by the director of public safety. The written examination shall be given and supervised by the borough administrator. 
b.  To proceed to the oral portion of the examination procedure, a candidate must achieve a score of at least seventy percent (70%). Candidates will be notified in writing of their grades on the written portion of the exam by the chief of police or his/her designee. 
(2)  Oral examination. 
a.  Candidates who achieve a minimum qualifying score (seventy percent (70%)) on the written examination will be permitted to sit for an oral examination by the reviewing committee. 
b.  The oral examination by the reviewing committee shall focus on leadership and management skills, knowledge of police practices and procedures, knowledge of the laws applicable to police work, knowledge about the borough and its form of government, knowledge of the police department ordinance, and knowledge of N.J.S.A. 40A:14-118. The reviewing committee shall grade each candidate on a 100-point scale. The chief of police and/or his/her designee (excluding chief interviews) shall be present at this step. 
c.  The reviewing committee shall grade each candidate's oral interview on a 100-point basis. In order to proceed to the final portion of the promotional process, a candidate must achieve a score of at least seventy percent (70%). 
(3)  Personal interview. Candidates for the rank of captain will be interviewed by the director of public safety. 
(4)  Record review. 
a.  Candidates that successfully achieve a score of seventy percent (70%) on the written examination or written submission and seventy percent (70%) on the oral examination shall proceed to the next step in the promotional process, the review of service record. 
b.  The reviewing committee shall examine the length and merit of candidate's service. The examination process shall give specific weight to performance evaluations, experience, military service, demonstrated leadership ability, education and disciplinary history. 
c.  The weight to be given each portion of the review shall be: 
Type Weight (percentage) Written test or submission 20 Oral exam 20 Interview with Commissioners 20 Performance evaluations 20 Leadership evaluation 10 Experience 5 Education 5 Associate's degree or sixty (60) college credits = two and one-half percent (21/2%). Bachelor's degree = five percent (5%). Two (2) years of active-duty military experience (including Coast Guard) or six (6) years Reserves or National Guard can be substituted for associate's degree or sixty (60) college credits, if honorably discharged. Associate's degree or sixty (60) college credits and two (2) years of active-duty military experience (including Coast Guard) or six (6) years' Reserves or National Guard will be worth five percent (5%), if honorably discharged. Discipline shall be a minus depending on seriousness and timeliness of the infractions.  
(g)  The review committee shall rank each candidate based on the total score as outlined above. The candidates shall then be ranked from the highest to lowest based on score. The list shall include the candidates' names and the final scores. 
(h)  The results of the promotional process with the final scores of the candidates and any other information that may be pertinent shall be submitted to the director of public safety. 
(i)  The director of public safety shall meet with the board of commissioners who shall make the final promotional decision. 
(j)  Test results shall remain valid for a period of two (2) years and subsequent promotions may be made based upon these test results. However, the borough may call for a new promotional process at any time. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, 11-10-2015) 
State Law reference- Police promotions, N.J.S.A. 40A:14-122.6, 40A:14-129, 40A:14-130. 
Sec. 2-179. - Chain of command. 
(a)  The following chain of command shall exist within the police department: 
(1)  Chief of police; 
(2)  Captain; 
(3)  Lieutenant 
(4)  Sergeant; 
(5)  Corporal; 
(6)  Patrolman; 
(7)  Special officer; 
(8)  Civilian employee. 
(b)  Each rank/position shall be subordinate to all higher ranks. 
(c)  Civilian employees shall report to their assigned supervisor or designee, or in his/her absence, the ranking officer on duty. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, 11-10-2015) 
State Law reference- Chain of command required, N.J.S.A. 40A:14-118. 
Sec. 2-180. - Special law enforcement officers. 
    The director of public safety may appoint special law enforcement officers in accordance with N.J.S.A. 40A:14-146.8, N.J.S.A. 40A:14-146.9 and N.J.S.A. 40A:14-146.10. Special law enforcement officers shall possess and exercise all the powers and duties as provided by law during their term in office, but shall not be continued as regular members of the police department and shall not be entitled to tenure. Special law enforcement officers may be reappointed for additional terms. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, 11-10-2015; Ord. No. 2018-03, Art. I, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 2-181. - Discipline. 
(a)  Major discipline. Pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40A:14-147, and except as otherwise provided by law, no permanent member of the police department shall be removed from office, employment or position for political reasons or for any cause other than incapacity, misconduct or disobedience of the rules and regulations established for the government of the police department, nor shall such member be suspended, removed, fired or reduced in rank from or in the office, employment or position therein, except for just cause or as otherwise provided in this section. 
(b)  Minor discipline. Notwithstanding anything set forth in this section, an officer or member of the police department may be issued an oral or written reprimand for minor instances of misconduct, disobedience, violations of the rules and regulations and for other improper conduct. Officers or members of the police department may file a written statement in response to any recorded reprimand, but there shall not be any right to appeal such discipline either by grievance or petition to the chief of police or the board of commissioners. 
(c)  Preliminary investigation. 
(1)  Upon an allegation of wrongdoing made by a citizen or another officer against any officer of the police department, the allegations of wrongdoing shall be investigated in accordance with the "Internal Affairs Policy and Procedures" of the Police Management Manual promulgated by the police bureau of the division of criminal justice in the department of law and public safety, which are hereby adopted. 
(2)  These guidelines shall be applied and followed consistent with any applicable tenure or civil service laws, and shall not supersede any provisions relating to internal affairs investigations contained in any collective bargaining agreements. 
(3)  After completion of the investigation, if the investigating officer believes that there is sufficient cause to file a formal complaint, he/she shall prepare a written report, together with all supporting documentation, which shall be forwarded to the chief of police. 
(d)  Review by chief of police. 
(1)  If, after reviewing said report and supporting documentation, the chief of police believes that sufficient cause exists to file a formal complaint, the chief shall prepare and serve said formal complaint, specifying a time, date and place for a hearing within the time limits and as required in N.J.S.A. 40A:14-147. 
(2)  The chief of police shall provide the director of public safety with a copy of all internal affairs reports involving allegations of incapacity, misconduct or disobedience of the rules and regulations established for the government of the police department. In the event that no formal discipline is issued, the director of public safety will return the reports to the chief of police. The information contained in such reports shall be deemed confidential and may not be released except as permitted by the attorney general's internal affairs policy and procedures guidelines or by other law. 
(e)  Hearing. 
(1)  At the time and place fixed for such hearing, the hearing officer shall receive evidence concerning the charges and shall afford the accused an opportunity to be heard, to cross-examine witnesses appearing in support of the charges, to present evidence on his/her own behalf, to be represented by counsel and, in general, permit the accused every opportunity to provide his/her defense. 
(2)  The hearing officer shall have the power to hear and determine the charge or charges against the officer. The hearing officer shall have the power to subpoena witnesses and documentary evidence, which said subpoena may be enforced by the superior court in accordance with N.J.S.A. 40A:14-148. 
(3)  A verbatim transcript shall be made of said hearing, the cost of which shall be paid by the borough. 
(f)  Hearing officer. 
(1)  The hearing officer shall be the borough administrator, unless, in the director of public safety's sole discretion and for any reason, the director of public safety appoints an independent third party to serve as hearing officer. In the event that the director of public safety appoints a third party to serve as hearing officer, the borough shall bear the entire expense and/or cost of the services of the hearing officer. The borough shall be represented by its attorney, special labor counsel or such other counsel who may be retained for this purpose. 
(2)  The hearing officer shall make findings of fact and recommendations within thirty (30) days of the date of the close of evidence. The hearing officer shall decide the guilt or innocence of the accused based on a preponderance of the evidence. The decision of the hearing officer shall be set forth in a detailed report, including specific findings of fact. In the event that the guilt of the accused is established, the report shall contain a detailed explanation for any suggested penalty, including a discussion of any aggravating or mitigating factors. 
(g)  Director of public safety's determination. 
(1)  Within thirty (30) days of the date of the receipt of the hearing officer's report, the director of public safety will issue the final decision, which may affirm, modify or reject the report of the hearing officer. 
(2)  In the event that the officer is found guilty of any charges, the director shall impose a penalty which may include any of following: 
a.  Removal from office as a member of the police department and employee of the borough. 
b.  Reduction in rank. 
c.  Suspension from duty without pay for any period not to exceed six (6) months. 
d.  Suspension with pay for any period. 
e.  Public reprimand. 
f.  Private reprimand. 
g.  Restitution for loss of property or costs of investigations or other actions. 
h.  Fines. 
i.  Any of the above penalties singly or in combination with each other. 
(3)  In the event that the hearing officer determines that the accused is not guilty of all of the offense(s) charged, that charge(s) will be dismissed and the accused shall be reinstated, and if the accused had been suspended without pay, any back pay accrued during the period of suspension shall be paid to the accused, less any funds earned by the officer from other sources during the time of his/her suspension. 
(h)  Appeals. Any member of the police department who has been convicted after any hearing offenses may seek review of the conviction in the superior court pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40A:14-150. 
(i)  Alternative procedures. 
(1)  In the event that the chief of police suffers from incapacity, or has committed misconduct or disobedience of the rules and regulations established for the government of the police department, the director of public safety shall act as the charging official and may file disciplinary charges as permitted by law. 
(2)  The director of public safety may appoint an investigator, who need not be a member of the police department, to conduct an investigation. All members of the police department and all other borough employees shall cooperate with the investigation. 
(3)  Any hearing of the charges against the chief of police shall be heard by a hearing officer in the manner set forth in subsection (f) of this section. The disposition of the matter, including the imposition of any penalty, shall be made by the board of commissioners. 
(4)  Notwithstanding anything set forth in this subsection, the chief of police may be issued an oral or written reprimand for minor instances of misconduct, disobedience, violations of the rules and regulations and for other improper conduct. The chief of police may file a written statement in response to any recorded reprimand, but there shall not be any right to appeal such discipline either by grievance or petition to the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, 11-10-2015) 
State Law reference- Permitted political activities, N.J.S.A. 40A:14-1467; police officer suspensions, N.J.S.A. 40A:14-147 et seq. 
Sec. 2-182. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  The director of public safety, in his/her capacity of the appropriate authority, shall adopt rules and regulations, or amendments thereto, for the government of the department and for discipline of its members. Proposed rules and regulations may be submitted by the chief of police, the borough solicitor or special counsel to the director of public safety. 
(b)  The director of public safety shall adopt the rules and regulations in writing which will be sent to the chief of police along with a true copy of the rules and regulations or any amendments thereto. 
(c)  Upon receipt of written notice of the adoption of rules and regulations by the director of public safety, the chief of police shall publish and distribute copies to the members of the department, who shall review and become familiar with the contents and provisions thereof. 
(d)  Failure to follow or comply with the rules and regulations shall subject any member of the police department to discipline pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40A:14-147. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, 11-10-2015) 
Sec. 2-183. - Special emergency directives. 
    Pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40A:14-118, the director of public safety shall have the authority to issue special emergency directives for the management, operation and discipline of the police department and its members and to promote the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the borough. For the purposes of this article, the term "emergency" means any sudden, unexpected or unforeseeable event requiring the immediate use or deployment of law enforcement personnel as shall be determined by the director of public safety, the chief of police or such other officer who has been given the authority of designating an "emergency" within or affecting the borough. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, 11-10-2015) 
Sec. 2-184. - Applicability of policies and procedures manual of the borough to the police department. 
    The provisions of the borough to the Audubon Policies and Procedures Manual, as amended, shall apply to all members and employees of the borough police department. In the event that the provisions of this Code, the rules and regulations of the borough police department, any applicable collective bargaining agreement or any federal or state law provide greater or more liberal benefits to the member of the police department, those provisions shall be applied. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, 11-10-2015) 
Sec. 2-185. - Extra-duty employment through borough. 
(a)  The term "extra-duty employment" is defined as work or services provided to private and public entities other than the borough that is conditioned on the actual or potential use of law enforcement powers by a member of the borough police department. The work or services may be provided while such member is in uniform or in plain clothes. 
(b)  Any person or entity wishing to receive police services which the borough is not obligated or expected to provide or does not usually provide as part of its regular plan of police services, may arrange to receive such services within the borough through the office of the chief of police. Such person should notify the chief of police, in writing, of the specific nature of the services desired at least fifteen (15) days before such services are required, unless exigent circumstances exist. All requests shall be subject to the availability of personnel as determined by the chief of police. The chief of police is responsible for public safety in the borough and as such shall administer all activities pursuant to this section as part of his/her regular duties, except as stated in subsection (d) of this section. 
(c)  All police services within the borough shall be delivered by officers from the borough police department, except as stated in subsection (d) of this section. If the chief of police determines that the demand cannot be met by the borough police department he may request additional police officers from outside agencies. The following are examples of extra-duty assignments that can be considered for contracting: 
(1)  Traffic control or pedestrian safety. 
(2)  Crowd control. 
(3)  Security and protection of life and property. 
(4)  Routine law enforcement for public authorities. 
(5)  Plain clothes assignments. 
(d)  Extra-duty police services shall not be required for road repair or construction projects conducted under the auspices, supervision or funding of the state or Federal Department of Transportation (DOT) so long as the contractor provides traffic directors (flag persons) as required or specified by the DOT. In the event that members of the borough police department agree to accept compensation in the role of traffic directors in the amount permitted by the DOT, they may be assigned to such projects if the contractor requests such services from the borough. The chief of police shall be informed of such road repair and construction projects. 
(e)  All requests for extra-duty police services will be made on a written form provided by the borough which shall state: 
(1)  The scope of services that are to be provided; 
(2)  The commencement date of the police services to be provided; 
(3)  The hours of authorized operation; 
(4)  The number of officers requested and total man-hours needed; and 
(5)  The anticipated date for completion of the police services. 
(f)  All police officers providing extra-duty services pursuant to this section shall be considered "on-duty" and will function under the supervision of the chief of police. The borough police department and its employees will maintain all employment rights while assigned to work extra-duty assignments. Employees working extra-duty assignments are required to adhere to the borough police department rules and regulations and all department policy and procedures and special orders and are subject to disciplinary action for any violation of the rules and regulations. 
(g)  Members of the police department are eligible to accept extra-duty employment only during periods when they are not assigned to regular duty and at times when such extra-duty employment will not interfere with the efficient performance of their regularly scheduled police duties. The chief of police or his/her designee shall monitor all extra-duty assignments to ensure that the borough's interests are protected. 
(h)  Any compensation received for extra employment shall not be applied to the member's pension benefits nor shall pension contributions be deducted from such compensation. The hours worked as extra employment shall not be counted or applied for the determination of the member's entitlement for overtime compensation for his/her regular employment with the borough. 
(i)  All requests for extra-duty police services will be finalized in a written agreement between the borough and the individual or entity requesting such services. The agreement shall specify the following: 
(1)  The scope of services that are to be provided; 
(2)  The commencement date of the police services to be provided; 
(3)  The hours of authorized operation; 
(4)  The number of officers requested and total man-hours needed; 
(5)  The anticipated date when the need for police services will be completed; 
(6)  The rate of compensation for the officers who perform services; 
(7)  The amount of any administrative fee imposed by the borough; and 
(8)  Such other terms that may be required to protect the borough, the officers providing services, the public and the party requesting police services. 
(j)  Compensation rates. 
(1)  There will be an administrative fee of ten dollars ($10.00) imposed for each hour of service rendered pursuant to this section. 
(2)  Compensation for services provided to schools within the borough shall be sixty dollars ($60.00) per hour (three-hour minimum). In the event officers are asked to assist with events for out-of-town school systems events; officers will receive the established rate of pay negotiated for that locality. 
(3)  Compensation for traffic director services provided on DOT-related projects and municipal projects shall be in the maximum amount permitted by the DOT. 
(4)  Compensation for services provided to all others shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per hour (four-hour minimum). 
(5)  Compensation for the use of police vehicles shall be eighty dollars ($80.00) per day of service, regardless of the number of hours actually served by an officer. 
(6)  There will be a three-hour show-up time for all cancellations due to weather without proper notification. Nonweather-related cancellations will be billed a four-hour minimum. 
(7)  All administrative fees shall be paid to the borough and shall be part of the general funds of the borough without limitations on their use. 
(8)  The chief of police shall report to the director of public safety concerning off-duty extra-duty employment and shall make recommendations on an annual basis concerning the rates to be charged for these services. 
(k)  Eligibility for extra-duty employment. 
(1)  To be eligible for extra-duty employment, a sworn officer must be in good standing with the department. Officers who are on medical or disability leave, who are suspended for disciplinary reasons, or who are otherwise on leave, are not eligible for extra-duty assignments. Officers who are in probationary status or part-time status may work off-duty employment at the discretion of the chief of police or his designee. 
(2)  Sworn officers may work no more than four (4) hours of extra-duty work in a workday while working a normal twelve-hour shift. Sworn officers may work no more than eight (8) hours of extra-duty work in a workday while working a normal eight-hour shift. At no time are sworn officers permitted to work more than sixteen (16) hours in a twenty-four-hour period. 
(3)  Extra-duty work will not be scheduled if it conflicts or interferes with an officer's performance of duty. The chief of police or his designee may authorize the use of earned time off when staffing requirements have been satisfied. 
(4)  Sworn officers assigned to extra-duty work may be subject to a recall for regular duty at any time and shall immediately leave the extra-duty assignment and shall respond as required by the department of police. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, 11-10-2015; Ord. No. 2017-07 , Art. 1, 9-19-2017) 
Sec. 2-186. - Off-duty employment by police officers. 
(a)  Off-duty employment is any employment or position that will not require the use, or potential use of law enforcement powers by the off-duty employee. 
(b)  Sworn police officers may engage in off-duty employment, subject to the restrictions or limitations stated herein, that: 
(1)  Is not law enforcement in nature; 
(2)  Does not require the use of police powers as a condition of employment; 
(3)  Presents no potential conflict of interest with the officer's responsibilities as a law enforcement officer; and 
(4)  Is not performed during assigned hours of duty. Some examples of employment representing conflicts of interest are: 
a.  Process servers, repossessions, bill collectors, towing of vehicles, collection of monies or merchandise for private purposes. 
b.  Personnel investigations for the private sector or any employment which might require the police officer to access police information, files, records, services as condition of employment or use such thereof. 
c.  Appearing in uniform during the performance of tasks other than that of police nature. 
d.  Assisting, in any manner, in the case preparation for the defense in any criminal proceeding. 
e.  Conducting activities for a business or labor group that is on strike. 
f.  Working in occupations that are regulated by, or that must be licensed through the police department. 
g.  Employment that constitutes a threat to the status or dignity of the police department or law enforcement, such as: 
1.  Establishments that sell sexually explicit books, magazines, sexual devices, videos, CDs, or services of a sexual nature. 
2.  Any groups dedicated to racist, ethnic or gender-related beliefs or philosophy. 
(c)  Sworn police officers wishing to engage in regular off-duty employment will submit a memo to the chief of police through the proper and established chain of command and receive permission from the chief of police (or his/her designee) to engage in regular off-duty employment. The memo shall contain: 
(1)  The name, address, telephone number, email address and business website of the employer. 
(2)  The nature of the work performed. 
(3)  The officer's off-duty work schedule, including the days and hours worked. 
(4)  Such other information as the chief of police may require. 
(d)  Eligibility for off-duty employment. 
(1)  Members of the police department are eligible to accept off-duty employment only during periods when they are not assigned to regular duty and at times when such off-duty employment will not interfere with the efficient performance of their regularly scheduled police duties. The chief of police or his/her designee shall monitor all off duty employment to ensure that the borough's interests are protected. 
(2)  To be eligible for off-duty employment, a sworn officer must be in good standing with the department. Officers who have not completed their probationary periods or who are on medical or disability leave are not eligible for extra-duty assignments. 
(3)  The following conditions apply to off-duty employment: 
a.  Sworn officers may work no more than four (4) hours of extra-duty work in a work day while working a normal twelve-hour shift. Sworn officers may work no more than eight (8) hours of extra-duty work in a work day while working a normal eight-hour shift. At no time are sworn officers permitted to work more than sixteen (16) hours in a twenty-four-hour period. 
b.  Sworn officers assigned to extra-duty work may be subject to a recall for regular duty at any time and shall immediately leave the extra-duty assignment and shall respond as required by the department of police. 
(4)  The chief of police shall include in his/her monthly report to the director of public safety information about the off-duty work of members of the department. 
(5)  A member of the department may be required to limit or terminate off-duty employment if the chief of police determines that the off-duty employment interferes with or threatens the status and dignity of the department or the ability of the member to perform his/her duties as a sworn police officer. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, 11-10-2015) 
Sec. 2-187. - Internal affairs guidelines. 
    The borough police department internal affairs guidelines are hereby adopted and shall be implemented by the police department. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, 11-10-2015) 
State Law reference- Requirement to so provide, N.J.S.A. 40A:14-181 et seq. 
Secs. 2-188-2-212. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-213-2-232. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HUMAN RELATIONS COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-233. - Established; confirmation. 
    There is hereby established and confirmed the creation of a commission to be known as the "Borough of Audubon Human Relations Commission." 
(Ord. No. 812-01, § 1(2-1), 5-2-2001) 
Sec. 2-234. - Purpose. 
(a)  The purpose of this division is to confirm the creation of a human relations commission. 
(b)  The creation of this commission affirms that this borough's strength and quality of life derives, in part, from its cultural diversity and recognizes that racial, ethnic or religious tension undermines the strength and unity of a community and is detrimental to the community's health and well-being. It is only through an environment of tolerance, mutual understanding and harmonious relations between all individuals of the borough's diverse population that a more perfect community can be realized. The uniqueness of each individual and different groups of individuals contributes to a beautiful panorama within the borough. 
(c)  The purpose of this commission is to promote good relations between all the people of this community and to demonstrate a high regard for the protection of the civil rights of all persons. Its ultimate goal is the integration of all unique human differences into a unified community. 
(Ord. No. 812-01, § 1(2-2), 5-2-2001) 
Sec. 2-235. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Human rights means any action or activity which has an effect on any person's based on race, creed, color, national or ethnic origin, ancestry, religious affiliation, age, marital status, affectional or sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, familial status, disability, nationality or sex. 
(Ord. No. 812-01, § 1(2-3), 5-2-2001) 
Sec. 2-236. - Membership, terms of office and vacancies. 
(a)  The human relations commission shall consist of a minimum of seven (7) and a maximum of nine (9) members, to be appointed by the board of commissioners who shall serve for a term of two (2) years, such terms to be staggered. No member shall serve more than two (2) consecutive two-year terms. The commencement date of membership term shall be July 1. In addition, there shall be a borough commission liaison member appointed by the mayor and board of commissioners with the consent of the borough commission, which liaison member shall serve as a non-voting member. In case of death, resignation or inability to serve, the successor shall be appointed in the same manner as the appointment of the original members, to fill the unexpired term of such member. 
(b)  Each member shall serve until his or her successor is duly appointed and qualified. Members shall serve without compensation. 
(c)  Members of the human relations commission shall not use the commission as a platform for their own political or personal gain. 
(Ord. No. 812-01, § 1(2-4), 5-2-2001) 
Sec. 2-237. - Organization; expenditures. 
    The human relations commission shall, as soon as possible after the July 1 of each year, select a chairperson and such other officers as it may deem necessary and shall adopt bylaws to govern its procedural operations. Upon request by the commission, there may be appropriated in each annual budget of the borough such sum as may be determined by the board of commissioners to be necessary for the purposes of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 812-01, § 1(2-5), 5-2-2001) 
Sec. 2-238. - Powers and duties. 
    The commission shall act in any advisory capacity to the board of commissioners. It is not intended to and may in no way act to function as a review board of police or another borough department activity and may not infringe upon, or in any manner usurp the power and authority granted by law to the mayor or board of commissioners in manners including, but not limited to, the hiring and removing of personnel or the general supervision over all departments, offices, agencies, officials or employees of the borough. The commission shall: 
(1)  Carry out educational programs which promote tolerance, understanding and harmonious relations between all individuals of the borough; 
(2)  Foster participation in and encourage individual, organizational, neighborhood and community efforts to engender understanding, good will, cooperation and conciliation among the various groups and individuals of this borough; 
(3)  Receive, mediate and seek reconciliation of the problems brought to its attention by individuals of the borough and by the borough government with respect to matters involving human rights; 
(4)  Monitor the borough's commitment to equal rights and assure the borough's conformity with existing civil rights laws while promoting the goals of equality, justice and harmony; 
(5)  Serve as a conciliation agency where the services of the commission might be effective in accomplishing its objective; 
(6)  Oversee the administration of sensitivity training on racial, ethnic and religious relations for the board of commissioners, and all members of the borough's boards, committees, agencies and authorities serving the community; 
(7)  Study and analyze the status, nature and extent of discrimination, prejudice, bias, intolerance and indifference in the community at large; 
(8)  Report from time to time, and not less than once a year, to the board of commissioners on ways and means to promote and encourage understanding, good will, cooperation, equal opportunity and conciliation in the community at large, and ways and means to eliminate discrimination, bias, intolerance, indifference and group tensions in the community at large. 
(Ord. No. 812-01, § 1(2-6), 5-2-2001) 
Secs. 2-239-2-269. - Reserved.

DIVISION 3. - COST RECOVERY FOR HAZARDOUS MATERIAL DISCHARGES[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Exemption from liability and cleanup costs, N.J.S.A. 58:10-23.11g12. 

Sec. 2-322. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cleanup and removal costs means all costs associated with a discharge within the boundaries of the borough, which shall include labor and material for the removal of hazardous substances or taking of reasonable measures to prevent or mitigate damages to the public health, safety or welfare of the residents of the borough, including the lands, private and public, therein. 
    Discharge means any intentional or unintentional action or omission resulting in the release, spill, leak, emission, dumping or disposal of hazardous substances into the waters or on lands within the borough or outside the borough when damage may result to the waters or lands inside the borough. 
    Hazardous substance means all elements and compounds, including petroleum products as set forth within N.J.S.A. 58:10-23.11b, except that sewage and sewage sludge shall be considered "hazardous substances" for the purpose of this chapter. 
(Code 1992, § 194-1; Ord. No. 677, 2-18-1992) 
Sec. 2-323. - Assignment of liability. 
    Any person who shall discharge hazardous substances within the borough shall be strictly liable for all cleanup and removal costs incurred by the borough or agencies and employees thereof. 
(Code 1992, § 194-2; Ord. No. 677, 2-18-1992) 
Sec. 2-324. - Hearing upon reasonableness of assessment. 
    Upon assessment of cleanup and removal costs, the person assessed may, within ten (10) days of receipt of such assessment, make a written request for a hearing before the commissioners exclusively upon the reasonableness of the amount assessed. 
(Code 1992, § 194-3; Ord. No. 677, 2-18-1992) 
Sec. 2-325. - Liability for attorneys' fees and collection costs. 
    The person responsible for the discharge shall be liable for all reasonable attorneys' fees and costs incurred in the collection of cleanup and removal costs. 
(Code 1992, § 194-3; Ord. No. 677, 2-18-1992) 
Secs. 2-326-2-353. - Reserved.

Footnotes:

State Law reference- Public records generally, N.J.S.A. 47:1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-354. - Public record request forms. 
(a)  The borough commissioners of the borough hereby adopt the "public record request form," a copy of which is attached to Ord. No. 832-02 and made a part of this article by reference, and that such public record request form shall be completed in its entirety and submitted in writing by any member of the general public requesting such government records as described in N.J.S.A. title 47, ch. 1A. (N.J.S.A. 47:1A-1 et seq.). 
(b)  The borough commissioners of the borough hereby adopt the "police department request for public records," a copy of which is attached to Ord. No. 832-02 and made a part of this article by reference, for use by the police department, specifically the police chief, who has been designated as the "deputy custodian of records" by Resolution 73-02 adopted on July 2, 2002, for matters involving requests for police-related information and documents. 
(c)  All distributed public request forms shall include the attachments advising the public of their rights under N.J.S.A. title 47, ch. 1A. (N.J.S.A. 47:1A-1 et seq.). In addition, in accordance with said law, such public notification of the rights of the public to appeal a denial of or failure to provide requested information shall be prominently posted within the municipal building. 
(Ord. No. 832-02, § 1, 8-27-2002) 
Sec. 2-355. - Procedures for requests. 
(a)  These forms must be completed and remitted to the proper "custodian of records" at which time such custodian shall determine the validity of such request, when such information shall be ready, and the estimated cost for copies of such documents. In addition, the requestor may be responsible for providing a deposit of one-half of the estimated cost of such documents at the time such request is made. The requestor shall be provided a copy of the completed public record request form at the time such request is received, reviewed and completed by the proper custodian of records. 
(b)  If received by someone other than the official custodian of records, all public record request forms shall be initialed by the person receiving such request, stamped with the date received and the time of such receipt also noted on the form, and remitted to the proper "custodian of records" at the earliest possible time. The custodian of records shall also note the date and time received by him/her. In accordance with such law, access to or denial of access to a government record shall be determined and made available within seven (7) business days after receipt of such request by the proper custodian of records. 
(Ord. No. 832-02, § 2, 8-27-2002) 
Sec. 2-356. - Fees generally. 
(a)  Whenever the nature, format, matter of collation or volume of a government record embodied in the form of printed matter to be inspected, examined or copied pursuant to the Open Public Records Law is such that the record cannot be reproduced by ordinary document copying equipment in ordinary business size or involves an extraordinary expenditure of time and effort to accommodate the request, the public agency may charge, in addition to the actual cost of duplicating the record, a special charge that shall be reasonable and shall be based upon the actual direct cost of providing the copy or copies or service, as well as reasonable administrative fees. Such fees shall be determined prior to providing such copy or copies, and the requestor shall have the opportunity to review the object to the charge prior to it being incurred. 
(b)  The duplication of any copies of normal governmental documents shall be charged at a statutory rate of shall be five cents ($0.05) per letter size page or smaller, and seven cents ($0.07) per legal size page or larger. 
Municipal and tax lien searches, per copy ..... $10.00 
(c)  Under special circumstances, all other provisions relative to costs and fees not detailed within this article shall be administered as detailed within N.J.S.A. title 47, ch. 1A (N.J.S.A. 47:1A-1 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 832-02, § 3, 8-27-2002)
