Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Alcoholic beverages generally, N.J.S.A. 33:1-1 et seq.; municipal regulation of alcohol, N.J.S.A. 33:1-40. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Consumption restricted; discarding containers. 
(a)  Consuming alcoholic beverages. No person shall consume alcoholic beverages: 
(1)  While in or on a public street, lane, sidewalk, public parking lot, public or quasi-public place or in any public conveyance. 
(2)  In a private motor vehicle while the same is parked in any public street, lane or public parking lot. This subsection shall not apply to a passenger of a charter or special bus operated as defined under N.J.S.A. 48:4-1, or a limousine service. 
(b)  Discarding containers. No person shall discard alcoholic beverage containers upon any public street, lane, sidewalk, public parking lot, public or quasi-public place or upon any private property not his/her own without the express permission of the owner. 
(c)  No person shall suffer, aid, abet or permit any person to violate any provision of this section. 
(Code 1992, § 110-1; Ord. No. 409, 5-25-1976) 
Secs. 6-2-6-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DEALERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-21. - Application of restrictions. 
    Restrictions as set forth in this article shall apply to any transferee and/or holder of any license issued pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 20, 8-27-2002; Ord. No. 845-03, 6-24-2003; Ord. No. 903-06, 5-23-2006; Ord. No. 913-06, 11-28-2006) 
Sec. 6-22. - Hours of sale. 
(a)  No plenary retail consumption licensee shall sell, or deliver, or allow, permit or suffer the sale, or delivery of, any alcoholic beverage on licensed premises on any day between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 10:00 a.m., with the exception of January 1 of each year, when the hours during which no such sales shall be made, as set forth above, shall be between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m. 
(b)  No plenary retail distribution licensee shall sell, or deliver, or allow, permit or suffer the sale, or delivery of, any alcoholic beverage on licensed premises for consumption off the licensed premises in original containers on any day between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 10:00 a.m., with the exception of January 1 of each year, when the hours during which no such sales shall be made, as set forth above, shall be between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 12, 8-27-2002; Ord. No. 845-03, 6-24-2003; Ord. No. 903-06, 5-23-2006; Ord. No. 913-06, 11-28-2006) 
Sec. 6-23. - Restrictions; sexually oriented activities. 
    No sexually oriented activities shall take place within any portion of any licensed premise within the borough. The term "sexually oriented activities" means the fondling or other erotic touching of uncovered or covered genitalia, pubic region, buttocks, or female breast or any actual or simulated act of masturbation, sexual intercourse or deviant sexual intercourse; the appearance of waiters or waitresses or other employees, either topless or bottomless and with less than completely and opaquely covered genitals, pubic region, buttocks, or female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 16, 8-27-2002) 
Sec. 6-24. - Nude or nearly nude activity. 
(a)  The term "nude or nearly nude activity" means and includes any person performing, showing, exhibiting, acting or representing such a manner or attire as to expose to view any portion of the pubic area, anus, vulva or genitals or any simulation thereof, or any female showing, performing, exhibiting, acting or representing in such a manner or attire as to expose to view that portion of the breast referred to as the areola or nipple, or simulation thereof. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or perform or allow to be conducted or performed any nude or nearly nude activity on or within any premises for which a plenary retail alcohol consumption license has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 19, 8-27-2002) 
Sec. 6-25. - Unaccompanied persons under legal age excluded. 
    No plenary retail consumption licensee shall permit any patron who is under the legal age to purchase and consume alcoholic beverages or to be within any room in which any bar is located, unless said patron is accompanied by a parent, legal guardian or spouse, provided that said parent, legal guardian or spouse shall have attained the age at which a person may purchase and consume alcoholic beverages. This section shall not apply to the dining area of any bona fide restaurant whose principal business is the service of food. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 13, 8-27-2002) 
Sec. 6-26. - Sale to intoxicated persons. 
    No licensee shall sell, serve, deliver or allow, permit or suffer to service or delivery of any alcoholic beverage, directly or indirectly, to any person actually or apparently intoxicated, or allow, permit or suffer the consumption of alcoholic beverage by any such person upon such licensed premises. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 18, 8-27-2002) 
Secs. 6-27-6-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 6-56. - Sales without license prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell or distribute alcoholic beverages in the borough without a license previously applied for and granted pursuant to the provisions of this division and the New Jersey Alcoholic Beverage Control Act (N.J.S.A. 33:1-1 et seq.), with the exception of one-day permits authorized by the Act. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 6, 8-27-2002) 
Sec. 6-57. - Applicable statutes and rules. 
    All applications for license under this division and any license issued hereunder and proceedings in connection therewith shall be subject to state statute and the rules promulgated by the division of alcoholic beverage control of the state, and shall be subject to any other laws hereafter enacted affecting said subject matters. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 2, 8-27-2002) 
Sec. 6-58. - Administrative authority. 
    The commissioners of the borough being the governing body shall constitute the authority for the administration of issuance of any license issued under this division and shall forthwith report the issuance of such license to said state commissioner of the division of alcoholic beverage control. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 3, 8-27-2002; Ord. No. 845-03, 6-24-2003; Ord. No. 903-06, 5-23-2006; Ord. No. 913-06, 11-28-2006) 
Sec. 6-59. - Contents of application. 
    All applications for licenses shall set forth in full the answers to questions as prescribed by the Act and by the rules and regulations of said state commissioner and shall include declarations called for by said provisions. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 8, 8-27-2002) 
Sec. 6-60. - Qualifications for license. 
    No license shall be issued to any person, firm, corporation, group or partnership not fully qualified under the provisions of said Act and said rules and regulations. The chief of police shall submit a report to the board of commissioners upon review of the application in accordance with the Act. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 9, 8-27-2002) 
Sec. 6-61. - Issuance of a license. 
    Pursuant to N.J.S.A. 33:1-19.1 and the New Jersey Alcoholic Beverage Control Act (N.J.S.A. 33:1-1 et seq.), the borough may, by resolution, determine to permit the issuance of a plenary retail consumption license to the highest qualified bidder at a public auction. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 4, 8-27-2002) 
Sec. 6-62. - Limitation of licenses. 
    There shall be three (3) plenary retail consumption licenses within the borough. There shall be one (1) plenary retail distribution license within the borough. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 5, 8-27-2002; Ord. No. 845-03, 6-24-2003; Ord. No. 903-06, 5-23-2006; Ord. No. 913-06, 11-28-2006) 
Sec. 6-63. - Plenary retail consumption license fee. 
    The annual fee for a plenary retail consumption license and a plenary retail distribution license is two thousand four hundred dollars ($2,400.00). The holder of a plenary retail consumption license and plenary retail distribution license shall be entitled to sell for consumption or distribution on the licensed premises alcoholic beverages, subject to the provisions of Title 33 of the state statutes and the rules, regulations, conditions and restrictions regulating the license. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 7, 8-27-2002; Ord. No. 903-06, 5-23-2006; Ord. No. 913-06, 11-28-2006) 
Sec. 6-64. - Increase in license fee. 
    Commencing in the licensing year 2004, and thereafter as permitted by law, the borough clerk is authorized and directed to increase the annual licensing fee for retail consumption licenses by the sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00) over the existing fee. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 7.1, 8-27-2002) 
Sec. 6-65. - Term of license; proration of fee; surrender. 
(a)  The license provided hereunder shall be for a term of one (1) year from July 1 in each year, and all fees shall be paid in advance upon presentation of the application; provided, however, that any licensee, who shall voluntarily surrender his/her license and who shall not have committed any violation of this division or of any rule or regulation and who shall have paid all taxes, setoffs, or counterclaims that may have become due to the state or to the borough, shall be entitled to, after deduction of fifty percent (50%) of said fee, as a surrender fee, to the prorated fee for the unexpired term. 
(b)  Any licensee who shall not have actively engaged in the sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages in the borough for a period of at least one hundred eighty (180) days annually shall forthwith surrender his/her license upon demand of the governing body of the borough, after proceedings for revocation shall be held in accordance with section 6-68. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 10, 8-27-2002) 
Sec. 6-66. - Restrictions on location. 
    The plenary retail consumption licenses shall be issued for the sale of alcoholic beverages subject to following restrictions: 
(1)  One (1) plenary retail consumption license shall be issued for the sale of alcoholic beverages in a restaurant to be located within the redevelopment zone known as the Black Horse Shopping Center District for the borough by Ordinance No. 831-02. 
(2)  One (1) plenary retail consumption license shall be issued for the sale of alcoholic beverages in a restaurant to be located in the Special Improvement and Business District for the borough, excluding the area added to the Special Improvement and Business District by Ordinance No. 845-03. 
(3)  One (1) plenary retail consumption license shall be issued for the sale of alcoholic beverages in a restaurant to be located within the redevelopment zone known as the Black Horse Shopping Center District for the borough by Ordinance No. 913-06. 
(4)  The plenary retail distribution license shall be located in premises having at least ten thousand (10,000) square feet devoted to that purpose that are located within the redevelopment zone known as the Black Horse Shopping Center District for the borough by Ordinance No. 903-06. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 14, 8-27-2002; Ord. No. 845-03, 6-24-2003; Ord. No. 903-06, 5-23-2006; Ord. No. 913-06, 11-28-2006) 
Sec. 6-67. - License to be posted and displayed. 
(a)  Before any licensee to whom a license has been issued shall start doing business for the period of time for which the license has been issued, the licensee shall enclose the license in a suitable frame having clear glass space and substantial backing, so that whole such license may be seen therein. The license thereupon shall be so posted and at all times displayed in a conspicuous place in the main or principal room where the licensee's business is being carried on so that all persons visiting such place of business may readily see the same. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person holding such license, or his/her servant, agent or employee to post license or permit the same to be posted upon premises other than the premises licensed or upon premises where traffic in alcoholic beverages is being carried on by any person other than the licensee, or his/her servant, agent or employee. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 17, 8-27-2002) 
Sec. 6-68. - Suspension or revocation of license. 
(a)  Any license issued under this division may be suspended or revoked for violation of any of the provisions of this division or any of the provisions of said Act or said statutes heretofore mentioned or of any of the regulations and rules prescribed by said state commissioner of alcoholic beverage control. 
(b)  Proceedings for suspension or revocation shall be in accordance with the provisions of said Act, by service of a five-day notice of charges preferred against the licensee, as provided in said Act, and by the affording of a reasonable opportunity for a hearing, and such suspension or revocation shall carry the penalties and prohibitions provided for in said Act. 
(Ord. No. 831-02, § 11, 8-27-2002) 
Chapter 10 - AMUSEMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate amusements, N.J.S.A. 40:52-1(f). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 10-1-10-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AMUSEMENT BUSINESSES 

Sec. 10-19. - Regulations and inspections. 
    All amusement businesses shall be subject to such police regulation and inspection as the director of public safety may from time to time promulgate. 
(Code 1992, § 114-5; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 10-20. - Permit. 
(a)  Required. No person or persons or corporation or corporations shall open, operate or maintain a bowling alley, poolroom, theater, roller-skating rink, miniature golf course, driving and putting course, street carnival, dance hall, traveling circus or any other amusement where a fee is charged, within the limits of the borough, without first taking out a permit therefor. Said permit shall be approved by the board of commissioners of the borough. 
(b)  Application. All applications for permits shall be made to the borough clerk on blanks to be furnished by him and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  The location of the business for which the permit is desired. 
(3)  A certificate of the fire marshal stating that the building in which said business is to be conducted is not a fire hazard. 
(c)  Term; fees. Each permit shall be issued until revoked by the board of commissioners, and the applicant shall pay to the borough clerk for the use of the borough the sum of one dollar ($1.00) therefor. In addition to the permit fee, an annual license fee of five dollars ($5.00) per year shall be paid to the borough, the license to be issued by the borough clerk. 
(d)  Transfer; revocation. Permits shall not be transferable and shall be subject to revocation by resolution of the board of commissioners upon complaint made that the amusement is being operated so as to constitute a nuisance or if the owner or operator of such amusement is convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude and if such complaint is found justified by a majority vote of the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1992, §§ 114-1-114-3, 114-7; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 10-21. - Saturday and Sunday operation. 
    All bowling alleys, poolrooms, theaters, roller-skating rinks, miniature golf courses, driving and putting courses, street carnivals, dance halls, traveling circuses and other amusements where a fee is charged shall close not later than 12:00 midnight (prevailing time) Saturday and shall not open on Sundays. 
(Code 1992, § 114-4; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 10-22. - Outdoor lighting. 
    Lighting systems installed on any open-air miniature golf course or driving and putting course or in front of an amusement business shall not interfere with the comfort and privacy of the occupants of the neighboring premises and shall not dazzle the vision of persons using the public streets. 
(Code 1992, § 114-6; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 10-23. - Street carnivals. 
    Street carnivals given by local organizations for public or charitable purposes shall not be required to pay any fee for the issuance of a permit, but in all other respects shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1992, § 114-8; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Secs. 10-24-10-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AMUSEMENT DEVICES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-50. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Coin-controlled amusement device means a machine which, upon the insertion of a coin or slug, operates or may be operated for use as a game, contest or amusement of any description or which may be used for any such game, contest or amusement and which contains no automatic payoff device for the return of slugs, money, coin checks, tokens or merchandise, and shall include pinball machines and other coin-controlled devices in which marbles, balls or pellets are projected or propelled by spring or plunger or any other means wherein such marbles, balls or pellets fall into slots, tracks, grooves or any other position or wherein said marbles, balls or pellets strike pins or objects, which machine may be used as a game of skill or amusement. 
(Code 1992, § 118-2; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 10-51. - Use for gambling unlawful. 
    No person shall use or permit to be used any coin-controlled amusement device licensed hereunder for the purpose of gambling. 
(Code 1992, § 118-8; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 10-52. - Minimum age of operators. 
    No person under the age of sixteen (16) years shall be permitted to play any of said machines. 
(Code 1992, § 118-9; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Secs. 10-53-10-77. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-78. - License required. 
    No person shall place, operate or maintain, or permit to be placed, operated, used or maintained, in any public or quasi-public place or in any store, building or other place wherein the public is invited or may enter, or in or upon premises used as a clubhouse or as club rooms, within the limits of the borough, any coin-controlled amusement device, without first having obtained a license for each such device. 
(Code 1992, § 118-1; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 10-79. - License application. 
    Applications for licenses hereunder shall be made to the borough clerk of upon a form to be furnished by the borough and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name of the applicant. If the applicant is a corporation, the application shall contain the names of the officers and directors of the corporation. 
(2)  The residence of the applicant. 
(3)  The place of business of the applicant. 
(4)  The number of licenses desired. 
(5)  The address or addresses where each machine or device is to be located. 
(Code 1992, § 118-4; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 10-80. - Issuance of license; expiration; fee. 
    The license for the placing, operating, maintenance or use of such coin-controlled amusement device shall be issued by the clerk of the borough to and in the name of the owner of such device. All licenses hereunder shall expire on December 31 of the year for which they are issued. The license fee shall be eighty dollars ($80.00) for each coin-controlled amusement device. An operator may have no more than three (3); said licenses are not transferable. A separate license shall be obtained for each such device and shall be affixed thereto. 
(Code 1992, § 118-3; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 515, 2-8-1983) 
Sec. 10-81. - Coin-operated rides. 
(a)  A coin-controlled amusement device used to entertain children under the age of sixteen (16) by giving them a ride on the device shall be licensed at the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) per year for each device. 
(b)  A group of said devices, exceeding three (3) and not exceeding ten (10), may be licensed for the sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per year, provided that said devices are all in the same area and under the control of the same licensee. 
(c)  In the event that the application is made for said license on or after July 1 in any particular year, the license shall be issued for the balance of said year at half the annual license fee. 
(Code 1992, § 118-10; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 10-82. - Contents of license. 
    Every license issued hereunder shall be numbered and shall disclose on its face the name and post office address of the licensee to whom it is issued and the address of the establishment wherein the licensed device shall be located. 
(Code 1992, § 118-6; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 10-83. - Transfer of license. 
    The holder of a license issued hereunder shall be permitted to transfer such license from any machine to any other like or similar machine operated in the same premises for which the license is issued by removing the license from such machine and affixing it to such other machine. The holder of any license shall be permitted to transfer any license issued hereunder from a machine in any establishment to a like or similar machine in another establishment by surrendering such license to the borough clerk and obtaining a new license for such machine for the location to which the license is transferred, upon payment to the borough clerk of a transfer fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Code 1992, § 118-7; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 10-84. - Display of license. 
    No coin-controlled amusement device shall be placed, operated, maintained or used or permitted to be placed, operated, maintained or used in the borough until the license required hereunder shall be affixed thereto in a conspicuous place so that the same may be easily identified. Any such device which shall not have a license as required herein affixed thereto shall be deemed to be an unlicensed device. Any person having supervision or control over any store, building or other place where the public may enter, or any clubhouse or club room, wherein any such device without a license affixed thereto is operated, used or maintained shall be deemed to have permitted such unlicensed device to be placed, operated, used and maintained therein in violation of the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1992, § 118-5; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Cruelty to animals, N.J.S.A. 4-22-11.1 et seq.; general authority relative to animals, N.J.S.A. 40:48-1(11). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Wildlife feeding. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings stated herein unless their use in the text of this section clearly demonstrates a different meaning: 
    Feed means to give, place, expose, deposit, distribute or scatter any edible material with the intention of feeding, attracting or enticing wildlife. The term "feeding" does not include baiting in the legal taking of fish and/or game. 
    Wildlife means all animals that are neither human nor domesticated. 
(b)  Prohibited. No person shall feed, in any public park or on any other property owned or operated by the borough, any wildlife, excluding confined wildlife (for example, wildlife confined in zoos, parks or rehabilitation centers, or unconfined wildlife at environmental education centers). 
(c)  Enforcement. This section shall be enforced by the borough police department and/or zoning enforcement of the borough. Any person found to be in violation of this section shall be ordered to cease the feeding immediately. 
(d)  Penalty. Any person who is found to be in violation of the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. of 12-28-2004, §§ II-V) 
Secs. 14-2-14-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ANIMAL CONTROL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Dogs, N.J.S.A. 4:19-1 et seq.; animal control officers required, N.J.S.A. 4:19-15.16b. 

Sec. 14-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means a cat or a dog. 
    Animal care facility means an animal control center or animal shelter, maintained by or under contract with any state, county, or municipality, whose mission and practice is, in whole, or significant part, the rescue and placement of animals in permanent homes or rescue organizations. 
    Animal control authority means any person or agency designated or certified by the state to enforce the provisions of this article, including the borough animal control officer, or any person or entity under contract with the borough for the control of animals. 
    Animal control officer means a certified municipal animal control officer or, in the absence of such an officer, the chief law enforcement officer of the municipality or his designee. 
    Animal of licensing age means any cat or dog which has attained the age of seven (7) months or which possesses a set of permanent teeth. 
    Animal rescue organization means any not-for-profit organization which has tax-exempt status under Section 501(c)(3) of the United States Internal Revenue Code, whose mission and practice is, in whole or in significant part, the rescue and placement of animals in permanent homes. 
    Cat means a member of the species of domestic cat, Felis catus. 
    Cattery means any room or group of rooms, cage or exhibition pen not part of a kennel, wherein cats for sale are kept or displayed. 
    Dog means a member of the species of domestic dog, Canis familiaris. 
    Harboring means maintaining custody or control over an animal or permitting an animal to remain on the premises or providing shelter or food, which shall include the leaving of food in an area to which stray animals have access. 
    Household means a domestic unit consisting of a person or group of people occupying a single dwelling. 
    Licensing authority means the agency or department of the borough or any designated representative thereof charged with administering the issuance and/or revocation of permits and licenses under the provisions of this article. 
    Neutered means rendered permanently incapable of reproduction as certified by a licensed veterinarian. 
    Offer for sale means to sell, offer for sale or adoption, advertise for the sale of, barter, auction, give away or otherwise dispose of a dog or cat. 
    Owner, when applied to the proprietorship of an animal, means and includes every person having a right of property (or custody) in such animal and every person who has such animal in his keeping or who harbors or maintains an animal or knowingly permits an animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by that person. 
    Pet shop means a retail establishment where dogs and cats are sold, exchanged, bartered or offered for sale as pet animals to the general public at retail. Such definition shall not include an animal care facility or animal rescue organization, as defined. 
    Potentially dangerous dog means any dog or dog hybrid declared potentially dangerous by a municipal court pursuant to N.J.S.A. 4:19-23 which has caused bodily injury as defined in N.J.S.A. 2C:11-1(a) to a person during an unprovoked attack, and poses a serious threat of bodily injury or death to a person, or severely injured or killed another domestic animal, and poses a threat of serious bodily injury or death to a person, or poses a threat of death to another domestic animal, or has been trained, tormented, badgered, baited or encouraged to engage in unprovoked attacks upon persons or domestic animals. 
    Public nuisance means an animal that damages either public or private property or harms the lawful users or occupants thereof. 
    Spayed means rendered permanently incapable of reproduction as certified by a licensed veterinarian. 
    Stray animal means a cat or a dog having no known owner or custodian or known place of care and shelter. 
    Vicious dog means any dog which has killed a person or caused serious bodily injury as defined by N.J.S.A. 2C:11-1(b) to a person or has engaged in dog fighting activities as described in N.J.S.A. 4:22-24 and N.J.S.A. 4:22-26. 
    Violent dog means any dog which has attacked or bitten any human being or which habitually attacks other dogs or domestic animals. 
(Ord. No. 929-07, art. I, 9-25-2007; Ord. No. 2015-08, art. I, 10-6-2015; Ord. No. 2015-09, § 1, 10-20-2015; Ord. No. 2016-05 , 3-15-2016) 
Sec. 14-22. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, any person who violates or who fails or refuses to comply with this article shall be liable to a penalty of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, to be recovered by and in the name of the local board of health or by and in the name of the borough. 
(b)  Vicious dogs. Except as may be provided by state statute, any person who violates or refuses to comply with this article as it related to vicious dogs shall be liable to a penalty of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per day of violation, and each day's continuance of the violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 929-07, art. VIII, 9-25-2007) 
Sec. 14-23. - Permitted animals. 
(a)  Number of animals permitted. No household within the borough shall harbor more than three (3) cats or three (3) dogs at any time. A household may not harbor more than a total combined number of five (5) cats and dogs at any one time. 
(b)  Effective date. Notwithstanding the provisions of the foregoing subsection, any owner who is harboring more than three (3) cats and/or three (3) dogs in a household at September 25, 2007, shall be permitted to keep and maintain said number of animals provided that all such animals are properly vaccinated and licensed in accordance with the requirements set forth herein within ninety (90) days of such date. An owner shall be entitled to maintain the presently existing number of animals greater than the number permitted by this article for the lifetime of such animals or unless they otherwise cease to be harbored within that household. Upon the happening of such event, such animal(s) may not be replaced unless and until the number of cats and/or dogs harbored by the owner complies with the requirements of subsection (a) of this section, that is, there are three (3) cats or less, three (3) dogs or less or a combined number of no more than five (5) animals in the household. 
(Ord. No. 929-07, art. II, 9-25-2007) 
Sec. 14-24. - Vaccination requirements. 
(a)  Vaccination and license requirements. No person shall own, keep, harbor or maintain any animal over seven (7) months of age within the borough unless such animal is vaccinated and licensed. The provisions of this section do not apply to animals held in a cattery or kennel or to those held by a state or federally licensed research facility or veterinary establishment where animals are received or kept for diagnostic, medical, surgical or other treatments or licensed animal shelters, pounds or pet shops. 
(b)  Vaccination. All animals shall be vaccinated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian in accordance with the latest "Compendium of Animal Rabies Vaccines and Recommendations for Immunization" published by the National Association of State Public Health Veterinarians, except as provided for in subsection (d) of this section. 
(c)  Vaccination certificate. A certificate of vaccination shall be issued on a form recommended by the state to the owner of each vaccinated animal. 
(d)  Exemptions. Any animal may be exempted from the requirements of such vaccination for a specified period of time by the local board of health upon presentation of a veterinarian's certificate stating that because of an infirmity or other physical condition or regimen of therapy, the inoculation of such animal shall be deemed inadvisable. 
(Ord. No. 929-07, art. III, 9-25-2007) 
Sec. 14-25. - License requirements; fees. 
(a)  Animals must have a license number displayed. 
(1)  Any person who shall own, keep or harbor an animal of licensing age within the limits of the borough shall annually apply for and procure from the licensing authority of the borough or other official designated by the governing body thereof to license animals in the borough in which he resides a license and official registration tag with license number or a registration sleeve for each animal so owned, kept or harbored, and shall place upon such animal a collar or other device with the license number securely fastened or displayed thereto. Acceptable methods of displaying license numbers shall include but are not limited to break-away or elastic collars. License tags or sleeves are not transferable. 
(2)  Any person or persons keeping a kennel shall within ninety (90) days of the passage of this article, and annually thereafter, report said fact to the licensing authority, who shall, after approval of the board of health, issue licenses to keep kennels to such person or persons. 
(b)  Time for applying for license. The owner of any newly acquired animal of licensing age or of any animal which attains licensing age shall make application for a license tag or sleeve for such animal within ten (10) days after such acquisition or age attainment. This requirement will not apply to a nonresident harboring an animal within the borough for no longer than ninety (90) days. 
(c)  Animals brought into the borough. 
(1)  Any person who shall bring or cause to be brought into the borough any animal licensed in another state for the current year and bearing a registration tag or sleeve and who shall keep the same or permit the same to be kept within the borough for a period of more than ninety (90) days shall immediately apply for a license and registration tag or sleeve for such animal. 
(2)  Any person who shall bring or cause to be brought into the borough any unlicensed animal and who shall keep the same or permit the same to be kept within the borough for a period of more than ten (10) days shall immediately apply for a license and registration tag or sleeve for each such animal. 
(d)  Application information. The application shall state the name, breed, sex, age, color and markings of the animal for which the license and registration are sought. It shall also state the name, street and post office address of the owner and the person who shall keep or harbor such animal. The information on said application and the registration number issued for the animal shall be preserved for a period of three (3) years by the licensing authority or other local official designated to license animals in the borough. 
(e)  License forms and official tags. License forms and official tags or sleeves shall be furnished by the borough and shall be numbered serially and shall bear the year of issuance and the name of the borough. 
(f)  Evidence of rabies inoculation. No licensing authority or other official designated by the governing body of any municipality to license animals therein shall grant any such license and official registration tag or sleeve for any animal unless the owner thereof provides evidence that the animal to be licensed and registered has been inoculated with a rabies vaccine of a type approved by and administered in accordance with the recommendation of the United States Department of Agriculture and the United States Department of Human Services or has been certified exempt as provided by section 14-24(d). The rabies inoculation shall be administered by a duly licensed veterinarian or by such other veterinarian permitted by law to do the same. 
(g)  License fees. 
(1)  Twenty dollars ($20.00) for each unneutered/unspayed animal. 
(2)  Fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each neutered/spayed animal. 
(3)  Five dollar ($5.00) late fee after March 31 and a ten dollar ($10.00) late fee after June 30. 
(h)  Fees, renewals and expiration of license. 
(1)  A license from another municipality shall be accepted. The person applying for the license and registration tag and/or sleeve shall pay the fee fixed or authorized. The fee for the renewal of a license and registration tag or sleeve shall be the same as for the original, and said license, registration tag or sleeve and renewal thereof shall expire on December 31 in the following year. 
(2)  Only one license and registration tag or sleeve shall be required in the licensing year for any animal in the borough. Any valid New Jersey license tag or sleeve issued by a New Jersey municipality shall be accepted by the borough as evidence of compliance. 
(i)  Loss of license. If a license tag or sleeve has been misplaced or lost, the licensing authority may issue a duplicate license and/or registration sleeve for that particular animal at a fee of one dollar ($1.00). 
(j)  Proof of licensing. Proof of licensing shall be produced by any person owning, keeping, maintaining or harboring an animal, or operating a kennel, upon the request of any health official, police officer, animal control officer or other authorized person. 
(k)  Interference with officials. No person shall hinder, molest or interfere with anyone authorized or empowered to perform any duty under this section. 
(l)  Disposition of fees. 
(1)  License fees and other moneys collected or received under the provisions of this article shall be forwarded to the treasurer of the borough, and shall be used for the following purposes only: 
a.  Collecting, keeping and disposing of any animal liable to seizure; 
b.  Local prevention and control of rabies; 
c.  Providing anti-rabies treatment under the direction of the local board of health for any person known or suspected to have been exposed to rabies; and 
d.  Administering the provisions of this section. 
(2)  Any unexpected balance remaining in such special account shall be retained until the end of the third fiscal year following and may be used for any of the purposes set forth in this section. At the end of said third fiscal year following and at the end of each fiscal year thereafter, there shall be transferred from such special account to the general funds of the borough any amount then in such account which is in excess of the total amount paid into the special account during the last two (2) fiscal years next preceding. 
(Ord. No. 929-07, art. IV, 9-25-2007; Ord. No. 2014-17, 12-30-2014) 
Sec. 14-26. - Control over animals; nuisances prohibited. 
(a)  Any person who owns, keeps or harbors any animal located within the borough or permits an animal to enter the borough shall exercise sufficient and proper care and control over such animal at all times so as to prevent the animal from becoming a public nuisance or otherwise violating this article. 
(b)  Running at large; leashing. All owners shall be required to maintain control over their animals and shall not permit any animal to run at large at any time within the limits of the borough. No animal shall be permitted off the premises of the person owning, keeping or harboring the animal unless accompanied by a person who is capable of controlling it and who has the animal securely confined and controlled by an adequate leash or chain not more than six (6) feet long, or by an electronic collar. 
(c)  Soiling and defilement by animals. No person owning, keeping, harboring or walking any animal shall permit it to soil, defile, defecate or commit any nuisance on any common thoroughfare, street, sidewalk, passageway, road, bypass, play area, park or any place where people congregate or walk upon any public property whatsoever. This provision shall not apply to privately owned property of the owner or keeper of the animal and the property owned or controlled by persons who have invited or permitted the owner or keeper of animal to bring such animal upon the premises. If such person shall permit such an animal to soil, defile or defecate on or commit any nuisance on the areas aforesaid, the person shall immediately remove all feces and droppings deposited by such animal, which removal shall be in a sanitary manner by shovel, container, disposal bag, etc., and disposed of in a sanitary manner. 
(d)  Property damage. No person owning, keeping, harboring or walking an animal shall cause, suffer, permit or allow such animal to do any injury to or to do any damage to any lawn, shrubbery, flowers, grounds or property of persons in the borough other than the owner or person having the care, custody and control of such animal. 
(e)  Seizure and impoundment. 
(1)  The chief of police of the borough or such other duly authorized agent of the borough, as the board of commissioners may from time to time appoint, shall take into custody and impound or cause to take into custody and impound, and if not redeemed, thereafter destroy as hereinafter provided, any animal running at large within the borough. The chief of police or other duly authorized agent of the borough shall, upon the taking and impounding of any animal pursuant to this subsection, cause a notice, in writing, of such taking and impounding to be mailed to the owner of said animal, if such owner of said animal can be ascertained, stating that said animal will be destroyed unless claimed by said owner within seven (7) days from the mailing of said notice. Said animal shall be delivered to its owner upon payment of all fees that the borough may be charged by the duly authorized agent. If said animal is not claimed by the owner in the time period set forth herein, it may be disposed of or destroyed. 
(2)  The chief of police or other duly authorized agent of the borough may impound said animal so taken either within or without the limits of the borough, and the place to which said animal shall be taken when impounded shall be clearly set forth in the resolution of the board of commissioners authorizing the agent to take said animals, and said place of impounding shall not be changed without the consent of the board of commissioners of the borough. 
(f)  No person shall abandon any animal of any age or permit an animal to become a stray. 
(Ord. No. 929-07, art. V, 9-25-2007) 
Sec. 14-27. - Harboring stray or unlicensed animals. 
    No person shall harbor any non-owned, unlicensed or stray animal or make food or shelter available to the same following receipt of a notice from the secretary of the borough board of health: 
(1)  Advising said person that harboring in violation of this section is occurring; and 
(2)  Providing said person seven (7) days within which to cease and desist such harboring. 
(Ord. No. 929-07, art. VI, 9-25-2007) 
Sec. 14-28. - Vicious dogs and potentially dangerous dogs. 
(a)  Investigation; impoundment. It shall be the duty of the police department to receive and investigate complaints against dogs. However, it shall be the duty of an animal control officer to seize and impound a dog pursuant to N.J.S.A. 4:19-19 when the officer has reasonable cause to believe that the dog is a vicious dog pursuant to N.J.S.A. 4:19-22 or is a potentially dangerous dog, pursuant to N.J.S.A. 4:19-23. The dog shall be impounded until the final disposition as to whether the dog is vicious or potentially dangerous. Subject to the approval of the officer, the dog may be impounded in a facility or other structure agreeable to the owner. 
(b)  Pendency of appeal. No dog may be destroyed during the pendency of an appeal. 
(c)  A dog shall not be declared a vicious dog or potentially dangerous if said dog was provoked to cause bodily injury as defined in N.J.S.A § 2C:11-1(a) to a person, or severely injuring or killing a domestic animal if the domestic animal was the aggressor. 
(d)  A dog determined to be a potentially dangerous dog requires the owner of said dog to comply with registration of potentially dangerous dog and conditions as set forth in N.J.S.A § 4:19-24. 
(e)  A municipal court that determines that a dog is potentially dangerous may require an owner to maintain liability insurance for the dog in accordance with N.J.S.A § 4:19-15.2(3)(b). 
(Ord. No. 2016-05 , 3-15-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-05 , adopted March 15, 2016, amended § 14-28 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former § 14-28 pertained to vicious dogs and violent dogs and derived from Ord. No. 2015-08, art. I, adopted Oct. 6, 2015. 
State Law reference- Vicious dogs, N.J.S.A. 4-19-21.1 et seq. 
Secs. 14-29-14-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOARDING AND RAISING LIVESTOCK 

Sec. 14-60. - Boarding, keeping, raising livestock within borough prohibited. 
    It shall be prohibited within the borough to board, keep or raise livestock. For the purposes of this section, the term "livestock" means animals normally raised on a farm not including dogs and cats. Livestock shall include, but shall not be limited to horses, goats, sheep, pigs, cows, steers and donkeys. Because certain livestock shall be maintained domestically, livestock shall not include chickens and ducks in this section. 
(Ord. No. 752-97, § 1, 7-1-1997) 
Sec. 14-61. - Enforcement. 
    The zoning officer of the borough shall be authorized to enforce this article. In the event that the zoning officer of the borough has probable cause to believe that any person or corporation or business entity shall maintain, raise or board livestock as defined in this article, the said zoning officer shall first issue a letter to the offending party or parties. The letter shall include a warning notice, warning the person or persons involved that the said boarding, keeping or raising of livestock is in violation of this Code and said parties shall have thirty (30) days to remove livestock from within the municipal boundaries of the borough or a summons will be issued in violation of same. 
(Ord. No. 752-97, § 2, 7-1-1997) 
Sec. 14-62. - Violations; hearings; penalties. 
(a)  In the event that the said zoning officer has issued a warning letter, and thirty (30) days has expired, and the removal of the livestock as defined in this article has not taken place, then and in that event, the zoning officer shall cause to file a summons and complaint with the municipal court of the borough. The municipal court of the borough has jurisdiction to hear and adjudicate on any alleged violation of this article. The municipal judge, at the time set for said hearing, shall inquire into the facts and give all interested parties an opportunity to be heard under oath and to be represented by counsel. 
(b)  In the event that the municipal court judge of the borough determines that a violation of this article exists, then the court shall imposed a fine up to two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) in the discretion of the municipal court judge for a first offense; in the event of a second offense, then the municipal court judge shall have the authority to issue a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) in the discretion of the municipal court judge. In the event of a third or any subsequent offense, then the municipal court judge shall have the authority to enter a fine of up to one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) in the discretion of the municipal court judge. 
(Ord. No. 752-97, § 4, 7-1-1997) 
State Law reference- Penalty for ordinance violations, N.J.S.A. 40:49-5. 
Sec. 14-63. - Restrictions on the sale of animals. 
(a)  A pet shop may offer for sale only those dogs and cats that the pet shop has obtained from or displays in cooperation with: 
(1)  An animal care facility; or 
(2)  An animal rescue organization. 
(b)  A pet shop shall not offer for sale a dog or cat that is younger than eight (8) weeks old. 
(Ord. No. 2015-09, § 2, 10-20-2015) 
Chapter 18 - EMERGENCY SERVICES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 18-1-18-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ALARM SYSTEMS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Alarm businesses, N.J.S.A. 45:5A-23 et seq. 

Sec. 18-19. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm system means any mechanical, electrical or electronic device which is designed or used for the detection of an unauthorized entry into a building, structure, or facility, or for alerting others about the commission of an unlawful act in a building, structure or facility or for alerting others about the existence of any other condition requiring response of police, fire, or ambulance personnel. 
    False alarm means the activation of an alarm where an emergency does not exist, or an alarm activated by inadvertence, negligence or an unintentional or intentional act of someone other than an intruder, and shall include alarms caused by malfunctioning of the alarm, device alarm system or its related equipment. The term "false alarm" shall not include alarms created by malfunctioning of the police department alarm console or other police department equipment, or activations caused by public utility interruptions where such interruptions have been reported to the police or activations caused by natural disaster or activations caused by testing or repair of any alarm system or device. 
    Fire or ambulance personnel means any one (1) or more units of the borough volunteer fire companies and/or borough volunteer ambulance corps. 
    Police means the borough police department. 
(Ord. No. 885-05, § 2, 5-24-2005) 
Sec. 18-20. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish regulations concerning the operation and maintenance of certain alarm systems within the borough, and to provide penalties upon conviction for violations of any of the provisions set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 885-05, § 1, 5-24-2005) 
Sec. 18-21. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to the general alerting alarms that may be used by fire companies, ambulance squads, or civil defense agencies to summon response of their members. The provisions of this article further shall not apply to the alarm systems that are affixed to motor vehicles such as police, ambulance, and/or fire vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 885-05, § 5, 5-24-2005) 
Sec. 18-22. - General regulations. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of all persons, entities, firms, corporations or other groups that maintain alarm systems within the borough, to provide current information to the police, consisting of the names and telephone numbers of responsible persons who may be contacted in case of emergency, or who are authorized to provide services to the alarm systems. This information is to be filed with the borough police department when the alarm system is initially placed into service, and must be revised immediately whenever changes are necessary. 
(b)  It shall be a violation of this article for each occasion when the police, fire or ambulance are required to respond to a false alarm as defined herein. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of all persons, entities, firms, corporations, or other groups that maintain alarm systems within the borough to prevent the transmission of false alarms through a program of training, and periodic inspection and maintenance of their respective alarm systems. 
(Ord. No. 885-05, § 3, 5-24-2005) 
Sec. 18-23. - False alarms; penalties. 
    For any false alarm, the following penalties shall be applied: 
(1)  For the first and second false alarm in any given calendar year, a warning shall be issued by the borough through a letter to the owner of the premises on which the false alarm was sounded. 
(2)  For the third false alarm in the same calendar year, a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be paid to the borough. 
(3)  For the fourth and fifth false alarm in the same calendar year, a fine of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) shall be paid to the borough. 
(4)  Any person, entity, firm, corporation or other group that is found guilty of violating any of the other provisions of this article or guilty of a sixth or more false alarms in the same calendar year shall be subject to a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). This article shall be enforceable in the municipal court of the borough. 
(Ord. No. 885-05, § 4, 5-24-2005) 
Chapter 22 - ENVIRONMENT AND NATURAL RESOURCES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 22-1-22-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STORMWATER DISCHARGES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 22-19-22-39. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ILLICIT CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 22-40. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. The definitions below are the same as or based on corresponding definitions in the New Jersey Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NJPDES) rules at N.J.A.C. 7:14A-1.2. 
    Domestic sewage means waste and wastewater from humans or household operations. 
    Illicit connection means any physical or non-physical connection that discharges domestic sewage, non-contact cooling water, process wastewater, or other industrial waste (other than stormwater) to the municipal separate storm sewer system unless that discharge is authorized under a NJPDES permit other than the Tier A Municipal Stormwater General Permit (NJPDES Permit Number NJ0141852). Non-physical connections may include, but are not limited to, leaks, flows, or overflows into the municipal separate storm sewer system. 
    Industrial waste means non-domestic waste, including, but not limited to, those pollutants regulated under section 307(a), (b), or (c) of the Federal Clean Water Act (33 USC 1317(a), (b), or (c)). 
    Municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) means a conveyance or system of conveyances (including roads with drainage systems, municipal streets, catch basins, curbs, gutters, ditches, manmade channels, or storm drains) that is owned or operated by the borough or other public body, and is designed and used for collecting and conveying stormwater. 
    NJPDES permit means a permit issued by the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection to implement the New Jersey Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NJPDES) rules at N.J.A.C. 7:14A 
    Non-contact cooling water means water used to reduce temperature for the purpose of cooling. Such waters do not come into direct contact with any raw material, intermediate product (other than heat) or finished product. Non-contact cooling water may, however, contain algaecides, or biocides to control fouling of equipment such as heat exchangers, and/or corrosion inhibitors. 
    Process wastewater means any water which, during manufacturing or processing, comes into direct contact with or results from the production or use of any raw material, intermediate product, finished product, byproduct, or waste product. The term "process wastewater" includes, but is not limited to, leachate and cooling water other than non-contact cooling water. 
    Stormwater means water resulting from precipitation (including rain and snow) that runs off the land's surface, is transmitted to the subsurface, is captured by separate storm sewers or other sewerage or drainage facilities, or is conveyed by snow removal equipment. 
(Ord. No. 875-04, § II, 12-28-2004) 
Sec. 22-41. - Penalties. 
    Any person who is found to be in violation of the provisions of this division shall be subject to a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 875-04, § V, 12-28-2004) 
State Law reference- Penalty for ordinance violations, N.J.S.A. 40:49-5. 
Sec. 22-42. - Enforcement. 
    This division shall be enforced by the borough police department, construction official and/or zoning enforcement of the borough. 
(Ord. No. 875-04, § IV, 12-28-2004) 
Sec. 22-43. - Prohibited conduct. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged through an illicit connection to the municipal separate storm sewer system operated by the borough, any domestic sewage, non-contact cooling water, process wastewater, or other industrial waste (other than stormwater). 
(Ord. No. 875-04, § III, 12-28-2004) 
Secs. 22-44-22-74. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DISCHARGE RESTRICTIONS 

Sec. 22-75. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) means a conveyance or system of conveyances (including roads with drainage systems, municipal streets, catch basins, curbs, gutters, ditches, manmade channels, or storm drains) that is owned or operated by the borough or other public body, and is designed and used for collecting and conveying stormwater. 
    Stormwater means water resulting from precipitation (including rain and snow) that runs off the land's surface, is transmitted to the subsurface, is captured by separate storm sewers or other sewerage or drainage facilities, or is conveyed by snow removal equipment. 
(Ord. No. 871-04, § II, 12-28-2004) 
Sec. 22-76. - Enforcement. 
    This division shall be enforced by the borough police department and/or zoning enforcement of the borough. 
(Ord. No. 871-04, § V, 12-28-2004) 
Sec. 22-77. - Penalties. 
    Any person who continues to be in violation of the provisions of this article, after being duly notified, shall be subject to a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 871-04, § VI, 12-28-2004) 
State Law reference- Penalty for ordinance violations, N.J.S.A. 40:49-5. 
Sec. 22-78. - Prohibited conduct. 
    The spilling, dumping, or disposal of materials other than stormwater to the municipal separate storm sewer system operated by the borough is prohibited. The spilling, dumping, or disposal of materials other than stormwater in such a manner as to cause the discharge of pollutants to the municipal separate storm sewer system is also prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 871-04, § III, 12-28-2004) 
Sec. 22-79. - Exceptions to prohibition. 
    The following shall be exceptions to the prohibited conduct described in section 22-78: 
(1)  Water line flushing and discharges from potable water sources. 
(2)  Uncontaminated ground water (e.g., infiltration, crawl space or basement sump pumps, foundation or footing drains, rising ground waters). 
(3)  Air conditioning condensate (excluding contact and non-contact cooling water). 
(4)  Irrigation water (including landscape and lawn watering runoff). 
(5)  Flows from springs, riparian habitats and wetlands, water reservoir discharges and diverted stream flows. 
(6)  Residential car washing water and residential swimming pool discharges. 
(7)  Sidewalk, driveway and street wash water. 
(8)  Flows from firefighting activities. 
(9)  Flows from rinsing of the following equipment with clean water: Equipment used in the application of salt and de-icing materials immediately following salt and de-icing material applications. Prior to rinsing with clean water, all residual salt and de-icing materials must be removed from equipment and vehicles to the maximum extent practicable using dry cleaning methods (e.g., shoveling and sweeping). Recovered materials are to be returned to storage for reuse or properly discarded. Rinsing of equipment, as noted in the above situation, is limited to exterior, undercarriage, and exposed parts and does not apply to engines or other enclosed machinery. 
(Ord. No. 871-04, § IV, 12-28-2004) 
Secs. 22-80-22-101. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PRIVATE STORM DRAIN INLET RETROFITTING 

Sec. 22-102. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) means a conveyance or system or conveyances (including roads with drainage systems, municipal streets, catch basins, curbs, gutters, ditches, manmade channels, or storm drains) that is owned or operated by the borough or other public body and is designed and used for collecting and conveying stormwater. 
    Storm drain inlet means an opening in a storm drain used to collect stormwater runoff and includes, but is not limited to, a grate inlet, curb-opening inlet, slotted inlet, and combination inlet. 
    Waters of the state means the ocean and its estuaries, all springs, streams and bodies of surface or ground water, whether natural or artificial, within the boundaries of the state or subject to its jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 954-09, § II, 5-18-2009) 
Sec. 22-103. - Penalty. 
    Any person who is found to be in violation of the provisions of this division shall be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each storm drain inlet that is not retrofitted to meet the design standard. 
(Ord. No. 954-09, § VI, 5-18-2009) 
State Law reference- Penalty for ordinance violations, N.J.S.A. 40:49-5. 
Sec. 22-104. - Enforcement. 
    This division shall be enforced by the borough police department and the zoning officials of the borough. 
(Ord. No. 954-09, § V, 5-18-2009) 
Sec. 22-105. - Prohibited conduct. 
    No person in control of private property (except a residential lot with one (1) single-family house) shall authorize the repaving, repairing (excluding the repair of individual potholes), resurfacing (including top coating or chip sealing with asphalt emulsion or a thin base of hot bitumen), reconstructing or altering any surface that is in direct contact with an existing storm drain inlet on that property unless the storm drain inlet either: 
(1)  Already meets the design standard below to control passage of solid and floatable materials; or 
(2)  Is retrofitted or replaced to meet the standard in section 22-106 prior to the completion of the project. 
(Ord. No. 954-09, § III, 5-18-2009) 
Sec. 22-106. - Design standard. 
    Storm drain inlets identified in section 22-105 shall comply with the following standard to control passage of solid and floatable materials through storm drain inlets. For purposes of this section, "solid and floatable materials" means sediment, debris, trash, and other floating, suspended, or settleable solids. For exemptions to this standard, see subsection (3) of this section. 
(1)  Design engineers shall use either of the following grates whenever they use a grate in pavement or another ground surface to collect stormwater from that surface into a storm drain or surface water body under that grate: 
a.  The New Jersey Department of Transportation (NJDOT) bicycle safe grate, which is described in Chapter 2.4 of the NJDOT Bicycle Compatible Roadways and Bikeways Planning and Design Guidelines (April 1996); or 
b.  A different grate, if each individual clear space in that grate has an area of no more than seven (7) square inches, or is no greater than one-half (1/2) inch across the smallest dimension. Examples of grates subject to this standard include grates in grate inlets, the grate portion (non-curb-opening portion) or combination inlets, grates on storm sewer manholes, ditch grates, trench grates, and grates of spacer bars in slotted drains. 
Examples of ground surfaces include surfaces of roads (including bridges), driveways, parking areas, bikeways, plazas, sidewalks, lawns, fields, open channels, and stormwater basin floors. 
(2)  Whenever design engineers use a curb-opening inlet, the clear space in that curb opening (or each individual clear space, if the curb opening has two (2) or more clear spaces) shall have an area of no more than seven (7) square inches, or be no greater than two (2) inches across the smallest dimension. 
(3)  This standard does not apply: 
a.  Where the municipal engineer agrees that this standard would cause inadequate hydraulic performance that could not practicably be overcome by using additional or larger storm drain inlets that meet these standards; 
b.  Where flows are conveyed through any device (e.g., end of pipe netting facility, manufactured treatment device, or a catch basin hood) that is designed at a minimum, to prevent delivery of all solid and floatable materials that could not pass through one (1) of the following: 
1.  A rectangular space four and five-eighths (4 5/8 ) inches long and one and one-half (11/2) inches wide (this option does not apply for outfall netting facilities); or 
2.  A bar screen having a bar spacing of one-half (1/2) inch; 
c.  Where flows are conveyed through a trash rack that has parallel bars with one-inch spacing between the bars; or 
d.  Where the state department of environmental protection determines pursuant to the state register of historic places rules at N.J.A.C. 7:4-7.2(c), that action to meet this standard is an undertaking that constitutes an encroachment or will damage or destroy the state register-listed historic property. 
(Ord. No. 954-09, § IV, 5-18-2009) 
Chapter 26 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Uniform Fire Safety Act, N.J.S.A. 52:27D-192 et seq.; fire prevention ordinances authorized, N.J.S.A. 40:48-2.28; general authority relative to fire prevention and explosives, N.J.S.A. 40:48-1(14), (16)-(19), (24)). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Key boxes. 
(a)  Where access to or within a structure or an area is restricted because of secured openings or where immediate access is necessary for life-saving or firefighting purposes, the fire code official is authorized to require a key box to be installed in an approved location. The key box shall be of an approved type and shall contain keys to gain necessary access as required by the fire code official. The key box shall contain: 
(1)  Keys to locked points of ingress whether on the interior or exterior of such buildings. 
(2)  Keys to locked mechanical equipment rooms. 
(3)  Keys to locked electrical rooms. 
(4)  Keys to elevator controls. 
(5)  Keys to other areas as directed by the fire marshal. 
(6)  If applicable, a code to provide entry to the premises. 
(7)  Other material as directed by the fire marshal. 
(b)  An approved lock shall be installed on gates or similar barriers when required by the fire code official. 
(c)  This section applies to the owner or person in control of the following types of buildings: 
(1)  Any apartment building or other rental building containing four (4) or more residential living units and in which access to the building or to common areas or mechanical or electrical rooms within the building is denied through locked doors. 
(2)  Any non-residential building where a fire detection or suppression system is monitored by an alarm company or has an external audible alarm. 
(3)  Any building or facility containing a quantity of hazardous materials which would require compliance with Title III of Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act (SARA). 
(d)  The operator of the building shall immediately notify the fire code official and provide the new key when a lock is changed or rekeyed. The key to such lock shall be secured in the key box. 
(e)  The owners of buildings requiring lockboxes shall have the required device, with proper operating keys installed, within one (1) year of the adoption of the ordinance from which this section is derived. 
(f)  The owner of any property equipped with an alarm system (defined as any system which reports a fire, burglar, and/or carbon monoxide level to a monitoring central station or reports by its own dialer directly to the police/fire departments) shall install a security box containing a key or keys or any codes which allow full access to the property in the event of an activated alarm. 
(g)  The term "security box" shall be defined, for purposes of this section, as a secured, locked device that is located on the exterior of the premises at or near the main entrance which can be accessed by the borough police or fire department in the event that an alarm is activated and it is or becomes necessary to gain access to the premises to adequately determine the cause of the activation of the alarm. The security box shall be of a type that is commonly known as a "Knox Box," hinged and from the 3200 series. 
(h)  The precise location of the security box shall be subject to the approval of the chief of the borough fire department. The key box shall be installed, at or near the recognized public entrance, adjacent to the fire alarm panel, on the exterior of the structure or in a location or locations designated and approved by the local fire official in consultation with the local fire chief. The box shall be located at a height approved by the local fire official of not less than four (4) feet and not more than six (6) feet above final grade. The key box is not required to be attached to or monitored by the alarm system; however, this action is recommended. 
(i)  The requirements of this section shall be immediately effective for all new construction and new alarm system installations, but for existing systems, the effective date is June 15, 2010. 
(j)  The borough construction code official may determine appropriate fees for processing an application to determine whether a key box which does not comply with the specifications can be approved for installation and a request for designation or approval of proposed locations for key boxes. Such fees shall become effective upon adoption by resolution of the board of commissioners. 
(k)  The borough construction code official shall be the enforcing agency of this section. Any person who owns or operates a structure subject to this section shall be subject to penalties set in this Code for any violation of this section, and the minimum fine for a conviction or a violation of this section shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense, two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the second offense, and three hundred dollars ($300.00) for each subsequent offense. 
(Ord. No. 971-2010, § 2, 6-15-2010) 
State Law reference- Penalty for ordinance violations, N.J.S.A. 40:49-5. 
Sec. 26-2. - [Obstruction of access to fire hydrants prohibited.] 
(a)  Obstruction. Unobstructed access to fire hydrants shall be maintained at all times. Growth, trash, leaves, storage and other debris, materials or objects shall not be placed or kept near fire hydrants, fire department inlet connections or fire protection system control valves in a manner that would prevent such equipment or fire hydrant from being immediately discernible. The fire department shall not be deterred or hindered from gaining immediate access to fire protection equipment. 
(b)  Removal. The fire chief and police chief and their designated representatives are authorized to remove or cause to be removed any trash, debris, material or object obstructing a fire hydrant, fire department inlet connection or fire protection system control valves at the expense of the owner of such trash, debris, material or object. 
(Ord. No. 2013-07, §§ 1, 2, 10-15-2013) 
Secs. 26-3-26-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STATE UNIFORM FIRE CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Uniform Fire Safety Act, N.J.S.A. 52:27D-192 et seq. 

Sec. 26-21. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Generally. Pursuant to N.J.S.A. 52:27D-202, the New Jersey Uniform Fire Code (N.J.A.C. 5:70-1 et seq.) shall be locally enforced in the borough. 
(b)  Agency designation. The local enforcing agency shall be the office of the borough fire marshal in the bureau of fire prevention of the borough. The borough fire marshal's office shall hereinafter be known as the "local enforcing agency." 
(c)  Duties. 
(1)  The local enforcing agency shall enforce the Uniform Fire Code in all buildings, structures, and premises within the established boundaries of the borough other than one- and two-unit owner-occupied dwellings used exclusively for dwelling purposes and buildings, structures and premises owned or operated by the federal government, interstate agencies or the state. 
(2)  The local enforcing agency shall faithfully comply with all pertinent requirements of the Uniform Fire Safety Act (N.J.A.C. 5:70-1 et seq.) and the Uniform Fire Code. 
(d)  Organization; appointments. The local enforcing agency shall be under the direct supervision of the fire official of the borough. He or she shall provide monthly or annual reports, as requested, to the chief of the fire department, borough administrator and to the director of public safety of the borough. The fire official and other employees of the local enforcing agency shall be appointed and removed in accordance with the personnel laws, regulations, ordinances, resolutions, policies, and procedures governing borough employees. 
(Ord. No. 2011:04, §§ 1-4, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-22. - Life hazard uses. 
    The local enforcing agency established by section 26-21(b) shall carry out the periodic inspections of life hazard uses required by the Uniform Fire Code on behalf of the commissioner of the state department of community affairs. 
(Ord. No. 2011:04, § 5, 4-5-2011)
