    Non-profit-making vendor means a person who sells goods, the proceeds of which are devoted exclusively to the purposes of a philanthropic, charitable or religious society, on whose behalf he/she acts as an agent without pay. 
    Peddler means a person, commonly referred to either as a "peddler" or "hawker," who goes from place to place by traveling on the streets or from house to house and carries with him/her goods, wares and merchandise for the purpose of selling and delivering them to consumers. 
    Person means an individual, firm, partnership, corporation, voluntary association, incorporated association and principal or agent thereof. 
    Solicitor means a person selling goods by sample or taking orders for future delivery, with or without accepting an advance payment for the goods, and not a taxpayer or representative thereof in the borough. 
    Transient merchant means a person, commonly referred to either as a "transient merchant" or "itinerant vendor," who engages in merchandising business in this municipality with the intent to close out or discontinue such business within a period of one (1) year from the date of commencement and occupies a room, building, tent, lot or other premises for the purpose of selling goods, wares and merchandise. 
    Transient merchant peddler means a person who engages in business in the manner defined by "transient merchant" and, in pursuance thereof, becomes a peddler or hires a peddler, as defined by "peddler" above. 
(b)  The above definitions, except for "person," shall constitute a license classification, a separate license being issued for each class under the terms hereinafter set forth. 
(Code 1992, § 246-1; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 34-298. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person required by this chapter to procure a license who violates its terms or fails to comply with the N.J.S.A. title 45, ch. 24 (N.J.S.A. 45:24-1 et seq.) shall be subject to a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), imprisonment for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days or a period of community service not exceeding ninety (90) days or any combination thereof. 
(Code 1992, § 246-12; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 34-299. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to prevent unfair competition and dishonest business practices by the regulation of the conduct of non-profit-making vendors and new merchants specified in section 34-297, and by the imposition of license fees for revenue upon peddlers, transient merchants, transient merchant peddlers and solicitors. Licenses shall be issued, without payment of fees, to non-profit-making vendors and new merchants. 
(Code 1992, § 246-2; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 34-300. - Hours of business. 
    All peddlers, transient merchants, transient merchant peddlers and solicitors shall confine their activities to Monday through Saturday between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. eastern standard time. Any activity conducted on Sunday or outside the required hours is a violation of this article and each day of violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1992, § 246-1; Ord. No. 471, 4-3-1980; Ord. No. 2018-13, Art. I, 11-20-2018) 
Sec. 34-301. - Required records and reports. 
(a)  All licenses shall be issued on forms drawn in accordance with this article. They shall be printed in book form, with corresponding stubs, and shall be consecutively numbered. The license shall contain suitable blank spaces for writing in the name, the class of license granted, the location of the business and the amount of fee paid. 
(b)  There shall be kept in the office of the borough clerk the necessary books for recording the time the application for license is received, showing its class, whether new or renewal, the name of the licensee, the regular number of the blank form, when the application was approved by the chief of police and the borough clerk, the amount of fee received therefor and the date when the license was issued. 
(c)  The borough clerk shall monthly file a report with the board of commissioners showing the number of licenses granted, by classes, and the amounts of fees received therefor. Each report shall state the number and class of licenses suspended or revoked and the reasons for such suspension or revocation. The monthly report shall be cumulative during the course of the year, so that each report summarizes the action of all preceding months of the current year. 
(Code 1992, § 246-8; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Secs. 34-302-34-320. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 34-321. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler, transient merchant, transient merchant peddler, solicitor, non-profit-making vendor and new merchant to sell or dispose of or to offer to sell or dispose of any goods, wares or merchandise within the municipality without first obtaining a license and having paid the license fee hereinafter prescribed for peddlers, transient merchants, transient merchant peddlers and solicitors. 
(Code 1992, § 246-3; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 34-322. - License applications. 
    Any person desiring a license shall file with the borough clerk an application blank, separate blanks being provided for each of the six (6) classes of licenses. The blanks shall contain the following information: 
(1)  All licenses. 
a.  For all license classes: 
1.  The name of the applicant. 
2.  His/her permanent home residence. 
3.  The name and address of the firm represented, and the names and addresses of the persons from whom goods making up the stock were or are to be purchased. 
4.  Three (3) business references. 
5.  The place or places of residence of the applicant for the preceding three (3) years. 
6.  The length of time for which the license is desired. 
7.  A description of the wares to be offered for sale. 
8.  The number either of arrests or convictions for misdemeanors or crimes and the nature of the offenses for which arrested or convicted. 
b.  To the application for all license classes must be appended a letter from the firm for which he/she purports to work authorizing the applicant to act as its representative. 
(2)  For transient merchant licenses. 
a.  In addition to the foregoing items, the application shall show: 
1.  A sworn statement of the true invoice of the amount, average, quality or kind and value of the goods to be offered for sale. 
2.  A statement of the location of such goods, by street or number, and whether on the premises from which they are sold or in warehouse. 
b.  To the application must be appended, in the discretion of the borough clerk, the bills or invoices of purchase for such goods. 
(3)  For transient merchant peddler licenses. In addition to the foregoing information, the application must show: 
a.  The names and addresses of each peddler acting for said merchant. 
b.  One (1) personal reference for each peddler. 
c.  For each peddler, the number either of arrests or convictions for misdemeanors or crimes and the nature of the offenses for which arrested or convicted. 
(Code 1992, § 246-5; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 34-323. - Establishing character of business; bond. 
(a)  For the three (3) classes of licenses of stationary vendors (viz., transient merchants, transient merchant peddlers and new merchants), the issuing officer is directed to establish the character of the business by: 
(1)  Eliciting a declaration of intention of all new businessmen as to whether they intend to remain within the municipality temporarily or longer than a period of one (1) year; and 
(2)  Requiring a filing of a bond in an amount equal to twenty-five percent (25%) of the value of the applicant's stock, and in no event shall the bond be less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) in amount, provided that new merchants shall not be required to file a bond in an amount in excess of ten percent (10%) of the value of the applicant's stock. 
(b)  The bond shall be declared forfeited upon conclusive proof of: 
(1)  Falsification in application for a license; 
(2)  Willful violation of an ordinance, state or federal law; or 
(3)  Removal from the municipality within a year after opening the business premises without payment of the license fee or fees required of transient merchants or merchant peddlers. 
(c)  The bond of every merchant continuously conducting a vending business for more than one (1) year shall be surrendered, and no further license shall be required of him/her under this chapter. 
(Code 1992, § 246-6; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 34-324. - Processing of application; license issuance. 
(a)  Following the filing of the application, the chief of police shall verify the information given by the applicant and shall signify his/her approval of the application. Upon verification of the application and payment of the prescribed fee, the license therefor shall be issued by the borough clerk. 
(b)  For all license classes, the license issued shall not authorize any person except the designated person named in said license to engage in business thereunder. Said license shall not be transferable from the person to whom issued to any other person. A separate license must be obtained by a licensed peddler for every agent or employee working for him. A separate license must be obtained by a licensed transient merchant for each branch or separate place of business in which his/her business is conducted, and each license shall authorize the person to conduct business only at the location which is indicated therein. 
(Code 1992, § 246-7; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 2018-13, Art. II, 11-20-2018) 
Sec. 34-325. - License fees. 
    License fees shall be as follows: 
(1)  Peddlers. One dollar ($1.00) per day for a daily license; two dollars ($2.00) per month for a monthly license; ten dollars ($10.00) per year for an annual license. Each daily license shall be issued stating the date on which it is to be used; each monthly license shall be issued stating the month in which it is to be used; each annual license shall terminate at the close of December 31 of the year in which it is issued; provided, however, that any license issued after May 1 of any calendar year shall be issued for a fee of six dollars ($6.00) for the remainder of the calendar year. 
(2)  Transient merchants. Twenty-five dollars ($25.00), which shall continue in favor of the person to whom it is issued for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days from the date the same is issued. 
(3)  Transient merchant peddlers. The amount prescribed by subsection (2) of this section and, in addition thereto, the amount prescribed by subsection (1) of this section for each peddler in his/her employment. The license shall continue in effect for one hundred eighty (180) days. 
(4)  Solicitors. 
Daily ..... $50.00 
Weekly ..... 100.00 
Seasonal (three (3) months) ..... 200.00 
(Code 1992, § 246-10; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 515, 4-8-1983; Ord. No. 2018-13, Art. III, 11-20-2018) 
Sec. 34-326. - Exceptions from license fees. 
    The following persons shall be exempt from paying any license fee under the terms of this chapter: 
(1)  Any person honorably discharged from the military, naval or marine forces of the United States. 
(2)  Any blind person who is a resident of this municipality. 
(3)  Any person who conducts a sale pursuant to the statutes of this state or pursuant to an order of the court. 
(4)  Any person exempt from the provisions of this chapter by the statutes of the State of New Jersey. 
(Code 1992, § 246-4; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 34-327. - Display of license; badge. 
(a)  Every person holding a license under this chapter shall be required to carry the license with him/her or at his/her business premises while engaged in the business licensed. He/she must produce the license at the request of any official of the borough. 
(b)  To every peddler granted a license, the borough clerk shall issue a badge bearing the words "Licensed Peddler, Municipality of Audubon," together with the number of the license and the year for which it is issued. All automobiles, wagons, carts or other vehicles used for peddling shall have affixed thereon said badge. A transient merchant, a transient merchant peddler and a new merchant must post a license certificate in a prominent place of his/her business premises. To the vendors of all other classes shall be issued a license button, which must be affixed on the lapel of his or her coat or garment while engaged in business. 
(Code 1992, § 246-9; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 34-328. - Suspension or revocation of license. 
    A license may be revoked by the board of commissioners by reason of the violation of the terms of the license, the violation of any municipal ordinance or state or federal statute or falsification in applying for a license. The licensed person must be granted a hearing by the council upon his/her request. A license may be suspended for not more than two (2) weeks by the issuing officer without a hearing. 
(Code 1992, § 246-11; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 34-329. - Establishment, display and distribution of a "Do Not Knock Registry." 
(a)  The municipal clerk's office shall prepare a list of addresses of those premises where the owner and/or occupant has notified the clerk's office that peddling, soliciting, canvassing, hawking and door-to-door sales enterprising as set forth in this chapter are not permitted on the premises (hereinafter referred to as the "Do Not Knock Registry"). Notification shall be by completion of a form available at the clerk's office during normal business hours. 
(b)  Any owner and/or occupant who has requested enlistment on the Do Not Knock Registry, pursuant to this chapter herein, shall be able to obtain from the clerk's office a sticker for display at his/her/its premises indicating enlistment on the Do Not Knock Registry. 
(c)  Owners and/or occupants who are placed on the Do Not Knock Registry at their request, shall remain on the Do Not Knock Registry until such time as they advise the clerk's office in writing that they wish to be removed from the list. 
(d)  The clerk's office shall distribute the current Do Not Knock Registry to a licensee under this chapter at the time of issuance of a license to peddle, solicit, canvas, hawk or otherwise door-to-door sell pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. The Do Not Knock Registry provided to licensees shall only include the physical address of the enlisted premises. The licensee shall not peddle, solicit, canvas, hawk or conduct door-to-door sales at any premises identified on the then current Do Not Knock Registry. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, Art. IV, 11-20-2018) 
Secs. 34-330-34-359. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - MOTOR VEHICLE SERVICE STATIONS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Filling and service stations, N.J.S.A. 34:3A-4 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 34-360. - General regulations. 
    Any person, persons, partnership or corporation owning and/or operating a motor vehicle service station or gasoline or oil filling station in the borough shall comply with the following regulations: 
(1)  No repair work on vehicles shall be done in the open on the premises except the following: 
a.  The repair of tires and tubes. 
b.  The recharging and rental of batteries. 
c.  Such incidental work as may be necessary in connection with the installation, mounting or adjustment of accessories herein permitted to be sold or in connection with the testing and adjustment of the fuel and electrical systems of motor vehicles. 
(2)  No parking of commercial vehicles shall be permitted on the premises except such temporary parking as may be necessary in connection with the servicing of such vehicles. No outdoor parking of any of the above-mentioned vehicles shall be permitted on the premises between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., except such vehicles as are required to remain on the premises for further servicing or repair, and at no time shall they be parked longer than seventy-two (72) hours. 
(3)  No auto bodywork, welding or outdoor major repair work shall be permitted on the premises. 
(4)  Any major repair of motor vehicles shall be performed in a fully enclosed building. No parts or partially dismantled or disabled motor vehicle may be stored out of doors. No motor vehicle shall be sold or displayed for sale on the premises unless the owner and/or operator of the premises holds a license permitting the display and sale of motor vehicles pursuant to the provisions of the state statutes. 
(5)  No junked motor vehicles or parts thereof and no unregistered, unlicensed motor vehicle shall be stored on the premises of any service station. Not more than eight (8) motor vehicles may be located on the premises outside a building for a period not to exceed five (5) days, provided that the owners are awaiting the repair of said motor vehicles. All vehicles stored overnight on the premises shall be screened from public and residential view. No motor vehicles may be parked on a public street awaiting repair or awaiting pickup by respective owners. 
(6)  Floor drains shall not be connected to the sanitary sewer system. A separate grease separation unit shall be installed. 
(7)  Signs and other advertising devices. 
a.  The display of signs shall be in accordance with the development ordinance. 
b.  The use of all flags, windmills, banners and any flashing or animated signs shall be prohibited. However, the use of pennants may be utilized for the purpose of advertising the opening of a new station, but shall be restricted to a ten-day period. 
c.  Accessory goods for sale may be displayed on the pump islands and the building island only. The outside storage of oil cans and/or antifreeze and other similar products may be displayed on the respective islands if provided for in a suitable metal stand or rack. 
d.  The display of new and used tires shall be restricted to metal cabinets designed specifically for that purpose and located at the property line but excluding the street property lines. Single tires may be displayed on the pump islands and building islands only and shall be prohibited from the vehicle circulation area. 
e.  All signs or parts thereof and the structures supporting the same or parts thereof shall be within the owner's property line and shall at no time project into or over the public right-of-way. 
f.  All outdoor vending machines are prohibited, exclusive of soft drink, ice and newspaper vending machines which are accessory uses to a gasoline service station, provided that they are located no farther than twenty (20) feet from the principal building. 
g.  All exterior lighting serving any automobile service facility shall be reflected away from the streets and adjacent property lines. 
(8)  The entire area of the station or garage or sales area traversed by motor vehicles shall be macadam or concrete. 
(9)  Hours of operation for motor repairs. 
a.  The operating hours for all motor vehicle service stations or gasoline or oil filling stations for repair work shall be as follows: 
1.  Monday through Saturday, 6:00 a.m. prevailing time to 11:00 p.m. prevailing time. 
2.  Sunday, 6:00 a.m. prevailing time to 6:00 p.m. prevailing time. 
b.  No work at all shall be permitted inside or outside a motor vehicle service station, gasoline or oil filling station after the closing hours. 
(Code 1992, § 262-5; Ord. No. 453, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 34-361. - Empty gas storage tanks. 
(a)  Gas storage tanks which are empty for over thirty (30) days shall be inserted with water and sealed. 
(b)  Gas storage tanks which are empty for over six (6) months shall be inserted with sand and sealed. 
(c)  Gas storage tanks which are empty for over one (1) year shall be removed from the premises on which they are located. 
(Code 1992, § 262-6; Ord. No. 453, 4-10-1979) 
Secs. 34-362-34-380. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 34-381. - Permit required. 
    No building or premises shall be used, and no buildings shall be erected which are arranged, intended or designed to be used, as a motor vehicle service station or as a gasoline or oil filling station and no premises which is now used as a service or gas station may be extended unless a permit is first obtained from the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1992, § 262-1; Ord. No. 453, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 34-382. - Permit application. 
    Any person, persons, partnership or corporation desiring to use any premises or to construct and erect any building arranged, intended or designed to be used as a motor vehicle service station or as a gasoline or oil filling station shall make application, in writing, to the board of commissioners, setting forth in said application the character of the building intended to be constructed on the premises to be used and a plot plan showing the location of the building on the premises to be used, street entrances and the dimensions of the same, the width of the street upon which the building fronts and the location and kind of structure of all buildings within two hundred (200) feet of the property intended to be used. The application will also be submitted to the borough planning board who would review the same and make recommendations to the board of commissioners. The review by the planning board and the board of commissioners under this article is in addition to any review under the borough development ordinance. This division does not supersede said development ordinance. 
(Code 1992, § 262-2; Ord. No. 453, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 34-383. - Public hearing; notice. 
    After the filing of an application, the board of commissioners shall fix a time and place, not exceeding sixty (60) days from the date of filing of said application, at which the board of commissioners shall hold a public hearing on said application, and the applicant shall receive due notice thereof. Said applicant shall, at least five (5) days prior to the time appointed for said hearing, give personal notice of said hearing to all property owners within two hundred (200) feet of the property upon which the building is intended to be located. Such notice shall be given either by handing a copy thereof to said property owners or by leaving a copy thereof at their usual place of abode, if said owners are the occupants of the property affected by said application or are residents of the borough. Whenever said owners are nonresidents of the borough, such notice may be given by sending written notice thereof by registered mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address of the property owner or owners as shown by the most recent tax list of said borough. Where the owner is a partnership, service upon any partner as above provided shall be sufficient. The applicant shall by affidavit present satisfactory proof to said board of commissioners at the time of the hearing that said notices have been duly served as aforesaid. 
(Code 1992, § 262-3; Ord. No. 453, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 34-384. - Issuance of permit. 
    Recognizing the necessity for motor vehicle service stations and, at the same time, that they may be inimical to the public safety and general welfare if located without due consideration of the conditions and surroundings, the board of commissioners, after duly considering the location and physical characteristics of the building or buildings intended to be erected or used and the traffic, fire and other hazards, conditions and surroundings incident to the operation of the proposed motor vehicle service station or gasoline or oil filling station and the public health, public safety, public convenience and general welfare of the community, shall grant the permit if, in the judgment of the board of commissioners, such building or buildings and use will not be detrimental to the health, safety and general welfare of the community and is reasonably necessary for the convenience of the community. 
(Code 1992, § 262-4; Ord. No. 453, 4-10-1979) 
Secs. 34-385-34-410. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - TAXICABS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Taxicabs, N.J.S.A. 48:161 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 34-411. - Definitions 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Taxicab means and includes any automobile or motorcar, commonly called "taxi," engaged in the business of carrying passengers for hire, which is held out, announced or advertised to operate or run, and which is operated or run, over any of the streets within the borough and particularly accepts and discharges such persons as may offer themselves for transportation from points or places to points or places within or without said borough, provided that nothing herein contained shall be construed to affect any public conveyance which is by law subject to state and/or federal regulation exclusively. 
(Code 1992, § 280-1; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-1, 12-27-2012) 
Sec. 34-412. - Reserved. 
    At the direction of Roger Merriam, senior code attorney, § 34-412 was repealed in its entirety, which pertained to hours of operation and derived from the Code of 1992, § 280-13; and Ord. No. 368, adopted May 13, 1969. 
Secs. 34-413-34-437. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal licensing of taxicabs, N.J.S.A. 48:16-2 et seq. 

Sec. 34-438. - License required. 
    No person shall pick up for hire any passengers for any taxicab within the borough unless both the taxicab and driver thereof are licensed pursuant to the terms of this article and conform to all the provisions hereof. 
(Code 1992, § 280-2; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-2, 12-27-2012) 
State Law reference- Municipal consent for operation of taxicab, N.J.S.A. 48:16-2. 
Sec. 34-439. - Taxicab license application; fees. 
    Every application for a taxicab license shall be made to the board of commissioners and shall set forth the full name and address of the owner, lessee or bailee of the taxicab to be licensed, the make and character of the taxicab, the length of time it has been in use, the number of persons said vehicle is suitable for carrying, the motor number and serial number of said vehicle, the then-present value of said vehicle and the place where it may be inspected by the members of the board of commissioners or their duly authorized representative. Each application shall be accompanied by a license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for a single taxicab to be licensed, together with a license fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each additional taxicab if there shall be more than one (1) taxicab to be licensed. In the event that any person desires to license six (6) or more taxicabs owned and operated by him/her within the borough, there shall be issued a fleet license covering all of such taxicabs for the fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Code 1992, § 280-3; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 515, 4-8-1983; Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-3, 12-27-2012) 
State Law reference- Limitation on taxicab license fees, N.J.S.A. 48:16-2. 
Sec. 34-440. - Persons eligible for licenses; criminal background check required. 
    Every application for a taxicab driver's license shall set forth the full name and address of the applicant, his or her age, whether or not he or she is a citizen of the United States and whether or not he or she has ever been convicted of a crime and, if so, the crime of which he or she has been convicted, the place of conviction, the date thereof and the punishment thereof. Each operator or driver of the taxicab for which the owner thereof is seeking the consent to operate in the borough must submit to a criminal history record check. The cost for the criminal history record background check, including all costs of administering and processing the check, shall be borne by the operator or driver of the vehicle. A person shall be disqualified from operating or driving a taxicab if a criminal history record background check required pursuant to this section reveals a record of conviction of any of the following crimes: 
(1)  In New Jersey or elsewhere any crime as follows: aggravated assault, arson, burglary, escape, extortion, homicide, kidnapping, robbery, aggravated sexual assault, sexual assault or endangering the welfare of a child pursuant to N.J.S.A. 2C: 24-4, whether or not armed with or having in his possession any weapon enumerated in subsection r. of N.J.S.A. 2C: 39-1, a crime pursuant to the provisions of N.J.S.A. 2C: 39-3, 2C: 39-4 or 2C: 39-9, or other than a disorderly persons or petty disorderly persons offense for the unlawful use, possession or sale of a controlled dangerous substance as defined in N.J.S.A. 2C: 35-2. 
(2)  In any other state, territory or commonwealth, or other jurisdiction of the United States, or any country in the world, as a result of a conviction in a court of competent jurisdiction, a crime which in that other jurisdiction or country is comparable to one of the crimes enumerated in paragraph (1) of this subsection. 
(3)  If a person has been convicted of one (1) of the crimes enumerated in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subsection can produce a certificate of rehabilitation issued pursuant to N.J.S.A. 2A: 168A-8 or, if the criminal offense occurred outside New Jersey, an equivalent certificate from the jurisdiction where the criminal offense occurred, the criminal offense shall not disqualify the applicant from operating or driving a taxicab. 
(4)  The provisions contained in subsections (1)-(3) above pertaining to a criminal background check shall not apply to an operator or driver of a taxicab who has received the consent to operate in the borough prior to the effective date of P.L. 2011, c. 135 (C. 48: 16-2.1 et al.) 
(Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-4, 12-27-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-4, adopted Dec. 27, 2012, amended § 34-440 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former § 34-440 pertained to persons ineligible for licenses and derived from the Code of 1992, § 280-4; Ord. No. 368, adopted May 13, 1969. 
Sec. 34-441. - Insurance requirements. 
    No taxicab license shall be issued until the applicant therefor shall have filed with the borough clerk an umbrella or "all perils" insurance policy issued by a company duly licensed to transact business under the insurance laws of this state in the sum of not less than thirty-five thousand dollars ($35,000.00), insuring against loss by reason of the liability imposed by law upon the owner or driver of said taxicab for damages on account of bodily injury or death suffered by any person as the result of or by reason of the ownership, maintenance or use of any taxicab within the borough, and in the sum of not less than sixty-five thousand dollars ($65,000.00), insuring against such loss or damage suffered by more than one (1) person as the result of such ownership, maintenance or use; and said insurance policy shall also provide for property damage insurance in the sum of not less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) for damage arising out of each ownership, maintenance or use minimum amount of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00.) Such policy shall also name the borough as an additional insured and shall require the issuer to notify the borough in the event of cancellation or termination of the policy. Any license issued for any such operation of said taxicab thereunder shall be permitted only so long as said insurance policy shall remain in force to the full and collectible amounts aforesaid. 
    The owner of a taxicab is not prohibited from obtaining any additional amount of motor vehicle liability insurance coverage from a company licensed outside the State of New Jersey. 
(Code 1992, § 280-5; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-5, 12-27-2012) 
State Law reference- Insurance. N.J.S.A. 48:16-3, 48:16-4. 
Sec. 34-442. - Power of attorney required. 
    No taxicab license shall be issued until the applicant therefor shall have delivered to said borough clerk, concurrently with the filing of the insurance policy referred to in section 34-441, a power of attorney executed by said applicant wherein and whereby said applicant shall appoint the treasurer of the borough his, her or its true and lawful attorney for the purpose of acknowledging service of any process out of a court of competent jurisdiction to be served against the insured by virtue of the indemnity granted under the insurance policy filed, and any license for a taxicab issued upon any such application shall continue effective and the operation of any taxicab thereunder shall be permitted only so long as said power of attorney shall remain in effect and unrevoked. 
(Code 1992, § 280-6; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-6, 12-27-2012) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, N.J.S.A. 48:16-5. 
Sec. 34-443. - Taxicab license card. 
    If the application for a taxicab license shall be granted, there shall be issued to the applicant a license card in evidence thereof setting forth the name and address of the license, the number of the license and the make and character of the taxicab licensed, together with the motor number and serial number of said vehicle and the maximum number of passengers to be carried therein at any one (1) time. Said license card shall be signed by the borough clerk and shall at all times be prominently displayed and adequately protected in the interior of any taxicab so licensed so that the fact thereof shall be at all times in full view and plainly legible to any passenger seated in the rear seat of such taxicab. There shall also be displayed in the interior of said taxicab so licensed a statement or schedule of the charges for the use thereof. Any taxicab license issued pursuant to this article may be transferred to another vehicle owned or in the custody of the same licensee, upon the payment of a transfer fee of one dollar ($1.00) and upon the approval of the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1992, § 280-7; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-7, 12-27-2012) 
Sec. 34-444. - Taxicab driver's license application; fee. 
    Every application for a taxicab driver's license shall be made to the board of commissioners and shall set forth the full name and address of the applicant, his or her age, whether or not he or she is a citizen of the United States and whether or not he or she has been convicted of a crime and, if so, the crime of which he or she has been convicted, the place of conviction, the date thereof and the punishment therefor. Section 34-440 herein fully describes the criminal background check procedures that must be followed by an applicant. 
    Such applicant shall also furnish satisfactory evidence that he or she has received a driver's license from the Motor Vehicle Department of the State of New Jersey. No taxicab driver's license shall be issued to any person who shall be under eighteen (18) years of age. Each applicant for a taxicab driver's license shall, at the time of filing his application, be fingerprinted by an outside agency, which fingerprint impressions may be used by the Borough of Audubon for securing from any agency any report or reports it may deem necessary with respect to said application. Said fingerprint impression and any report received with respect thereto shall be affixed to the application before consideration thereof by the board of commissioners. Each holder of a taxicab owners' license shall cause each driver employed by said holder to undergo testing by an accredited laboratory for use of controlled dangerous substances every six (6) months and provide to the borough proof of such testing. 
    A license fee of two dollars ($2.00) shall accompany each application for a taxicab driver's license. 
(Code 1992, § 280-8; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 515, 4-8-1983; Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-8, 12-27-2012) 
Sec. 34-445. - Taxicab driver's license card. 
    If the application for a taxicab driver's license shall be granted, there shall be issued to the applicant a license card in evidence thereof setting forth the number of the license, the name and address of the licensee and his or her age. Said license card shall be signed by the borough clerk and shall at all times be permanently displayed and adequately protected in the interior of any taxicab operated by the licensee so that the fact thereof shall be at all times in full view of and plainly legible to any passenger seated in the rear seat of such taxicab. 
(Code 1992, § 280-9; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-9, 12-27-2012) 
Sec. 34-446. - Verification of license application. 
    Every application for a taxicab license or a taxicab driver's license shall be verified by the oath or affirmation of the applicant or applicants, if an individual or co-partnership, and if a corporation, shall be verified by the oath or affirmation of an officer thereof. 
(Code 1992, § 280-10; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-10, 12-27-2012) 
Sec. 34-447. - Determination of number of new or additional taxi licenses available for issuance; taxicab application form and contents. 
    The borough shall, by ordinance, determine the number of new or additional taxi licenses available for issuance. After making this determination, the borough shall publish a notice of the new or additional authorized licenses. The notice shall specify a time and date after which no further applications will be accepted. The notice shall be published at least twice and at least one (1) week apart, with the second notice published at least thirty (30) days prior to the time and date specified in the notice as the time and date after which no further applications will be accepted. If a license or licenses are not issued within six (6) months after the closing time and date for acceptance of applications specified in the notice, no such license or licenses shall be issued without again complying with the above-described notice provisions. All applications for the issuance or renewal of any license of either class shall be made to the mayor and commissioners of the borough on the forms to be adopted by the said mayor and borough commissioners and to be obtained from the borough clerk and designed to elicit information respecting the identification, responsibility and law-abiding habits of the applicant. Pursuant to N.J.S.A. 48:16-2.1, the borough has the authority to determine the number of taxicab licenses available for issuance. The borough shall issue no more than fifteen (15) taxicab licenses per year. 
(Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-12, 12-27-2012; Ord. No. 2014-20, 12-30-2014) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-12, adopted Dec. 27, 2012, amended § 34-447 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former § 34-447 pertained to expiration of license; renewal and derived from the Code of 1992, § 280-11; Ord. No. 368, adopted May 13, 1969. 
Sec. 34-448. - Issuance, qualification for license. 
    Whenever the borough determines by ordinance to issue one (1) or more taxi licenses, the governing body may authorize that such license or licenses be issued to the highest qualified bidder therefor at a sale by public auction for that purpose conducted or supervised by the municipal clerk. The ordinance may prescribe qualifications for prospective bidders; provided, however that such qualifications shall not be inconsistent with any law of this state, or rule or regulation of any agency thereof. The ordinance may fix a minimum bid price and conditions of sale with reservation of the right to reject all bids where the highest bid is not accepted. The ordinance may also contain a provision that requires the recipient of the taxicab license to reimburse the municipality for any costs incurred by the municipality in complying with the public notice requirements discussed in section 34-447. In the event more than one (1) taxicab license is issued at the same public auction, the recipients thereof shall equally split the costs of reimbursing the municipality for any costs incurred by the municipality in complying with the public notice requirements. 
(Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-13, 12-27-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-13, adopted Dec. 27, 2012, amended § 34-448 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former § 34-448 pertained to required signs on vehicle and derived from the Code of 1992, § 280-12; Ord. No. 368, adopted May 13, 1969. 
Sec. 34-449. - Required signs on vehicle. 
    Every taxicab so licensed shall have painted on both sides thereof the words "Taxi" or "Cab" in letters at least three (3) inches high or the name of the operating owner containing the word "Taxi" or "Cab" or "Taxicab." Every taxicab shall display on the body of the vehicle the taxi license number issued to that vehicle. The number shall be three (3) inches in height and located in the center of the rear quarter panels on the driver and passenger sides and the rear center line of the trunk of the vehicle. Each taxicab shall display on each rear door of the taxicab the name of the municipality, i.e., the Borough of Audubon, in letters three (3) inches in height. 
(Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-14, 12-27-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-14, adopted Dec. 27, 2012, amended § 34-449 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former § 34-449 pertained to suspension or revocation of licenses and derived from the Code of 1992, § 280-14; Ord. No. 368, adopted May 13, 1969. 
State Law reference- Display of license number on taxicab, N.J.S.A. 48:16-4. 
Sec. 34-450. - Hours of operation. 
    Every application for a taxicab license shall, in addition to all of the other requirements contained in this chapter, contain a statement as to the hours when said taxicab will be in operation for public use, and the failure of any licensee to provide taxi service to the general public during the hours named in the application shall be sufficient cause for revocation of any license. 
(Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-15, 12-27-2012) 
Sec. 34-451. - Suspension or revocation of licenses. 
    The board of commissioners after notice and hearing may revoke or suspend any license issued pursuant to this article if the licensee has been once convicted of a crime in this or any other jurisdiction or has been convicted of being a disorderly person or of a violation of N.J.S.A. tit. 39 or who or which violates any provision of this article or has any judgment unsatisfied against him, her or it arising out of an automobile accident or who or which has made false answers in his, her or its application for such license or any renewal thereof or who or which has failed or fails to render reasonably prompt, safe, proper and adequate taxicab service or who or which has not complied fully with all the requirements of this chapter with respect to such license. Any taxicab driver's license may be revoked or suspended by the board of commissioners after notice and hearing if the licensee has in any degree contributed to any injury to person or damage to property arising out of the negligent operation of a motor vehicle or if said taxicab driver shall have any infectious, communicable or contagious disease. Any taxicab license may be revoked or suspended by the board of commissioners after notice and hearing if the taxicab licensed is dangerous to the safety or health of the occupants or others by reason of unsafe or unsanitary conditions or if the insurance policy required by section 34-441 hereof has once lapsed or if such insurance coverage is not maintained at all times or if said licensed taxicab shall be used for any improper, immoral or illegal business or purpose. 
(Ord. No. 2012-13, § 280-16, 12-27-2012) 
Secs. 34-452-34-470. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - GEMS, PRECIOUS METALS AND JEWELRY 

Sec. 34-471. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Dealer means any person, partnership, corporation or other entity, whether permanent or itinerant, who on one (1) of more occasions (through any means) buys and sells secondhand gold, silver, precious metals, gems or jewelry, and includes anyone advertising the purchase or sale of any of the aforementioned items. 
    Precious metals means items of gold, silver, platinum, and their alloys, including, but not limited to, jewelry, but excluding coins and bullion. 
    Itinerant business means any business conducted intermittently within the Borough of Audubon or at varying locations. 
    Minor means any person under the age of eighteen (18) years. 
    Permanent-based business means any business conducted on a year-round basis and housed in a single structure, such as a store or residence. 
(Ord. No. 2012-4, Art. I, 5-22-2012) 
Sec. 34-472. - Licenses. 
(a)  Issuance of license. 
(1)  Each dealer conducting business within the jurisdiction of the Borough of Audubon shall first register with the chief of the Audubon Police Department, or the officer so designated by the chief of police, who shall fingerprint the applicant and institute such an investigation of the applicant's moral character and business responsibility, as he deems necessary for the protection of the public welfare. In the event that the dealer is a business entity other than a sole proprietorship, the officers in a corporation or the partners in a partnership (or limited partnership) shall be deemed to be the applicant(s) who shall be fingerprinted and investigated in accordance with this section. Upon completion of the investigation, chief of the Audubon Police Department, or the officer so designated by the chief of police, shall either issue or deny the license based upon the results of his investigation. Upon the issuance of the license, the applicant shall be given a copy of this article. 
(2)  Any applicant denied a license under this section by chief of the Audubon Police Department, or the officer so designated by the chief of police, based upon the results of an investigation, may appeal such denial to the governing body of the Borough of Audubon within fifteen (15) days of the date of the denial. This appeal shall be perfected by service of a notice of appeal on the borough clerk of the Borough of Audubon either personally or by certified mail. 
(3)  The board of commissioners shall conduct a hearing on this appeal within thirty (30) days of its receipt of the appeal, and shall render a decision, in writing, on the appeal within twenty (20) days of the close of the hearing. 
(b)  License fees, non-transferability. The fee for a license under this article shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) per calendar year. A license issued under the provisions of this article shall not be transferable and shall terminate on December 31 of the year in which said license is issued. 
(c)  Revocation of license. Licenses issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked by the chief of the Audubon Police Department, or the officer so designated by the chief of police, after a hearing, upon notice to the applicant for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license. 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on the business of purchasing secondhand precious metals, gems and jewelry. 
(3)  Any violation of this article. 
(4)  Conviction of any crime or disorderly persons offense involving moral turpitude. 
(5)  Conducting the business of soliciting or canvassing in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety and general welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 2012-4, Arts. II, III, X, 5-22-2012) 
Sec. 34-473. - Surety bond. 
    Each licensee shall deliver a bond to the borough clerk executed by the applicant as principal with a surety company authorized to do business under the laws of the State of New Jersey as surety. The bond, to be approved by the borough attorney, shall be in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), conditioned for the due and proper observance of and compliance with the provisions and requirements of all ordinances of the borough in force or which may be adopted respecting the conduct of this business and conditioned also that the bond shall be and remain for the benefit of any person or persons who shall have received judgment against the licensee licensed under this article by reason of any damage sustained by any such person as a result of the operations of the licensee under this article, which damage shall be established by a judgment of a court of proper jurisdiction. 
    Said bond shall contain the following language: The obligation of this bond shall, in addition to the Borough of Audubon, be and remain for the benefit of any person who shall obtain a judgment against obligor, as a result of damage sustained in operation pursuant to any license granted under chapter 302 of the Ordinances of the Borough of Audubon. Said bond shall be kept for a minimum of one (1) year from the date of issuance of license and must be renewed annually along with the license. As per state law every itinerant business must also show proof of bond, issued license in jurisdiction of origin and weights and measures inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2012-4, Art. IX, 5-22-2012) 
Sec. 34-474. - Procedures of sale. 
    The dealer shall obtain each of the following pieces of information prior to purchase or transaction: the name, address, date of birth, driver's license number and state of issuance for the person from whom the items were purchased, received or sold. The name of the clerk making the transaction shall be "legibly set forth." 
    The precious metal(s) shall be retained in the form in which they were purchased for a period of ten (10) business days pursuant to article VII of this article. During this ten-day period the dealer may not sell the item. The dealer shall generate a receipt to allow the seller to return and receive compensation for the sold item(s). The purchased item(s) shall be kept in inventory, separate and apart from other merchandise that is currently available for sale. The dealer shall not pay the purchase price to the seller until the ten-day period has elapsed. Additionally, the dealer must comply with the digital imaging requirements discussed in article VI of this chapter. The transaction information must be documented on a "secondhand jewelry transaction receipt" form to be supplied to the Audubon Borough Police Department within forty-eight (48) hours of the transaction. 
(Ord. No. 2012-4, Art. IV, 5-22-2012) 
Sec. 34-475. - Records to be maintained. 
    Each dealer shall maintain a complete record of each purchase and sale, including the amount paid, description of the item and any identifying numbers or engravings. The dealer shall issue to the seller and keep for his own records, for not less than five (5) years, the weights of the precious metals purchase and the fineness of the precious metal. 
    The records required to be maintained shall be kept confidential by the dealer and shall be released only to appropriate law enforcement personnel. These records shall be subject to the inspection of any law enforcement officer requesting same in the normal course of his duties. The precious metal shall be retained in the form in which they were purchased for a period of ten (10) business days according to the procedures and descriptions described in article IV of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2012-4, Art. V, 5-22-2012) 
Sec. 34-476. - Description of items to be delivered to the chief of police or his designee. 
    Each dealer doing business in the Borough of Audubon shall deliver to the chief of the Audubon Police Department, or the officer so designated by the chief of police, the description of all items purchased, received or sold including a photographed recording of the item(s) being purchased by the dealer within 48 hours of the completion of the transaction of the "secondhand jewelry transaction receipt" forms prescribed by the public safety director, or official in charge. 
    The photograph shall be of digital form and quality with the ability to be electronically transferred to a computer. 
(Ord. No. 2012-4, Art. VI, 5-22-2012) 
Sec. 34-477. - Disposal within ten (10) days of purchase prohibited. 
    No dealer shall sell, melt or change the form of or dispose of any articles purchased or received within ten (10) days of the date of said purchase, and all such items shall be made available for at least ten (10) business days to any authorized police officer requesting such items. 
(Ord. No. 2012-4, Art. VII, 5-22-2012) 
Sec. 34-478. - Restrictions on transactions. 
    Each dealer must require identification of the person with whom he is transacting business, and no transaction may be made with any minor, as herein defined, nor with any individual who is in an intoxicated state and/or is under the influence of intoxicating liquor, narcotics or hallucinogenic or habit-producing drugs. 
(Ord. No. 2012-4, Art. VIII, 5-22-2012) 
Chapter 38 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal courts, N.J.S.A. 2B:12-1 et seq. 

Sec. 38-1. - Established. 
    A municipal court is hereby established in the Borough of Audubon, County of Camden and State of New Jersey, as provided by N.J.S.A. title 2B, ch. 12 (N.J.S.A. 2B:12-1 et seq.). 
(Code 1992, § 10-1; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 38-2. - Powers, duties, jurisdiction and limitations. 
    Said court shall have all of the powers, duties, jurisdiction and limitations conferred and provided by any law of the State of New Jersey or any rule or rules of the New Jersey Supreme Court. 
(Code 1992, § 10-1; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 38-3. - Compensation of judge. 
    The judge appointed pursuant to law shall be paid such salary as is provided by resolution of the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1992, § 10-3; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
State Law reference- Compensation of judge, N.J.S.A. 2B:12-7. 
Sec. 38-4. - Application to obtain services of municipal public defender; fee; inability to pay. 
    In order to obtain the services of the municipal public defender or a court approved counsel, an application must be filed with the municipal court on a form provided by the borough. The application form shall be consistent with the requirements of N.J.S.A. title 2A, ch. 158A (N.J.S.A. 2A:158A-1 et seq.). 
(1)  The municipal court judge shall make the decision as to which defendants are indigent after reviewing the defendant's application. This determination shall be based upon whether the applicant fits within the definition of "indigent defendant" found within N.J.S.A. 2B:24:2. 
(2)  The municipal court administrator shall assess a nonwaiveable application fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) upon each person from whom an application for services under this chapter is made. This fee shall be chargeable regardless of whether the applicant is found to require the services of the municipal public defender or court approved counsel. The municipal court judge may waive any application fee, in whole or in part, only if the court determines in its discretion, upon a clear and convincing showing by the applicant that the application fees represents an unreasonable burden upon the applicant. 
(3)  The defendant's inability to pay the application fee shall in no way affect or reduce the rendering of services under this chapter. In the case of a defendant who is unable or unwilling to pay the application fee, the fee shall become a lien and the borough may collect the fee consistent with N.J.S.A. 40:6A-1 and N.J.S.A. 2B:24-16. 
(4)  In all cases where it appears that the defendant has, or reasonably expects to have means to meet some part, though not all, of the cost of the services rendered to him, he shall be required to reimburse the borough, either by single payment or in installments in such amounts as the applicant can reasonably be expected to pay over a time period not to exceed four (4) months. No default or failure in the making of such payment shall affect or reduce the rendering of services under this chapter. 
(5)  All money collected for the use of this application fee shall be used exclusively to meet the costs incurred in providing the services of the municipal public defender or court approved counsel including, when required, expert and lay investigation and testimony. 
(Ord. No. 762-97, arts. I, II, 12-30-1997) 
State Law reference- Municipal public defenders, N.J.S.A. 2B:24-1 et seq. 
Chapter 42 - NUISANCES[1] 
Footnotes:
