    Trash means newspapers, ashes, glass, cans, bottles, grass cuttings and all other discarded articles commonly known as "debris" or "refuse" which can be enclosed in containers of the size and weight specified elsewhere in this article. 
(Code 1992, § 266-5; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 444, 9-26-1978) 
Sec. 50-63. - Placement for collection; materials collected. 
(a)  Placement for collection. No person or persons shall place ashes, rubbish or garbage on any sidewalk or in any street of the borough except between 4:00 p.m. of the day immediately preceding the day of collection each week and the hour on such day when such ashes, rubbish or garbage shall be collected from such sidewalk or street. 
(b)  Types of garbage, rubbish, and ashes collected. Only household garbage, rubbish, and ashes will be collected by the borough. This collection shall be limited to single-family homes and multi-unit residential buildings with three or less units. Apartment buildings or complexes in excess of three units will not be collected. All heavy, bulky, or large objects must be removed at the homeowner's expense or can be removed by the borough employees, using borough equipment, if the individual homeowner pays the tipping fee at the landfill or transfer point. If the individual homeowner elects the latter remedy, he must execute a contract with the borough in a form to be provided from time to time by resolution adopted by the borough commissioners. 
(Code 1992, § 266-6; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 444, 9-26-1978; Ord. No. 506, 10-12-1982; Ord. No. 747-97, § I, 3-4-1997) 
Sec. 50-64. - Collection by borough. 
    Except as provided herein, the borough shall be the sole collector of trash and garbage within the borough, and no person shall pick over or remove all or part of the trash, brush or garbage placed at the curb for borough collection, except as permitted by section 50-75. 
(Code 1992, § 266-7; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 444, 9-26-1978) 
Sec. 50-65. - Placement of trees or brush on streets unlawful. 
    No tree, tree stump, branch, brush or other similar objects shall be pushed, pulled or otherwise propelled on any public street. 
(Code 1992, § 266-18; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 444, 9-26-1978) 
Sec. 50-66. - Unlawful disposal of glass. 
    No person shall deposit or cause or permit to be deposited in or upon any street or sidewalk any glass or any article composed primarily of glass, except such as may be deposited at the curb for borough collection, and then only in a closed container. Also, any person who shall drop glass or otherwise cause glass to be dropped in any street or on any sidewalk so that such glass is thereby broken shall forthwith gather up and dispose of the same. 
(Code 1992, § 266-9; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 444, 9-26-1978) 
Sec. 50-67. - Unlawful deposits on streets. 
    No trash, brush or garbage shall be deposited upon any public street or in any other public place except at the curb for collection by the borough in accordance herewith. 
(Code 1992, § 266-10; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 444, 9-26-1978) 
Sec. 50-68. - Uncovered vehicles. 
    It is unlawful for any vehicle to be driven, moved, stopped or parked on any public roadway unless such a vehicle is constructed, covered or loaded to prevent any of its load from dropping, sifting, leaking or otherwise escaping therefrom. Any person operating a vehicle from which any materials which constitute litter have fallen or escaped, which could cause an obstruction, damage a vehicle or otherwise endanger travelers or public property must immediately cause the public property to be cleaned of all such materials and must pay the costs thereof. 
(Code 1992, § 266-12; Ord. No. 661, 6-18-1991) 
Sec. 50-69. - Construction sites. 
    It is unlawful for any owner, agent or contractor in charge of a construction or demolition site to permit the accumulation of litter before, during or immediately following the completion of any construction or demolition project. It is the duty of the owner, agent or contractor in charge of a construction site to furnish containers adequate to accommodate flyable or nonflyable debris or trash at areas convenient to construction areas and to maintain and empty the receptacles in such a manner and with such a frequency as to prevent spillage of refuse. 
(Code 1992, § 266-13; Ord. No. 661, 6-18-1991) 
Sec. 50-70. - Placement and removal of containers. 
    No person shall set or place any trash, brush, garbage or other material on the curbline for collection from any house, apartment or residence unit before 4:00 p.m. of the day prior to the collection day for the district in which the same is situated, nor shall he allow any empty containers to remain on the curbline, as herein provided, after 8:00 a.m. of the day following the day of collection, and such containers must be stored in such a manner as not to create a nuisance or annoyance to adjacent neighbors. 
(Code 1992, § 266-14; Ord. No. 661, 6-18-1991) 
Sec. 50-71. - Disposal regulations. 
    All trash and garbage placed at the curb shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  Garbage shall be drained of all liquids, wrapped in paper and placed in receptacles. 
(2)  All trash and wrapped garbage shall be mixed and shall be in closed containers, and such containers shall be securely enclosed, to the extent possible. 
(3)  Newspapers, magazines and similar materials, if not in a closed container, shall be securely tied to prevent their blowing away. 
(4)  No single article, bundle or loaded container shall exceed fifty (50) pounds and be longer than four (4) feet or bulkier than one (1) man can lift. 
(5)  No explosives or highly flammable materials shall be included in any trash or garbage set out. 
(6)  Household items and appliances shall be dismantled (doors and drawers removed) so as not to pose a threat to the lives of small children. 
(7)  No drugs of any kind shall be put out for collection by the borough, unless the chief of police is notified. 
(8)  All debris of any kind resulting from any construction, new or old, or from renovations performed by any person or persons, contractor or such shall be disposed of at a state-approved sanitary landfill. Any person doing such construction shall be informed of said article at the time of issue of a building permit by the borough building inspector. 
(Code 1992, § 266-15; Ord. No. 661, 6-18-1991) 
Sec. 50-72. - Covering of refuse containers or dumpsters. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) means a conveyance or system of conveyance (including roads with drainage systems, municipal streets, catch basins, curbs, gutters, ditches, manmade channels, or storm drains) that is owned or operated by the borough or other public body, and is designed and used for collecting and conveying stormwater. 
    Refuse container means any waste container that a person controls, whether owned, leased, or operated, including dumpsters, trash cans, garbage pails and plastic trash bags. 
    Stormwater means water resulting from precipitation (including rain and snow) that turns off the land's surface, is transmitted to the subsurface, is captured by separate storm sewers or other sewerage or drainage facilities or is conveyed by snow removal equipment. 
    Waters of the state means the ocean and its estuaries, all springs, streams and bodies of surface water or groundwater, whether natural or artificial, within the boundaries of the State of New Jersey or subject to its jurisdiction. 
(b)  Any person who controls, whether owned, leased or operated, a refuse container or dumpster must ensure that such container or dumpster is covered at all times and shall prevent refuse from spilling out or overflowing. 
(c)  Subsection (b) of this section does not apply to: 
(1)  Permitted temporary demolition containers. 
(2)  Litter receptacles (other than dumpsters or other bulk containers). 
(3)  Individual homeowners' trash and recycling containers. 
(4)  Refuse containers at facilities authorized to discharge stormwater under a valid NJPDES permit. 
(5)  Large bulky items (e.g., furniture, bound carpet and padding, white goods placed curbside for pickup). 
(d)  This section shall be enforced by the police department and the zoning officials of the borough. 
(e)  Any person who is found to be in violation of the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 955-09, §§ II-VI, 5-19-2009) 
Sec. 50-73. - Vehicles used to transport trash and garbage. 
    No trash, brush or garbage shall be transported on any public street in the borough, unless it is carried in a covered, leak proof vehicle. 
(Code 1992, § 266-16; Ord. No. 661, 6-18-1991) 
Sec. 50-74. - Materials originating outside borough. 
    No trash, brush or garbage originating outside the borough shall be disposed of at any place within the borough. 
(Code 1992, § 266-17; Ord. No. 661, 6-18-1991) 
Sec. 50-75. - Scavengers. 
    Any person not an employee of the borough shall not pick over or remove any part of the trash, brush or garbage placed at the curb for borough collection, unless he/she shall have first registered with the borough in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Any proposed registrant shall apply, in writing, to the borough clerk, giving his/her name and address, his place of business, if any, and the make, model and year of any vehicle he/she proposes to use. Said application shall state the applicant's willingness to comply with the following rules as a condition of registration: 
a.  Any vehicle used in connection with the subject activity shall be enclosed so as to prevent the dispersion of collected debris. 
b.  All debris so collected shall be disposed of outside the limits of the borough. 
c.  No registrant shall in any way interfere with borough employees engaging in collecting trash. 
d.  All trash, brush and garbage at the curb shall be left by the registrant as securely covered and contained as it was before he touched it. 
e.  All activity pursuant to registration under this section shall be carried on only during daylight hours. 
(2)  The application shall be made to the borough clerk, who shall thereupon issue a registration certificate and shall notify the chief of police of its issuance. 
(3)  The certificate shall be effective for the period of time specified on the certificate issued. The registration certificate shall be renewed as required by the same process described above. 
(4)  The failure to abide by the above regulations shall be sufficient cause for revocation of the registration for the particular year in which issued. 
(5)  The registration certificate shall at all times be in the possession of the person to whom it is issued while he/she is engaged in the authorized activity in the borough. 
(6)  The scavenger permit fee shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(7)  The following metals and items shall not be collected by scavengers under any circumstances with or without a permit fee. These items listed below shall not be collected under any circumstances by anyone within the borough boundaries within the borough: 
a.  Light iron; 
b.  Copper; 
c.  Brass; 
d.  Aluminum; 
e.  Lead; 
f.  White goods; 
g.  Batteries. 
(Code 1992, § 266-18; Ord. No. 515, 4-8-1983; Ord. No. 777-98, §§ 2, 3, 10-6-1998) 
Secs. 50-76-50-93. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - YARD WASTE 

Sec. 50-94. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Containerized means the placement of yard waste in a trash can, bucket, bag or other vessel, such as to prevent the yard waste from spilling or blowing out into the street and coming into contact with stormwater. 
    Street means any street, avenue, road, pike, drive, or other way, which is an existing state, county, or municipal roadway, and includes the land between the street lines, whether improved or unimproved, and may comprise pavement, shoulders, gutters, curbs, sidewalks, parking areas, and other areas within the street lines. 
    Yard waste means leaves and grass clippings. 
(Ord. No. 873-04, § II, 12-28-2004; Ord. No. 874-04, § II, 12-28-2004) 
Sec. 50-95. - Penalty. 
    Any person who is found to be in violation of the provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 873-04, § V, 12-28-2004; Ord. No. 874-04, § V, 12-28-2004) 
State Law reference- Penalty for ordinance violations, N.J.S.A. 40:49-5. 
Sec. 50-96. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this article shall be enforced by the police department and/or zoning enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 873-04, § III, 12-28-2004; Ord. No. 874-04, § IV, 12-28-2004) 
Sec. 50-97. - Containerization. 
    The owner or occupant of any property, or any employee or contractor of such owner or occupant engaged to provide lawn care or landscaping services, shall not sweep, rake, blow or otherwise place yard waste, unless the yard waste is containerized, in the street. If yard waste that is not containerized is placed in the street, the party responsible for placement of yard waste must remove the yard waste from the street or said party shall be deemed in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 873-04, § II, 12-28-2004) 
Sec. 50-98. - Collection 
    Sweeping, raking, blowing or otherwise placing yard waste that is not containerized at the curb or along the street is only allowed during the seven (7) days prior to a scheduled and announced collection, and shall not be placed closer than ten (10) feet from any storm drain inlet. Placement of such yard waste at the curb or along the street at any other time or in any other manner is a violation of this article If such placement of yard waste occurs, the party responsible for placement of the yard waste must remove the yard waste from the street or said party shall be deemed in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 874-04, § III, 12-28-2004) 
Secs. 50-99-50-124. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - RECYCLING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-01, adopted March 20, 2018, repealed the former art. VI, §§ 50-125-50-134, and enacted a new art. VI as set out herein. The former art. VI pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1992; Ord. No. 590, adopted October 13, 1987; Ord. No. 660, adopted June 18, 1991; and Ord. No. 726, adopted April 18, 1995. 

Sec. 50-125. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Audubon Borough Recycling Program Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. I, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 50-126. - Definitions. 
    Commingled means a combining of non-putrescible, source-separated recyclable materials for the purpose of recycling to include glass, aluminum, steel, plastic, corrugated and paper fiber. 
    Designated recyclable materials means those materials designated within the Camden County District Solid Waste Management Plan to be source separated for the purpose of recycling to include commingled, light iron, ferrous metal, waste oil, anti-freeze, yard and tree refuse (limbs, logs, branches, grass clippings, bushes, bituminous material, leaves) and e-waste. 
    Electronic waste means a computer central processing unit and associated hardware including keyboards, modems, printers, scanners and fax machines; a cathode ray tube, a cathode ray tube device, a flat panel display or similar video display device with a screen that is greater than four (4) inches measured diagonally and that contains one (1) or more circuit boards, including a television, cell phones; all corded electronic devices. 
    Multifamily dwelling means any building or structure, or complex of buildings in which two (2) or more dwelling units are owner-occupied or rented or leased, or offered for rental or lease, for residential purposes (see N.J.S.A 13:1E-99.13a.) and shall include hotels, motels, or other guest houses serving transient or seasonal guests as those terms are defined under Subsection (j) of Section 3 of the "Hotel and Multiple Dwelling Law," P.L. 1967, c. 76 (C.55:13A-1 et seq.). 
    Municipal recycling coordinator means the person or persons appointed by the municipal governing body and who shall be authorized to, among other things, enforce the provisions of this article, and any rules and regulations which may be promulgated hereunder. 
    Municipal solid waste (MSW) stream means all solid waste generated at residential, commercial, and institutional establishments within the boundaries of the municipality of the borough. 
    Recyclable material means those materials which would otherwise become solid waste, and which may be collected, separated, or processed and returned to the economic mainstream in the form of raw materials or products. 
    Source-separated recyclable materials means recyclable materials which are separated at the point of generation by the generator thereof from solid waste for the purposes of recycling. 
    Source separation means the process by which recyclable materials are separated at the point of generation by the generator thereof from solid waste for the purposes of recycling. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. I, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 50-127. - Source separation; exemption from source separation requirements. 
(a)  Mandatory source separation. It shall be mandatory for all persons who are owners, tenants, or occupants of residential and non-residential premises, which shall include but not be limited to retail and other commercial locations, as well as government, schools and other institutional locations within the municipality of the borough to separate designated recyclable materials from all solid waste. Designated recyclable materials shall be deposited separate and apart from other solid waste generated by the owners, tenants, or occupants of such premises and shall be placed separately at the curb in a manner and on such days and times as may be hereinafter established by regulations promulgated by the borough. 
(b)  Exemptions. Pursuant to N.J.S.A. 13:1E-99.16(d), the governing body of a municipality may exempt persons occupying commercial or institutional premises within its municipal boundaries from the source separation requirements of the ordinance which requires persons generating municipal solid waste within its municipal boundaries to source separate from the municipal solid waste stream, the specified recyclable materials if those persons have otherwise provided for the recycling of all designated recyclable materials. To be eligible for an exemption pursuant to this chapter, a commercial or institutional generator of solid waste shall file an application for exemption with the municipal recycling coordinator on forms to be provided for this purpose. The form shall include, at a minimum, the following information: the name of the commercial or institutional entity; the street address location and lot and block designation; the name, official title and phone number of the person making application on behalf of the commercial or institutional entity; the name, address, official contact person and telephone number of the facility which provides the service of recycling those designated recyclable materials, and a certification that the designated recyclable materials will be recycled, and that, at least on an annual basis, said recycling service provider or commercial/institutional generator shall provide written documentation to the municipal recycling coordinator of the total number of tons collected and recycled for each designated material. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. I, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 50-128. - Collection of recyclable materials. 
    The collection of recyclable materials shall be in the manner prescribed as follows: 
(1)  All containers containing recyclable materials shall be placed, prior to collection, between the curb and the sidewalk, or in the absence of curb and sidewalk, as near to the street as not to constitute a danger, where such receptacles shall be readily accessible to the collector without providing obstruction to pedestrians. The owner or occupant of the premises shall keep all receptacles clean and in safe handling condition. Receptacles or other items to be disposed of shall be placed as noted above anytime after 4:00 p.m. of the day immediately preceding the day of collection, but no later than 7:00 a.m. of the day of collection. After collection, any containers shall be removed from the curbside by no later than 7:00 p.m. of the day of collection. 
(2)  All receptacles or dumpsters shall be maintained in clean and safe manner. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. I, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 50-129. - Residential dwelling compliance requirements. 
    The owner of any property shall be responsible for compliance with this article. For multi-family units, the management or owner is responsible for setting up and maintaining the recycling system, including collection of recyclable materials, in accordance with guidelines or regulations established by the appropriate municipal office. Violations and penalty notices will be directed to the owner or management, in those instances where the violator is not easily identifiable. The management shall issue notification and collection rules to new tenants when they arrive and every six (6) months during their occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. I, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 50-130. - Non-residential establishment compliance requirements. 
(a)  All commercial and institutional generators of solid waste shall be required to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  The arrangement for collection of designated recyclables hereunder shall be the responsibility of the commercial, institutional or industrial property owner or their designee, unless the municipality provides for the collection of designated recyclable materials. All commercial, institutional or industrial properties which provide outdoors litter receptacles and disposal service for their contents shall also provide receptacles for designated recyclable materials, for those materials commonly deposited, in the location of the litter receptacle, and shall provide for separate recycling service for their contents. 
(c)  Every business, institution, or industrial facility shall report on an annual basis to the recycling coordinator, on such forms as may be prescribed, on recycling activities at their premises, including the amount of recycled material, by material type, collected and recycled and the vendor or vendors providing recycling service. 
(d)  All food service establishments, as defined in the health code, shall, in addition to compliance with all other recycling requirements, be required to recycle grease and/or cooking oil created in the processing of food or food products, and maintain such records as may be prescribed, for inspection by any code enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. I, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 50-131. - New developments of multi-family residential units or commercial, institutional, or industrial properties. 
(a)  Any application to the joint land use board of the borough or subdivision or site plan approval for the construction of multi-family dwellings of three (3) or more units, single family developments of fifty (50) or more units or any commercial, institutional, or industrial development for the utilization of one thousand (1,000) square feet or more of land, must include a recycling plan. This plan must contain, at a minimum, the following: 
(1)  A detailed analysis of the expected composition and amounts of solid waste and recyclables generated at the proposed development; and 
(2)  Locations documented on the application's site plan that provide for convenient recycling opportunities for all owners, tenants, and occupants. The recycling area shall be of sufficient size, convenient location and contain other attributes (signage, lighting, fencing, etc.) as may be determined by the municipal recycling coordinator. 
(b)  Prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy by the borough, the owner of any new multi-family housing or commercial, institutional, or industrial development must supply a copy of a duly executed contract with a hauling company for the purposes of collection and recycling of source-separated recyclable materials, in those instances where the municipality does not otherwise provide this service. 
(c)  Provision shall be made for the indoor, or enclosed outdoor, storage and pickup of solid waste, to be approved by the JLUB engineer. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. I, 3-20-2018) 
State Law reference- Adoption of model ordinance on recycling in multifamily housing, N.J.S.A. 13:1E-99.13a; municipal recycling system, N.J.S.A. 13:1E-99.16c. 
Sec. 50-132. - Prohibition of the collection of solid waste mixed with recyclable materials. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for solid waste collectors to collect solid waste that is mixed with, or contains visible signs of, designated recyclable materials. It is also unlawful for solid waste collectors to remove for disposal those bags or containers of solid waste which visibly display a warning notice sticker or some other device indicating that the load of solid waste contains designated recyclable materials. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the resident or occupant to properly segregate the uncollected solid waste for proper disposal or recycling. Allowing such unseparated solid waste and recyclables to accumulate will be considered a violation of this article and the local sanitary code. 
(c)  Once placed in the location identified by this article, or any rules or regulations promulgated pursuant to this article, no person, other than those authorized by the municipality, shall tamper with, collect, remove, or otherwise handle designated recyclable materials. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. I, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 50-133. - Enforcement. 
    The certified public works manager, the code enforcement official, the recycling coordinator, the zoning enforcement official, and the Camden County Department of Health are hereby individually and severally empowered to enforce the provisions of this article. An inspection may consist of sorting through containers and opening of solid waste bags to detect, by sound or sight, the presence of any recyclable material. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. I, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 50-134. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person, corporation, occupant, or entity that violates or fails to comply with any provision of this article or any of the rules and regulations promulgated hereunder shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Each day for which a violation of this article occurs shall be considered a separate offence. (Note the borough will enforce the provisions of N.J.S.A. 40:49-5 if and where necessary.) 
    Fines levied and collected pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be immediately deposited into the municipal recycling trust fund (or equivalent). Monies in the municipal recycling trust fund shall be used for the expenses of the municipal recycling program. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. I, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 50-135. - Severability; effective date. 
    If it is determined, by a court of competent jurisdiction, that any provision or section of this article is unconstitutional, all other sections and provisions shall remain in effect. This article shall take effect immediately. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. I, 3-20-2018) 
ARTICLE VII. - CONSTRUCTION, RENOVATION AND DEMOLITION DEBRIS RECOVERY PLAN 

Sec. 50-136. - Definitions. 
    Covered project means a construction, renovation, or demolition project for which a building permit or a demolition permit is required, and for which a dumpster or roll-off container shall be placed on premises for the purpose of placement of solid waste materials. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. II, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 50-137. - Review of debris recovery plan. 
    A debris recovery plan shall be filed with the municipal recycling coordinator prior to the commencement of any activity for which municipal approval is required as further identified above. The debris recovery plan shall identify the types and estimated quantities of construction and demolition debris to be generated from the project, how each material will be managed, and the name of each facility or service provider that the entity will use to manage each material. The plan shall further detail how the applicant shall ensure that a minimum of fifty percent (50%) of the materials to be generated will be separated and recycled. 
(1)  Approval . A debris recovery plan shall be reviewed by the municipal recycling coordinator, and approved if it provides for all of the information required by this article. An approved debris recovery plan shall be marked "approved" and returned to the owner of the entity which submitted the plan. 
(2)  Denial. A debris recovery plan shall not be approved if it does not provide all of the information required by this article. If a debris recovery plan is not approved, the owner of the entity which submitted the plan, shall be notified in writing that the plan has been rejected, including the reasons for the rejection. In order to obtain the building or demolition permit sought, the owner of the entity which will carry out the construction, renovation, or demolition project shall make the required changes and resubmit the debris recovery plan to the municipal recycling coordinator. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. II, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 50-138. - Diversion requirement adjustment. 
(a)  Application . If the owner of an entity carrying out a covered project experiences circumstances that makes it infeasible to comply with the diversion requirement cited in this article, the owner of the entity may apply for an adjustment. The owner shall indicate in writing why it is infeasible to divert fifty percent (50%) of the materials being generated from the covered project and specify what percentage of diversion could be achieved. Increased costs to the owner of the entity carrying out the covered project will not be an acceptable justification for an adjustment. 
(b)  Review . The municipal recycling coordinator shall review the information supplied by the owner. If warranted the municipal recycling coordinator shall attempt to contact the owner to discuss possible ways of meeting the diversion requirement. 
(c)  Granting of an adjustment. If the municipal recycling coordinator determines that it is infeasible for the entity carrying out a covered project to divert fifty percent (50%) of the generated C&D debris from the covered project, the percent of diversion required shall be adjusted. The owner shall be notified in writing of the adjusted diversion requirement. The owner of the entity carrying out the covered project shall be required to divert the percent of C&D debris required by the adjustment. 
(d)  Denial of adjustment . If the municipal recycling coordinator determines that it is feasible for the owner of an entity carrying out a covered project to meet the diversion requirement cited in this article, the owner shall be notified in writing of the denial of the diversion requirement adjustment. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. II, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 50-139. - Debris recovery plan reporting requirements. 
    Documentation . Upon completion of the covered project, but before the final inspection, the owner of the entity carrying out a covered project shall submit in person or by certified mail to the municipal recycling coordinator, the documentation required to demonstrate that the applicant has met the diversion requirement. The required documentation shall include the following: 
(1)  A completed debris recovery report, signed by the owner of the entity carrying out a covered project, indicating the quantity of each material generated during the covered project diverted or disposed, 
(2)  Receipts from all facilities or service providers utilized to divert and dispose of materials generated during the covered project, and 
(3)  Any additional information that the owner of the entity carrying out the covered project believes is relevant to determining compliance with the diversion requirement. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. II, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 50-140. - Compliance with diversion requirement. 
    The municipal recycling coordinator shall review the information submitted pursuant to this article and determine whether the owner of the entity carrying out the covered project has complied, or failed to comply with the diversion requirement. The determination regarding compliance will be provided to the owner of the entity carrying out the covered project in writing. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. II, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 50-141. - Appeal. 
    An owner of the entity carrying out the covered project may appeal a determination of failure to comply under this article to the municipality within thirty (30) days of the decision or determination. The appeal shall be in writing and shall state the facts and basis for the appeal. A decision by the department of public works shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. II, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 50-142. - Enforcement. 
    The certified public works manager, the code enforcement official, the recycling coordinator, the zoning enforcement official, and the county department of health are hereby individually and severally empowered to enforce the provisions of this article. An inspection may consist of sorting through containers and opening of solid waste bags to detect, by sound or sight, the presence of any recyclable material. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. II, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 50-143. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person, corporation, occupant, or entity that violates or fails to comply with any provision of this article or any of the rules and regulations promulgated hereunder shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. II, 3-20-2018) 
Sec. 50-144. - Severability; effective date. 
    If it is determined, by a court of competent jurisdiction, that any provision or section of this article is unconstitutional, all other sections and provisions shall remain in effect. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, Art. II, 3-20-2018) 
Chapter 54 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Streets generally, N.J.S.A. 40:67-1 et seq.; sidewalks, N.J.S.A. 40:65-1 et seq.; general powers relating to streets, highways, lanes, alleys and public places, N.J.S.A. 40:67-1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Duty to construct or repair sidewalks. 
    The owner or owners of lands fronting or bordering on the public streets of the borough are hereby required to construct, pave, repave, curb, recurb, improve and/or repair at his or their own proper cost and expense the sidewalks and curbs on both sides of the public streets of the borough in accordance with the provisions of this article; provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed to affect any sidewalks and curbs on said streets now in good repair and constructed at the proper grade or slope and substantially in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1992, § 270-1; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969; Ord. No. 480, 10-14-1980) 
State Law reference- Sidewalk repairs, N.J.S.A. 40:65-1 et seq. 
Sec. 54-2. - Snow and ice removal. 
    Every owner or owners or tenant or tenants of lands abutting or bordering upon sidewalks and gutters of public streets, avenues and highways of the borough shall remove all snow and ice from the same within twelve (12) hours of daylight after the same is formed or falls thereon. 
(Code 1992, § 270-6; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
State Law reference- Removal of snow and ice by municipalities, N.J.S.A. 40:48-9.11, 40:65-12. 
Sec. 54-3. - Sidewalk obstructions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any storekeeper, merchant or any other person or corporation to encumber or obstruct or permit to be encumbered or obstructed more than two (2) feet of the sidewalk immediately adjacent to the building line in front or alongside of his, her, their or its residence, dwelling place, place of business or other premises with baskets, barrels, boxes, showcases or merchandise or in any other way or manner, and then only temporarily and only on that portion of such sidewalk farthest away from the curb and within two (2) feet adjacent to said building line. 
(Code 1992, § 270-8; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Secs. 54-4-54-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREET OBSTRUCTIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 54-25. - Use of streets for storage. 
(a)  The space in any street to be used for the storing or placing of any building materials or appliances shall not exceed in extent the frontage of the owner of the lands upon which said building or buildings are to be erected, repaired or altered or additions made thereto and an additional eighty (80) feet adjoining said frontage on either side thereof, provided that the owners abutting on said additional space do not object thereto, in writing, to the director of highways; and if any such objections are made, the person or persons to whom such permit was issued shall immediately upon notice from said director of highways remove all materials and appliances from that part of such street in front of the person so objecting. 
(b)  No portion of any street shall be used for such purpose greater than a width of nine (9) feet from the curbline, and no materials or appliances shall be placed within fifteen (15) inches of the curbline or within twelve (12) inches of the gutter level, but the gutter shall at all times be open for a width of fifteen (15) inches and a height of twelve (12) inches. 
(c)  No materials or appliances shall be more than thirteen (13) feet in height and shall not be placed within fifteen (15) feet of any fire hydrant or street crossing. 
(Code 1992, § 270-13; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 54-26. - Mixing materials on streets. 
    No mortar, lime plaster, cement, concrete or other materials shall be mixed on any street in said borough paved with any material, and a permit shall not authorize the same unless the same shall be contained in a watertight box, the bottom of which shall be tongued and grooved and placed on bearers or sleepers leaving an airspace of at least four (4) inches between the street level and the bottom of the box, and the sides of which box shall be protected by a planking of at least twelve (12) inches in height. 
(Code 1992, § 270-14; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 54-27. - Fires on streets. 
    No bonfires or fire for the melting of solder, or tar or for the heating of roofing material or for any other purpose shall be made upon the surface of any street which is paved with any material, and a permit shall not authorize the same. 
(Code 1992, § 270-15; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 54-28. - Manner of storing materials; safeguards. 
    All materials or appliances placed or stored upon any street by virtue of any permit shall be stored or packed in such manner so as not to be dangerous to life or property or a menace to other users of said street, and lighted red lanterns or lamps shall be maintained at each end of such materials or appliances and at such other places as the director of highways shall direct, which shall be kept lighted from one (1) hour before sunset to one (1) hour after sunrise. 
(Code 1992, § 270-17; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 54-29. - Maintenance and cleaning of street area. 
    The person or persons or corporation or corporations to whom any permit may be issued shall at all times keep the portion of any street so occupied by any materials or appliances, and the adjacent area, in a clean condition satisfactory to the director of highways and shall sprinkle and wet the same with water, when directed so to do by said director of highways; and all dirt and debris shall be promptly removed, together with all unused materials or appliances, upon the completion of any building, buildings, repairs, alterations or additions made thereto, and the portion of any street so used by virtue of the permit shall be cleaned in a manner satisfactory to said director of highways. 
(Code 1992, § 270-18; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 54-30. - Obstructions interfering with traffic. 
    The director of highways shall in no event issue and grant a permit for any portion of a street that will interfere or obstruct the free passage of wagons, automobiles and other vehicles between said materials or appliances and the curb on the opposite side of the street. 
(Code 1992, § 270-20; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 54-31. - Removal of materials for street obstructions. 
    If the borough shall improve any street upon which any permit has been issued hereunder, which improvement includes the space designated in said permit, the person or corporation to whom such permit was issued shall immediately remove any material or appliances from said space to another space on said street or other places which the director of highways shall designate in writing. 
(Code 1992, § 270-21; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Secs. 54-32-54-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 54-51. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or persons or corporation or corporations to use any portion of any of the streets, avenues or other public places in the borough for the placing or storing of any building material or appliances thereon without first obtaining therefor a permit from the director of highways, as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1992, § 270-10; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 54-52. - Permit application. 
    All applications for permits under this article shall be in writing, signed by the applicant and filed with said director of highways, and shall set forth the following facts: 
(1)  The number and extent of such building or buildings for the accommodation of which he or they desire to occupy any portion of any streets. 
(2)  The dimensions and manner of construction of the building or buildings so to be erected, repaired, altered or additions made thereto, together with the number of stories and material to be used. 
(3)  The length or period of time said street space is requested for said materials or appliances. 
(Code 1992, § 270-11; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 54-53. - Issuance of permit; fee. 
    Upon the filing of such application, the director of highways shall issue a permit to such applicant designating the street and space thereon to be occupied by such materials or appliances and the period of time for which it may be so occupied, provided that such applicant shall first pay a permit fee of one dollar ($1.00) per month for such time as said director shall determine that said portion of said street will be necessarily used by said materials or appliances. 
(Code 1992, § 270-12; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 54-54. - Permit limitations. 
    No permit hereunder shall be construed to authorize the person or corporation to whom issued to pile any materials in any street, excepting such as are to be used in said building, or to place any planks or gangways across any sidewalk so as to in any way obstruct the free passage thereof. 
(Code 1992, § 270-16; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 54-55. - Extension of permit duration; fee. 
    In the event that any materials or appliances shall be upon any street for a longer period than the time authorized by the permit, the person or corporation to whom such permit was issued shall immediately upon the expiration of the time set forth in such permit apply to said director of highways for an extension of time for the use of such street, and upon the granting of the permit for such extended time, the applicant shall pay one dollar ($1.00) per month from the expiration of the time originally fixed for such further time as said director of highways shall determine will be reasonably necessary to use said street for said purpose for which said permit was originally issued. All fees imposed herein are for revenue. 
(Code 1992, § 270-19; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Secs. 54-56-54-83. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARADES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate parades, N.J.S.A. 40:67-1(l). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 54-84. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parade means any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, park or other public place in the borough. 
    Parade permit means a permit required by this article. 
Sec. 54-85. - Obstructing, interfering with generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to unreasonably hamper, obstruct, impede or interfere with any parade or parade assembly or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade. 
Sec. 54-86. - Parking on parade route. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a street or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a parade. The chief of police shall post signs to such effect, and, when so posted, it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. 
Secs. 54-87-54-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 54-116. - Required; exceptions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in or participate in, aid, form or start any parade, unless a parade permit has been obtained from the chief of police, with the following exceptions: 
(1)  Funeral processions. 
(2)  Students going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities, provided that such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities. 
(3)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Code 1992, § 224-4; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 54-117. - Application. 
(a)  Filing. A person seeking issuance of a parade permit shall file an application with the chief of police on forms provided by the chief. The application shall be filed not less than fourteen (14) days, nor more than twenty-one (21) days, before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade; provided, however, that the chief of police, where good cause is shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider an application which is filed less than fourteen (14) days before the date on which the parade is proposed to be conducted. 
(b)  Contents. The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct the parade. 
(2)  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization. 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairperson and who will be responsible for its conduct. 
(4)  The date when the parade is to be conducted. 
(5)  The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point. 
(6)  The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute the parade, and the types of animals and a description of the vehicles. 
(7)  The time when the parade will start and terminate. 
(8)  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traveled. 
(9)  The location, by streets, of any assembly areas for the parade. 
(10)  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any assembly area. 
(11)  The interval of space to be maintained between units of the parade. 
(12)  If the parade is designed to be held by, or on behalf of or for, any person other than the applicant, the applicant shall file with the chief of police a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf. 
(13)  Any additional information which the chief of police shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether the permit should be issued. 
(Code 1992, § 224-4; Ord. No. 368, 5-13-1969) 
Sec. 54-118. - Issuance or denial. 
(a)  The chief of police shall act upon an application for a parade permit within two (2) days after the filing. The chief shall issue the permit when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may be otherwise obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route. 
(2)  The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the borough to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the borough. 
(3)  The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of the borough other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto. 
(4)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas. 
(5)  The conduct of the parade will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire. 
(6)  The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property or to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance. 
(7)  The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route. 
(8)  The parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, goods or event, and is not designed to be held purely for private profit. 
(b)  If the chief of police disapproves an application for a parade permit, he shall mail to the applicant, within three (3) days after the date upon which the application was filed, a notice of his action, stating the reasons for his denial of the permit. Any person aggrieved by such denial shall have the right to appeal to the commission. The appeal shall be taken within two (2) days after notice of the denial. The commission shall act upon the appeal within two (2) days after its receipt. 
Sec. 54-119. - Issuance of alternate permit. 
    The chief of police, in denying an application for a parade permit, may authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time or over a route different than that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within seven (7) days after notice of the action of the chief of police, file a written notice of acceptance with the chief of police. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements, and shall have the effect, of a parade permit issued under this article. 
Sec. 54-120. - Contents. 
    Each parade permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  Starting time. 
(2)  Minimum speed. 
(3)  Maximum speed. 
(4)  Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade. 
(5)  The portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade. 
(6)  The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof. 
(7)  Such other information as the chief of police shall find necessary for the enforcement of this article. 
Sec. 54-121. - Compliance with conditions and directions of permit and other applicable laws; carried by the parade chairperson. 
(a)  The holder of a parade permit shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
(b)  The parade chairperson or other person heading or leading a parade shall carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade. 
Sec. 54-122. - Revocation. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit upon application of the standards for issuance as set forth in this article. 
Secs. 54-123-54-142. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BUILDING AND LOT NUMBERING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to require numbering of buildings and lots, N.J.S.A. 40:67-1(j). 

Sec. 54-143. - Applicability. 
    The intention of this article is to apply retroactively and to include existing lots and buildings as well as those created after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(Code 1992, § 136-1; Ord. No. 454, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 54-144. - Numbering of buildings and lots. 
    All buildings and lots of land established within the borough shall be subject to being numbered for proper identification. 
(Code 1992, § 136-2; Ord. No. 454, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 54-145. - Designated numbers to be used. 
    It is hereby declared unlawful to use any new number on any building unless it is a number designated for use on the borough maps for the particular location of any such building. 
(Code 1992, § 136-3; Ord. No. 454, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 54-146. - Inconsistent numbers to be changed. 
    Any person, firm, association or corporation now the owner of any interest in a building or who or which may hereafter acquire any such interest is hereby charged with the obligation to change any number or numbers now in use on any such building if such numbers are inconsistent with the numbering system hereby established as contained on borough maps. Such obligations shall continue as long as such ownership interest continues to exist, and it is hereby declared unlawful to use any number inconsistent with said borough system and maps. 
(Code 1992, § 136-4; Ord. No. 454, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 54-147. - Specifications for numbers; responsibility for expense. 
    The numbers shall be a minimum of two and one-half (21/2) inches in height, shall be clearly visible on the background to which they are attached and shall be located in a prominent place on the property so that they will be visible from the street. House numbers shall be procured and affixed at the owner's expense. 
(Code 1992, § 136-5; Ord. No. 454, 4-10-1979) 
ARTICLE V. - BLOCK PARTIES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 54-148. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Block party means any event conducted in or upon any street whereby the activity causes the street to be close to vehicular traffic. 
    Block party street means the numerical block of the street requested. 
    Block party permit means a permit required by this article. 
    Traffic restrictive devices means barricades, cones and emergency caution tape. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13 , Art. I, 11-21-2017) 
Sec. 54-149. - Obstructing, interfering with generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to unreasonably hamper, obstruct, impede or interfere with any block party assembly. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13 , Art. I, 11-21-2017) 
Sec. 54-150. - Vehicle parking on block party streets. 
    The Chief of Police shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along the street whereby the block party is being conducted. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13 , Art. I, 11-21-2017) 
Sec. 54-151. - Closure of street to vehicular traffic. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to effectuate the closure of the block party street to vehicular traffic by the use of traffic restrictive devices provided by the department of public works. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13 , Art. I, 11-21-2017) 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 54-152. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in or participate in any block party unless a block party permit has been obtained by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13 , Art. I, 11-21-2017) 
Sec. 54-153. - Application. 
(a)  Filing. A person seeking issuance of a block party permit shall file an application with the chief of police on the forms provided by the borough clerk's office. The application shall be filed not less than twenty-one (21) days, nor more than thirty (30) days, before the date on which the block party is to occur. 
(b)  Contents. The application for a block party shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and phone number of the person seeking to conduct the block party. 
(2)  The date when the block party is to occur. 
(3)  The location of the block party street. 
(4)  The start and stop time of the block party. 
(5)  A statement as to whether the block party street will be blocked entirely or only a portion of the block party street. 
(6)  Confirmation by signature that all affected owners/tenants from the requested block street are aware a block party is taking place and vehicular traffic will be restricted during the block party. 
(7)  Any additional information which the chief of police shall find reasonably necessary to make a fair determination as to whether the permit shall be issued. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13 , Art. I, 11-21-2017) 
Sec. 54-154. - Issuance or denial. 
    The chief of police shall act upon an application for a block party within five (5) days after the filing. The chief shall issue the permit when it is evident that the request is reasonable and poses no detriment to the community at large. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13 , Art. I, 11-21-2017) 
Sec. 54-155. - Notification to borough agencies. 
(a)  The chief of police shall notify the department of public works of the issuance and details of the permit and advise them as to the number of traffic restrictive devices that are needed for the block party. 
(b)  The chief of police shall notify the fire department and EMS of the issuance and details of the permit. 
(c)  The chief of police shall notify the director of public safety of the issuance and details of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13 , Art. I, 11-21-2017) 
Chapter 58 - TAXATION 

Sec. 58-1. - Exemption of improvements for older housing. 
(a)  Purpose. The Five-Year Exemption and Abatement Law (N.J.S.A. 40A:21-1 et seq.) enables municipalities to exempt from taxation an improvement project from ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) to twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) of assessed value for a single-family dwelling residential housing twenty (20) years old or older for a period of five (5) years; and the Borough of Audubon has determined that this tax incentive should be utilized in order to counteract trends toward deterioration in residential neighborhoods. 
(b)  Exemption allowed. The tax assessor is hereby directed to allow tax exemptions throughout the entire Borough, in accordance with the Five-Year Exemption and Abatement Law (N.J.S.A. 40A:21-1 et seq.) for qualified residential single-family housing. 
(c)  Determining the value of real property. In determining the value of real property for the purpose of taxation, an assessed improvement of least ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) up to twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) of the assessor's full and true value of home improvement, for each single-family dwelling unit more than twenty (20) years old, primarily and directly affected by the home improvement, shall be regarded as not increasing the value of such property for a period of five (5) years, notwithstanding that the value of the dwelling to which such improvements are made is increased thereby. 
(d)  Assessment not to be less than pervious assessment. In no event, however, shall the assessment during that period be less than the assessment thereon existing immediately prior to such home improvements unless there shall be damage through action of the elements sufficient to warrant a reduction. 
(e)  Assessment true value of improvement. The above assessed amount, determined by the tax assessor on October 1 of any year following the completion of the improvements, shall be the true value of the improvement and shall continue to be so treated for each of the five (5) years subsequent to the original determination by the tax assessor. 
(f)  Tax period of exemption. No exemption shall be granted until such time as the value of an improvement exceeds ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) of additional assessed value. Additional improvements, completed during a period in which the improved property is subject to a previously granted exemption privilege, shall not be qualified for additional deduction privileges under terms and conditions therein specified, during the five-year tax period. 
(g)  Filing of written application for exemption. A claimant desiring to seek the exemption to the above shall file a written application with the tax assessor of the borough pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40A:21-16, within thirty (30) days of completion of the improvement, conversion, alternation or construction. 
Chapter 62 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Motor vehicles and traffic regulation, N.J.S.A. 39:1-1 et seq.; municipal regulation of traffic, N.J.S.A. 39:4-197 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Word usage. 
(a)  Whenever any words and phrases are used in this chapter, the meaning respectively ascribed to them N.J.S.A. title 39, ch. 1 (N.J.S.A. 39:1-1 et seq.) shall be deemed to apply to such words and phrases used herein. 
(b)  Official time standard. Whenever certain hours are named in this chapter, they shall mean either Eastern standard time or Eastern daylight saving time, as may be in current use. 
(Code 1992, § 291-1; Ord. No. 654, 3-19-1991) 
Sec. 62-2. - Towing of vehicles. 
    Any vehicle parked in violation of this chapter shall be deemed a nuisance and a menace to the safe and proper regulation of traffic, and any peace officer may provide for the removal of such vehicle. The owner shall bear the reasonable costs of removal or storage which may result from such removal before regaining possession of any vehicle. 
(Code 1992, § 291-3; Ord. No. 654, 3-19-1991) 
Sec. 62-3. - Charitable solicitations in roadways. 
(a)  The borough shall permit charitable organizations as such are defined in N.J.S.A. 45:17A-20 to solicit contributions in roadways located in the borough in accordance with the provisions contained herein. 
(b)  All charitable organizations as defined in N.J.S.A. 45:17A-20 who desire to solicit contributions in roadways located in the borough shall file an application for a permit with the borough clerk on a form prepared by the borough which shall include the following information: 
(1)  Name, address, telephone number and name of contact person and proof of its designation as a charitable organization as provided in N.J.S.A. 45:17A-20; 
(2)  Specific location or locations of proposed charitable solicitation; 
(3)  Dates and times of proposed charitable solicitation; 
(4)  A diagram of the proposed solicitation areas including the location of any persons anticipated to be situated within the roadway; 
(5)  Written approval from the Camden County Board of Chosen Freeholders to conduct the solicitation in the event that it is to be conducted on any county highway or intersection of a county highway; 
(6)  Written approval from the commissioner of transportation of the state to conduct the solicitation in the event that it is to be conducted on any state highway or intersection of a state highway; 
(7)  A description of the manner in which the motorist solicitation will be conducted and the procedures to be used to ensure the safety of the members of the public who will be traveling the roadways situated in the borough; and 
(8)  Consent by an authorized representative of the charitable organization that it shall comply with any conditions imposed by the borough during the time that the solicitation is conducted. 
(c)  Upon filing of a complete application in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, following review by the borough chief of police or his designee and the borough administrator, the borough administrator shall be authorized to grant or deny the applicant's request. In the event the applicant's request is granted, a permit shall be issued to the applicant which shall be subject to the representations contained in the applicant's application and any conditions imposed by the borough administrator. 
(d)  The borough administrator, following consultation with the borough chief of police and the borough's insurer, shall be authorized to impose condition for the motorist solicitation. 
(e)  Any charitable organization requesting authorization from the borough for charitable solicitation shall comply with all of the terms and conditions of N.J.S.A. 39:4-60 and any procedures required by the borough. 
(Ord. No. 940-08, §§ 1-5, 8-19-2008) 
Sec. 62-4. - Skateboards prohibited in specified areas. 
(a)  No person shall ride a skateboard or other similar device on the public sidewalks, street, steps, ledges, curbing, or railing in the following described areas within the borough: 
(1)  Merchant Street (Route 30 (White Horse Pike) to Beloit Avenue); 
(2)  Peddlers Path; 
(3)  East Atlantic Avenue (from Dowling Avenue to Taylor Avenue); 
(4)  West Atlantic Avenue (from West Graisbury Avenue to West Nicholson Road); 
(5)  Entire Municipal Parking Lot along West Atlantic between West Merchant Street and Nicholson Road. 
(b)  No person shall ride a skateboard or other similar device upon private property if the owner of such private property has not granted permission to such person to ride a skateboard or other similar device upon such private property. 
(Ord. No. 844-03, §§ 1, 2, 4-23-2003) 
Sec. 62-5. - Obstructing traffic. 
    No person or persons shall obstruct any street or alley with any encumbrance whatsoever unless as otherwise expressly permitted herein, nor shall any person operate a vehicle upon a street or alley in such a way as to interfere with the efficient flow of traffic. 
(Ord. No. 757-97, § 1(292-1), 10-9-1997) 
Sec. 62-6. - Closing of streets. 
(a)  The director of the department of public safety or, in his/her absence, disability or inability to act, the mayor, and, in the event of his/her absence, disability or inability to act, then the chief of police of the municipality, is hereby authorized to provide, by regulation, for the closing of any street or portion thereof to motor vehicle traffic on any day or days whenever he/she finds that such closing is necessary for the preservation of the public safety, health or welfare. 
(b)  Any regulations promulgated by the director of the department of public safety and in accordance with subsection (a) of this section shall provide for the posting of proper warning signs of such closing on any street or portion thereof during the time the same is closed in pursuance thereof. 
(c)  Any violation of this regulation promulgated there under shall be punished by a fine not to exceed sixty-five dollars ($65.00). 
(d)  Any regulation adopted that mandates the closing of any street for a period greater than forty-eight (48) consecutive hours shall not become effective unless and until it has been submitted to and approved by the commissioner of the department of transportation. 
(Code 1992, § 291-2; Ord. No. 654, 3-19-1991; Ord. No. 2015-5, art. I, 6-23-2015) 
Sec. 62-7. - Drunk driving free school zones. 
(a)  Adoption of map. The Drunk Driving Free School Zones Map produced on or about October 1, 2000 by Key Engineers, the borough engineers, is hereby approved and adopted as an official finding and record of the location and areas within the municipality of property which is used for school purposes within the borough and which is owned by or leased to any elementary or secondary school on school land and of the areas on or within one thousand (1,000) feet of such school property. 
(b)  Original map and list to be on file; copies. The borough clerk is hereby directed to receive and to keep on file the original of the map approved and adopted pursuant to this section and the list of school crossings and to provide at a reasonable cost a true copy thereof to any person, agency or court which may from time to time request such a copy, along with a certification that such copy is a true copy of the map approved and adopted herein and kept on file. A true copy of such map and list and of this chapter shall be provided without cost to the county clerk and to the office of the county prosecutor. 
(c)  Map and list as evidence. It is understood that the map and list approved and adopted pursuant to this chapter was prepared and is intended to be used as evidence in prosecutions arising under the criminal and traffic laws of this state and that pursuant to state law, such map and list shall constitute prima facie evidence of the following: 
(1)  The location of elementary and secondary schools within the municipality; 
(2)  The boundaries of the real property which is owned by or leased to such schools or a school board; 
(3)  That such school property is and continues to be used for school purposes; 
(4)  The location and boundaries of areas which are on or within one thousand (1,000) feet of such school property; 
(5)  The location of all school crossings in the borough. 
(Ord. No. 807-00, §§ 3-5, 12-5-2000) 
Sec. 62-8. - One-way streets. 
    The following described streets or parts of streets are hereby designated as one-way streets in the direction indicated.

ARTICLE II. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate stopping, standing and parking, N.J.S.A. 39:4-197(3). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 62-41. - Regulations not exclusive. 
    The provisions of this article imposing a time limit on parking shall not relieve any person of the duty to observe other, more restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping or standing or parking of vehicles as set forth in N.J.S.A. 39:4-138, any other state statute or as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1992, § 291-16; Ord. No. 654, 3-19-1991) 
Sec. 62-42. - Emergency no parking. 
(a)  Upon the declaration of an emergency, there shall be no parking up in streets or sections of streets where temporary emergency no-parking signs are displayed. The chief of police or, in his/her absence, the ranking police officer is authorized to declare any emergency and to direct the posting of emergency no-parking signs when weather conditions, accidents, road construction, fire or public celebration dictate or require avoidance of hazards or other conditions which interfere with the free flow of traffic. Notification that emergency no-parking signs are being or will be posted shall be given to the operator or owner of any vehicle which has been parked prior to the posting of the signs. 
(b)  The effectiveness of this section is contingent upon the signs being erected as required by law. 
(c)  Any violation of this regulation promulgated there under shall be punished by a fine not to exceed sixty-five dollars ($65.00). 
(Code 1992, § 291-7; Ord. No. 654, 3-19-1991; Ord. No. 2015-5, art. I, 6-23-2015) 
Sec. 62-43. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-5, art. I, adopted June 23, 2015, repealed § 62-43 in its entirety. Former § 62-43 pertained to parking prohibited during snow emergencies and derived from the Code of 1992, § 291-8; and Ord. No. 654, adopted March 19, 1991.

    No person shall park a truck, tractor, trailer, semitrailer or omnibus having a registered gross weight in excess of eight thousand (8,000) pounds upon any street between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m.

Sec. 62-51. - Recreational vehicle parking prohibited during certain hours. 
    Parking of recreational vehicles and equipment, such as boats, travel trailers, campers, etc., is prohibited upon any street between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. Nothing herein, however, shall prohibit the parking of what is commonly called a "conversion van." 
(Code 1992, § 291-16; Ord. No. 654, 3-19-1991) 
Sec. 62-52. - Parking of roll-off dumpsters and containers restricted. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  Dumpster means a large trash receptacle that is designed to be hoisted and emptied into a truck. 
(2)  P.O.D. means a portable shed or storage container, storage unit, shed-like container or other similar structure that can or may be used for the storage of personal property of any kind and which is located for such purposes outside an enclosed building other than an accessory structure. 
(3)  Roll-off container means an open-top dumpster characterized by a rectangular footprint, utilizing wheels to facilitate rolling the dumpster in place. The container is designed to be transported by special roll-off trucks. 
(b)  Permit and authorization required. 
(1)  Prior to the placement of a dumpster, P.O.D./roll-off container on borough property, street right-of-way or on private property, the owner of the property, or the person contracting for use of such container shall apply for and receive a permit from the borough pursuant to the standards set forth herein. 
(2)  Application for the permit shall be made to the borough clerk, or designee, on a form provided by the borough. 
(3)  The application form shall require the applicant's full name, address and contact information, the person contracting for use of the container, where such person is other than the owner of the property for which the container is to be used, and owner of the property for which the container is to be used. 
(4)  The applicant must request a time period for placement of container. The requested time commences upon the container physically being situated on the real property. Permits granted for placement of a container on a street, right-of way or other public property shall be valid for a period of up to fourteen (14) days. The applicant may make an application for renewal of the permit at no extra charge. In no event may the requested time period exceed ninety (90) days. 
(5)  Each application must be signed by the borough clerk and the chief of police before it may be granted. 
(6)  A fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall accompany the permit application request. 
(c)  Placement. 
(1)  On public property: 
a.  Any container placed in a street or right-of-way shall be placed on the street in a legal parking space, not designated for handicap parking space, as designated by the borough, and shall be equipped with appropriate reflectors or other safety markings so that the container will not constitute a hazard to traffic. The borough police department, in the exercise of its discretion, may direct that additional markings, the location, or nature shall be supplemented or altered if the police determine such actions are necessary for the protection of the motoring public. 
b.  The police department may, at the discretion of the chief of police, order the immediate removal of a container in the interests of public health and safety or if the container will interfere with a community event or gathering. 
(2)  On private property: 
a.  No container may be placed on private property unless it complies with one (1) or more of the following provisions: 
1.  Such containers may be placed or maintained on a driveway or other suitably paved area for purposes of packing or unpacking goods and materials of the owner or occupant of the property in preparation for or subsequent to moving into or out of the property. 
2.  Such containers must be placed fifteen (15) feet from structure, on a driveway or other suitably paved area for purposes of storing the goods and materials of the owner or occupant of the property when necessary during renovation or rehabilitation of the structure. 
(d)  Other requirements. 
(1)  The container situated on residential property shall only be used for the storage of personal property, furniture and household items normally located on or in a residential dwelling or premises, or for the renovation or rehabilitation of a residential property. 
(2)  All storage containers shall: 
a.  Not have a height in excess of seven (7) feet nor a length of more than ten (10) feet nor a width of more than eight (8) feet. 
b.  All access doors shall be secured by locks. 
(e)  Violations, penalties and liability. 
(1)  The person contracting for use of the container and the owner of the property associated with its use shall be jointly responsible for compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof in municipal court, be punished for a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(3)  If a container is left in place at the expiration of the authorizing permit, the borough reserves the right to remove the container, upon providing notice to the owner. The owner shall be given up to five (5) days to remove the container. Such charge for removal and storage of the container shall be in addition to any fines that may otherwise be imposed pursuant to this section. 
(4)  A separate offense may be deemed committed for each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1992, § 291-17; Ord. No. 654, 3-19-1991; Ord. No. 2016-11 , Art. I, 10-18-2016)

    The following areas shall have prohibited parking during sporting events:
