Whenever an application for approval of a subdivision plat, site plan or conditional use includes a request for relief pursuant to this section of this chapter, the planning board shall grant or deny approval of the application within ninety-five (95) days after submission by a developer of a complete application to the administrative officer or within such further time as may be consented to by the applicant. Failure of the planning board to act within the period prescribed shall constitute approval of the application, and a certificate of the administrative officer as to the failure of the planning board to act shall be issued on request of the applicant, and it shall be sufficient, in lieu of the written endorsement or other evidence of approval herein required, and shall be so accepted by the county recording officer for purposes of filing subdivision plats. 
(c)  Whenever review or approval of the application by the county planning board is required by N.J.S.A. 40:27-6.3, in the case of a subdivision, or N.J.S.A. 40:27-6.6, in the case of a site plan, the municipal planning board shall condition any approval that it grants upon the timely receipt of a favorable report on the application by the county planning board or approval by the county planning board, by its failure to report thereon within the required time period. 
(Code 1992, § 208-29; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-176. - Exercise of powers of zoning board of adjustment. 
    The planning board of the borough shall exercise, and to the same extent and subject to the same restrictions, all the powers of the borough zoning board of adjustment pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40:55D-25(c). 
(Ord. No. 928-07, § I, 9-25-2007) 
State Law reference- General powers of planning board, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-25. 
Sec. 113-177. - Matters referred to planning board. 
    In the following circumstances, the particular matter under consideration affecting development shall be referred to the planning board and the planning board shall take the prescribed action: 
(1)  Prior to the adoption of an ordinance, regulation or resolution affecting the development or an amendment thereto, the planning board shall make and transmit to the commissioners, within thirty-five (35) days after referral, a report, including recommendations concerning the proposed measure. The commissioners, when considering such action, shall review the report of the planning board and may disapprove or change any such recommendation by a vote of a majority of the commissioners, or more, and shall record its reasons in its minutes for not following such recommendations. Failure of the planning board to transmit its report within the prescribed time period shall relieve the commissioners from the requirements of this section. 
(2)  Prior to any issuance of a construction permit for a commercial, industrial or multifamily dwelling use or any changes of such uses, the construction official shall refer the matter to the planning board for its recommendations. 
(3)  Prior to the issuance of a use and occupancy permit for any change in use, despite the fact that the proposed use may be a permitted use, the construction official shall refer the application to the planning board for its review and approval. 
(4)  Any requests for conditional uses which would affect traffic flow, the intensity of land utilization, an increase in off-street parking or surface drainage or soil conservation shall be approved or denied by the planning board in accordance with section 113-204(d)(4)b. 
(Code 1992, § 208-30; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Referral powers of planning board, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-26. 
Sec. 113-178. - Review committee. 
(a)  The planning board chairperson may, as a means of expediting the work of the board and for other purposes, appoint a review committee of three (3) board members for the following purposes: 
(1)  To review applications for minor subdivisions. 
(2)  To review applications for site plan review involving not more than one-fourth (1/4) acre. 
(3)  To review sign applications. 
(4)  To investigate or review such matters as may be directed by the chairperson. 
(5)  Upon forming committee opinion as to what it feels is the proper action, to report to the planning board as a whole for official action. 
(b)  The time periods specified by law shall not be extended to provide for the review committee to make such preliminary investigations since this procedure is intended to expedite the work of the planning board. 
(Code 1992, § 208-31; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-179. - Citizens' advisory committee. 
    After the appointment of a planning board, the mayor may appoint one (1) or more persons as a citizens' advisory committee to assist or collaborate with the planning board in its duties, but such person or persons shall have no power to vote or take other action required of the board. Such person or persons shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor. 
(Code 1992, § 208-32; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Citizens advisory committee, N.J.S.A. 40:55F-27. 
Sec. 113-180. - Applications to be available to environmental commission. 
    Whenever the environmental commission has prepared and submitted to the planning board an index of the natural resources of the municipality, the planning board shall make available to the environmental commission an informational copy of every application for development submitted to the planning board. Failure of the planning board to make such informational copy available to the environmental commission shall not invalidate any hearing or proceeding. 
(Code 1992, § 208-33; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, N.J.S.A. 40:55F-27. 
Secs. 113-181-113-198. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - ZONING BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Zoning board of adjustment, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-69 et seq. 

Sec. 113-199. - Board established. 
    The zoning board of adjustment, referred to throughout this chapter as the "board of adjustment," having been duly established according to law, is hereby continued pursuant to the provisions of P.L. 1975, chapter 291, section 56, zoning board of adjustment, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-69. 
(Code 1992, § 208-114; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979; Ord. No. 816-01, § II, 6-6-2001) 
Sec. 113-200. - Terms of office; vacancies; removal; membership; voting. 
(a)  The members having been duly appointed according to law shall each continue to fulfill the four-year appointment until expiration, reappointment or resignation, as applicable, and each reappointment or new appointment made by the commissioners shall be for the same four-year term. A member may after public hearing, if such member requests it, be removed by the commissioners for cause. A vacancy occurring other than at the end of a term shall be filled for the unexpired term only. No member shall hold any elective office or position under the borough. No member shall be permitted to act on any matter in which such member has, either directly or indirectly, any personal or financial interest. 
(b)  The members of the zoning board of adjustment shall be appointed in the manner consistent with N.J.S.A. 40:55D-69 et seq. and this Code. The terms of the members shall be determined so that, to the greatest practicable extent, the expiration of members terms shall be distributed evenly over the first four (4) years after their appointment, provided that the initial term of no member shall exceed four (4) years. All reappointments shall be for a period of four (4) years. There shall be permitted two (2) alternate members to the zoning board of adjustment designated "Alternate Number (1)" and "Alternate Number (2)". The terms of the alternate members shall be no more than two (2) years and shall be staggered initially so that the terms do not expire in the same year. Upon reappointment the term for each alternate shall be two (2) years. 
(Code 1992, § 208-115; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979; Ord. No. 816-01, § III, 6-6-2001) 
Sec. 113-201. - Organization. 
    The board of adjustment shall consist of seven (7) members. It shall elect a chairperson and vice chairperson from its members and select a secretary, who may or may not be a member of the board of adjustment or a borough employee. 
(Code 1992, § 208-116; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-202. - Powers; variances; referrals. 
(a)  The board of adjustment shall have the power to: 
(1)  Hear and decide appeals where it is alleged by an appellant that there is error in any order, requirement, decision or refusal made by the construction official, based on or made in the enforcement of those specific instances in this chapter where the construction official is required to act. 
(2)  Hear and decide, in accordance with zoning and other regulations of this chapter, requests for interpretation of the zoning map, the official map (if one exists) and other articles of this chapter. 
(3)  Where, by reason of exceptional narrowness, shallowness or shape of a specific property or by reason of exceptional topographic conditions or where the strict application of any regulation in this chapter would clearly result in peculiar and exceptional hardship upon a developer of such property, grant, upon an application or appeal relating to such property, a variance from such strict application of such regulation so as to relieve such hardship; provided, however, that no variance shall be granted under this section to allow a structure or use in a zoning district restricted against such structure or use unless by an affirmative vote of two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the full authorized membership of the board; and further provided that the request or appeal for such variance does not involve the review and approval by the planning board of a subdivision, site plan or conditional use in conjunction with which the planning board shall review a request for a variance pursuant to section 113-175. 
(b)  No variance or other relief may be granted under the terms of this section by any board, unless such variance or other relief can be granted without substantial detriment to the public good and will not substantially impair the intent and purposes of the master plan. 
(c)  An application under this section may be referred to any appropriate person or agency, including the planning board, so long as such referral shall not extend the time period in which the board of adjustment shall act. 
(Code 1992, § 208-117; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- General powers of zoning board, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-70 et seq. 
Sec. 113-203. - Employment of experts, staff and services. 
    The board of adjustment may employ or contract for and fix the compensation of legal counsel other than the borough solicitor and other experts and other staff and services as it shall seem necessary, but not exceeding, exclusive of gifts and grants, the amount appropriated by the commissioners for its use; and the commissioners shall make provision in the budget and appropriate funds for the expenses of the board of adjustment. 
(Code 1992, § 208-118; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-71. 
Sec. 113-204. - Appeals and applications. 
(a)  Appeals to the board of adjustment may be taken by any interested party which might be affected by a decision of the construction official in the course of such official's enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. Such appeal shall be taken within sixty-five (65) days by filing a notice of appeal with the construction official specifying the grounds for such appeal. The official from whom the appeal is taken shall transmit immediately to the board of adjustment all the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. 
(b)  An applicant may file an application with the board of adjustment under any of its powers without prior application to the construction official. 
(c)  If an application is filed with the board of adjustment, whether or not an appeal from a decision of the construction official is also taken, the applicant shall submit ten (10) copies of the completed application to the secretary of the board of adjustment. The time for the board's review shall not begin to run until the application is complete with the required fee. Unless the applicant is informed, in writing, by the secretary of the board within forty-five (45) days of the actual submission that it is not complete, such application shall be deemed complete as of the date it was actually submitted. 
(d)  Appeals, requests for interpretation, requests for a variance and other requests provided in N.J.S.A. 40:55D-70 shall be complete applications, consisting of at least the following as a minimum: 
(1)  Appeals, where it is alleged that an error has been made by the construction official or other borough agency, shall include: 
a.  The name, address and location, with a description, of the property with which the appeal is concerned. 
b.  A concise statement of the facts, including: 
1.  The article, section and subsection of this chapter under which application was made, including a copy thereof. 
2.  The applicant's understanding of the decision or ruling of the construction official or other borough agency which he received and from which appeal is taken. 
3.  A statement of the basis upon which the appeal is taken. 
c.  The harm, inconvenience or loss which the applicant, in his opinion, has suffered as result of the action from which appeal is taken. 
(2)  Interpretation of the regulations of this chapter, the official map (if one exists), the zoning map or the decision upon a special question, and the request for the same shall be in writing and shall include: 
a.  The name and address of the person making the request and a brief statement or reference to the particular text, map or decision which the applicant does not understand. 
b.  A brief statement of any peculiar need for such interpretation as it might affect a particular piece of property. 
(3)  Variance requests having to do with alleged hardship, a use in a zoning district restricted against such use or other matter which is not involved in the review of a site plan, subdivision or other type of development shall be granted or denied by the board of adjustment; where the request for a variance involves a site plan or subdivision or any type of development, the variance shall be granted or denied by the planning board; and in either case, applications shall include: 
a.  The name and address of the applicant and a description of property for which a variance is requested. 
b.  A simple map showing the lot in question, the street name and the names of all property owners within two hundred (200) feet of the lot in all directions and the owner of the lot in question if different from the applicant. 
c.  A statement of the particular section and article of the ordinance from which a variance is requested and the reasons why it should be granted. 
d.  A statement of the present zoning district in which the property is located and the use to which the property is now put. 
e.  A description of the improvement to be made on the property if the variance were granted. 
(4)  Conditional uses. 
a.  Conditional use requests may be submitted only for those instances and situations for which specific provision is made in this chapter and shall include: 
1.  The name and address of the applicant and a description of the property on which a conditional use would apply, if approved. 
2.  The specific article, section and subsection of this chapter which makes specific provision for the requested conditional use. 
3.  A concise statement of the use to which the property will be put if the conditional use were granted. 
b.  Conditional uses which would affect traffic flow, intensity of land utilization, increase in off-street parking, surface drainage or soil conservation, shall be approved or denied by the planning board; all others shall be approved or denied by the board of adjustment. 
(Code 1992, § 208-119; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Appeals and applications to board of adjustment, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-72. 
Sec. 113-205. - Public hearings. 
    The board of adjustment or planning board, as applicable, pursuant to the provisions of section 113-138(a), shall fix a reasonable time and place for public hearings on any appeal, request for variance or request for conditional use. The applicant shall give notice thereof in accordance with applicable subsections of section 113-140, subsections (a) and (b) in particular, and copies thereof shall be sent to the secretary of the board of adjustment or planning board (whichever is not holding the hearing) at least ten (10) days prior to the date thereof. 
(Code 1992, § 208-120; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-206. - Expiration of variance or conditional use. 
    Unless otherwise specified by the particular board granting the variance or conditional use, expiration shall automatically take place if the applicant fails to obtain a construction permit or use and occupancy permit, as applicable, within six (6) months from the date of authorization thereof. 
(Code 1992, § 208-121; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-207. - Appeals from decisions of board. 
    Any aggrieved party may appeal the decision of the board of adjustment or planning board, if applicable, in applying for a variance or conditional use or may appeal the decision of another borough agency, according to law. 
(Code 1992, § 208-122; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-208. - Standards for evaluating variance requests. 
(a)  The board of adjustment or planning board, as applicable, shall consider the following when hearing a request for a variance, in addition to such other factors as it may wish to consider in its deliberations, and the final decision shall contain evidence that the following and other factors have been considered: 
(1)  The shape of the property involved on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived was uniquely narrow or shallow compared with nearby properties which have been utilized according to the regulations of this chapter. 
(2)  Topographic conditions on the lot differ exceptionally from nearby improved lots. 
(3)  There are other unique conditions or situations which would make the strict application of any particular regulation of this chapter pointless, without relationship to the purposes thereof, and which would result in exceptional and undue hardship upon the owner or developer of the property, so long as such adverse condition has not been created by the applicant. 
(4)  The variance, if granted, would not alter the essential character of the zoning district in which the property is located, would not substantially or permanently impair the appropriate use or development of adjacent property or would not be detrimental to the public welfare. 
(5)  A variance, if granted, would represent the minimum relief that will achieve its purpose as well as be the least modification possible of the particular regulation of this chapter at issue. 
(6)  The variance shall be considered strictly on its own merits, without reference to similar situations or variances which may have been granted or denied previously. 
(b)  Either board may, if granting the variance, attach such conditions and safeguards as are necessary to ensure that the general purpose and intent of this chapter are complied with, which conditions may include but shall not be limited to harmonious design of buildings, plantings and their maintenance and the minimizing of noxious, offensive or hazardous elements. 
(Code 1992, § 208-123; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-209. - Standards for evaluating conditional use requests. 
(a)  The board of adjustment or planning board, as applicable, shall only in those instances where this chapter makes provision for conditional uses find, among other things: 
(1)  The requested conditional use would be consistent with the spirit, purpose and intent of this chapter as a whole or of any part thereof. 
(2)  If the particular board should determine that the granting of a conditional use would not be detrimental to the adjacent properties or to the surrounding neighborhood, the burden of proof shall be upon those opposing, if any, the granting of the conditional use and not upon the applicant. 
(b)  Where the board deems necessary, that suitable conditions and safeguards may be imposed as to the manner, extent or degree of the requested conditional use, if granted, and where specified herein, that the conditional use shall be deemed to be a use by right unless the particular location involved is determined by the board to be contrary to the purposes and intent of this chapter. 
(Code 1992, § 208-124; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-210. - Time for decision. 
(a)  The board of adjustment or planning board, as applicable, shall render its decision not later than one hundred twenty (120) days and ninety-five (95) days, respectively, for: 
(1)  An appeal taken from a decision of the construction official or zoning enforcement officer (not applicable to the planning board); or 
(2)  The submission of a complete application for a variance or conditional use. 
(b)  Failure of such board to render a decision within such specified time period or within such further time as may be consented to, in writing, by the applicant shall constitute a decision favorable to the applicant. 
(Code 1992, § 208-125; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Tine for decisions, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-73. 
Sec. 113-211. - Modification on appeal. 
    The board of adjustment, on appeal, may reverse or affirm, wholly or in part, or may modify the action, order, decision, requirement, interpretation or determination appealed from and to that end has all of the powers of the construction official or other borough agency from whom the appeal is taken. 
(Code 1992, § 208-126; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-212. - Stay of proceedings by appeal. 
    An appeal to the board of adjustment shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action in respect to which the decision appealed from was made, unless the construction official or other borough agency from whom the appeal is taken certifies to such board, after the notice of appeal shall have been filed with such official or agency, that by reason of facts stated in the certificate a stay would, in his or its opinion, cause imminent peril to life or property. In such case, proceedings shall not be stayed other than by an order of the superior court upon notice to the official or agency from whom the appeal is taken and on due cause shown. 
(Code 1992, § 208-127; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-213. - Additional powers. 
(a)  Whenever the board of adjustment is reviewing an application for a variance involving more than one (1) lot in a proposed subdivision, the application for subdivision review shall first be submitted to the board of adjustment for a ruling on the variance for more than one (1) lot, whose ruling shall supersede, with respect to such lots involved in the variance, any subsequent action by the planning board to which the board of adjustment shall refer the application for subdivision review. 
(b)  Whenever the board of adjustment receives an application for a variance on a proposed development for which site plan review and approval is simultaneously requested, the board of adjustment shall render its decision concerning the variance, which shall supersede subsequent action by the planning board to which the application for site plan review shall be referred. 
(c)  Whenever the board of adjustment refers a matter to the planning board before taking final action thereon, such reference shall not extend the length of time for the board of adjustment's action as prescribed by law, and whenever the planning board shall have made a recommendation regarding such matter authorized by this chapter to the board of adjustment, such recommendation may be rejected only by a majority vote of the full authorized membership of the board of adjustment. 
(Code 1992, § 208-128; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Secs. 113-214-113-234. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MASTER PLAN[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Master plan, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-28. 

Sec. 113-235. - Preparation; contents; policy statement. 
(a)  The planning board shall prepare and, after public hearing, adopt or amend a master plan or any component parts thereof to guide the use of lands within the borough in a manner which protects the public health and safety and promotes the general welfare. 
(b)  The master plan shall generally comprise a report or statement on land use and development proposals, with maps, diagrams and text, presenting, where appropriate, the following elements: meet the requirements of N.J.S.A. 40:55D-28. 
(1)  A statement of objectives, principle, assumptions, policies and standards upon which the constituent proposals for the physical, economic and social development of the borough are based. 
(2)  A land use plan element. 
a.  Taking into account and stating its relationship to the statement provided for in subsection (b)(1) of this section, and the other master plan elements and natural conditions, including but not necessarily limited to topography, soil conditions, water supply, drainage, floodplain areas, marshes and woodlands; 
b.  Showing the existing and proposed location, extent and intensity of development of land to be used in the future for varying types of agricultural, residential, commercial, industrial, recreational, educational and other public and private purposes; and 
c.  Including a statement of the standards of population density and development intensity recommended for the borough. 
(3)  A housing plan element, including but not limited to residential standards and proposals for construction and improvement of housing. 
(4)  A circulation plan element, showing the location and types of facilities for all modes of transportation required for the efficient movement of people and goods into, about and through the borough. 
(5)  A utility service plan element, to such extent appropriate, analyzing the need for and showing the future general location of water supply and distribution facilities, drainage and flood control facilities, sewerage and waste treatment, solid waste disposal and disposal and provision for other related utilities. 
(6)  A community facilities plan element, showing the location and type of educational or cultural facilities, historic sites, libraries, hospitals, firehouses, police stations and other related facilities, including their relation to the surrounding areas. 
(7)  A recreation plan element, showing a comprehensive system of areas and public sites for recreation. 
(8)  A conservation plan element, providing for the preservation, conservation and utilization of natural resources, including open space, water, trees, soil and other natural resources. 
(9)  Appendixes or separate reports containing the technical foundation for the master plan and its constituent elements where such cannot otherwise be made evident. 
(c)  The master plan and its plan elements may be divided into appropriate subsections and shall include a specific policy statement indicating the relationship of the proposed development of the borough to: 
(1)  The master plans of contiguous municipalities; 
(2)  The master plan of the county; and 
(3)  Any comprehensive guide plan of the state. 
(Code 1992, § 208-34; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-236. - Periodic reexamination; report. 
    The commissioners shall, at least every six (6) years, provide for a general reexamination of the master plan and this development chapter by the planning board, which board shall prepare a report on the findings of such reexamination, a copy of which shall be sent to the county planning board and to the municipal clerks of each adjoining municipality. The six-year period shall commence with the adoption or termination of the last general reexamination of such plan and regulations; the first such reexamination shall be completed within six (6) years after August 1, 1976. The borough planning board's report shall state: 
(1)  The major problems and objectives relating to land development in the borough at the time of such adoption, last revision or reexamination. 
(2)  The extent to which there have been reductions or increases in such problems and objectives subsequent to such date. 
(3)  The extent to which there have been significant changes in the assumptions, policies and objectives forming the basis for such plan or regulations as last reviewed or amended. Particular regard should be given to density and distribution of population and land uses, housing conditions, circulation, conservation of natural resources and change in state, county or borough policies and objectives. 
(4)  The specific changes recommended for such plan or regulations, if any, including underlying objectives, policies and standards, or whether a new plan or regulations should be prepared. 
(Code 1992, § 208-35; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Periodic examination of master plan and regulations, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-89 et seq. 
Sec. 113-237. - Continuity. 
    The borough master plan is a continuing process and, despite periodic reexamination or updating as required by law, the basic elements and policies contained therein shall remain in effect until they are specifically revised or deleted by the planning board. 
(Code 1992, § 208-36; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Secs. 113-238-113-267. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFICIAL MAP[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Official map, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-32 et seq. 

Sec. 113-268. - Map adopted; use. 
(a)  There is hereby adopted, pursuant to the provisions of article 5 of the Municipal Land Use Law (N.J.S.A. 40:55D-32 et seq.), a document known as the "Official Map of Audubon." 
(b)  Such official map shall be deemed conclusive with respect to the location and width of streets and public drainageways and the location and extent of flood-control basins and public areas, whether or not such streets, ways, basins and areas are improved or unimproved or are in actual physical existence. 
(c)  Upon receiving an application for development, the borough may reserve for future use the aforesaid streets, ways, basins and areas in the manner provided in section 113-298. 
(Code 1992, § 208-37; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-269. - Issuance of building permits. 
(a)  For purposes of preserving the integrity of the official map, no permit shall be issued for any building or other structure in the bed of any street or public drainageway, flood-control basin or public area reserved pursuant to section 113-268, as shown on the official map or shown on a plat filed pursuant to this chapter before adoption of an official map, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Whenever one (1) or more parcels of land, upon which is located the bed of a mapped street or public drainageway, flood-control basin or public area reserved as provided herein, cannot yield a reasonable return to the owner unless a building is permitted, the board of adjustment may, in a specific case, by an affirmative vote of a majority of the fully authorized membership of such board, direct issuance of a construction permit for such building or structure in the bed of such mapped street or public drainageway, flood-control basin or public area reserved as provided herein, which will as little as possible increase the cost of opening such street or tend to cause minimum change in the official map, and the board may impose reasonable requirements as a condition of granting the permit so as to promote the health, morals, safety and general welfare of the public. 
(Code 1992, § 208-38; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-34. 
Sec. 113-270. - Building lots to abut street. 
(a)  No construction permit for the erection of a building or other structure shall be issued unless the lot abuts a street giving access thereto. Such street shall have a duly placed location on the official map or shall be: 
(1)  An existing state, county or borough street or highway; 
(2)  A street shown upon a plat approved by the planning board; or 
(3)  A street on a plat duly filed in the office of the county recording officer prior to passage of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived or any prior ordinance which required prior approval of plats by the commissioners. 
(b)  Before any permit shall be issued, such street shall have been certified to be suitable improved to the satisfaction of the commissioners, or such improvement assured by means of a performance guaranty, as provided in section 113-302. 
(Code 1992, § 208-39; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Building lot adjacent to street, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-35. 
Sec. 113-271. - Variances. 
    Where the enforcement of the section 113-270 would entail practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship or where the circumstances of the case do not require the building or other structure to be related to a street, the board of adjustment may, upon application or appeal, vary the application of section 113-270 and direct the issuance of a construction permit, subject to conditions that will provide adequate access for firefighting equipment, ambulances and other emergency vehicles. 
(Code 1992, § 208-40; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Appeals, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-36. 
Secs. 113-272-113-290. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SUBDIVISION REVIEW AND APPROVAL[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Subdivision and site plan review and approval, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-37 et seq.; required provisions of ordinances, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-38; discretionary provisions of subdivision ordinances, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-49, 40:55D-50. 

Sec. 113-291. - Authority to approve plats; referral to county. 
(a)  Pursuant to the provisions of N.J.S.A. 40:55D-37, the borough planning board is directed and required to review and approve subdivisions in required stages by resolution and to approve subdivision plats for recording by resolution as a condition for the filing thereof with the county recording officer. 
(b)  Conditions requiring county planning board review. 
(1)  Each complete application for subdivision approval shall be submitted to the county planning board by the borough planning board secretary where any one (1) of the following conditions prevails: 
a.  The property abuts an existing county road. 
b.  The property will be adjacent to a proposed road shown on the county master plan or county official map. 
c.  The property abuts county-owned land. 
d.  The property is situated within two hundred (200) feet of any borough line. 
e.  Drainage flows to or upon a county road or county property. 
(2)  The borough planning board shall condition any approval that it grants involving those properties meeting any condition set forth in subsection (1) of this section upon the timely receipt of a favorable report by the county planning board or its approval by failure to report within the time period prescribed by law. 
(Code 1992, § 208-41; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-292. - Application submission procedures. 
(a)  The applicant shall submit fifteen (15) copies of a major subdivision, and twelve (12) copies of a minor subdivision, each with application forms, to the borough planning board secretary, who shall: 
(1)  Record the date of receipt of the required copies and refer payment of the required fee to the borough clerk. 
(2)  Refer one (1) copy to each of the members of the planning board within five (5) days from date of receipt, if the application is complete as verified by the secretary, and the board members shall verify the application as being for a major or minor subdivision, as defined herein. If the application is complete, and is duly verified as major or minor, the planning board secretary shall notify the applicant that the application is complete; but, if the application is determined to be incomplete by reason of improper classification as to major or minor or otherwise, the planning board secretary shall so notify the applicant within forty-five (45) days from the date of receipt of the complete application, and failure to so notify the applicant within such time period shall automatically make the application complete as of the date of actual submission. 
(b)  A complete application shall be in the hands of the planning board secretary at least fourteen (14) days prior to the next regularly scheduled meeting of the planning board; any application submitted less than fourteen (14) days prior to such meeting may be returned to the applicant for submission subsequently at the proper time or may be held until the proper time, at the applicant's option. 
(Code 1992, § 208-42; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-293. - Application requirements. 
(a)  Checklist and completeness procedures. There is adopted by ordinance an official submission checklist which specifies the documents and information that must accompany all applications for minor subdivisions, preliminary and final major subdivisions, minor site plans, preliminary and final major site plans, variances, and general development plans under this chapter. No application shall be deemed complete under N.J.S.A. 40:55D-10.3 unless the requirements have been met or waived by the land use board following a waiver request by the applicant. The checklist specifies the information that must be submitted for each type of application to be deemed complete. The checklist is available and on file at the Audubon Borough Hall. The single updated borough land development application form, revised November 2010, and attached hereto, shall replace the separate applications for conditional uses, variances, site plans, and subdivisions. A separate application for sign permit shall be retained. 
(b)  The required fee, in accordance with the schedule of fees of the borough, adopted by ordinance and amended by resolution from time to time by the commissioners, current copies of which are maintained in the office of the borough clerk. 
(c)  A subdivision plan, on which the following shall be set forth: 
(1)  A scale where one (1) inch equals not more forty (40) feet. If the property is of a size that would not permit the entire tract on one sheet, then a scale of one (1) inch equals one hundred (100) feet may be utilized for the overall site plan/subdivision sheet, with separate sheets at a larger scale showing match lines. 
(2)  A location map showing all road intersections within three hundred (300) feet and a north point. 
(3)  All structures, wooded areas and other topography, with existing contours at two-foot intervals, except that five-foot intervals where slopes exceed fifteen percent (15%) may be used on the site. 
(4)  All lot lines, with owners of all lots within two hundred (200) feet of the proposed subdivision. 
(5)  Streets, easements, watercourses and rights-of-way, both existing and proposed. 
(6)  Complete utility and drainage plans, showing the location and method of disposal of stormwater at the outfall. 
(7)  Any extension of off-site improvements necessitated by the proposed development. 
(8)  A soil erosion and sedimentation control plan, in such detail as the extent of disturbance to the natural surface conditions. 
(Code 1992, § 208-43; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979; Ord. No. 980-2010, §§ I, III, IV, 12-28-2010) 
Sec. 113-294. - Distribution of complete application. 
    The planning board secretary shall distribute the complete application, including all plans and pertinent exhibits and information, as follows, in addition to the planning board members: 
(1)  The borough engineer. 
(2)  The borough department of public works. 
(3)  The chief of police. 
(4)  The chief of the fire department. 
(5)  The planning board's attorney. 
(6)  Such other public bodies or offices as would be appropriate for particular reasons. 
(Code 1992, § 208-44; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-295. - Review and approval procedures. 
(a)  Public notice as required by N.J.S.A. 40:55D-12 shall be given by the applicant for all applications for development involving any request for: 
(1)  A variance. 
(2)  A conditional use approval. 
(3)  Approval of minor site plan, minor subdivision, preliminary major subdivision and preliminary major site plan. 
(4)  Approval of a planned development. 
(b)  Upon submission to the planning board secretary of a complete application for: 
(1)  A minor subdivision, the planning board may waive notice and public hearing, if the board finds that the application conforms to the definition of minor subdivision, in section 113-2, and approve the subdivision; subject, however, to such conditions as the board may prescribe concerning applicable requirements contained herein: 
a.  The planning board shall grant or deny approval of the minor subdivision within forty-five (45) days of the submission of a complete application to the planning board secretary or within such further time as may be consented to, in writing, by the applicant. 
b.  Failure of the planning board to act within the time prescribed shall constitute minor subdivision approval, and a certificate of the planning board secretary as to the planning board's failure to act shall be issued upon request of the applicant, which certificate shall be sufficient in lieu of written endorsement or other evidence of approval and shall be so accepted by the county recording officer for purposes of filing subdivision plats. 
c.  Whenever review of the county planning board is required according to conditions prescribed herein, any approval of the minor subdivision shall be conditioned upon approval by the county planning board, either by its favorable report or its failure to act, as described herein. 
d.  Approval of minor subdivision shall expire one hundred ninety (190) days from the date of approval, unless within that period of time a plat in conformity with the law is filed by the developer. 
e.  The zoning requirements applicable to the minor subdivision and the terms or conditions upon which the minor subdivision was approved shall not be changed for a period of two (2) years after date of such approval, provided that the minor subdivision shall have been duly recorded with the county recording officer. 
(2)  Approval of preliminary plan of a major subdivision, the review committee shall be given the application within five (5) days, and if such committee finds that the application is incomplete in any way, the planning board secretary shall notify the developer, within forty-five (45) days of submission of the application to said secretary, that his application is not complete, or the application shall be deemed to be properly submitted and complete. 
a.  If the planning board requires substantial amendment in the layout proposed that has been the subject of a public hearing, an amended application shall be resubmitted and acted upon as if it were the original submission. 
b.  If the application, and the subdivision which is a part thereof, complies with all of the provisions of this chapter, the planning board shall grant preliminary approval. 
c.  Upon the submission to the planning board secretary of a complete application for a subdivision of not more than ten (10) lots, the planning board shall grant or deny preliminary approval within forty-five (45) days of the date of such submission or within such further time as may be consented to by the developer. 
d.  Upon the submission of a complete application to the planning board secretary for more than ten (10) lots, the planning board shall grant or deny preliminary approval within ninety-five (95) days of the date of such submission or within such further time as may be consented to by the developer. 
e.  If the planning board shall fail to act within the above respective time periods, preliminary approval of the subdivision shall be considered granted. 
f.  Effect of preliminary approval. Preliminary approval of a major subdivision, pursuant to the above, shall confer upon the applicant the following rights for a three-year period from the date of preliminary approval: 
1.  The general terms and conditions of preliminary approval, including zoning applicable to the tract, layout and design standards for streets, curbs and sidewalks and off-tract requirements shall not be changed. 
2.  The applicant may submit for final approval before the expiration date of preliminary approval. 
3.  The applicant may apply for, and the planning board may grant, extensions of such preliminary approval for additional periods of at least one (1) year, but not to exceed a total of two (2) years, provided that if the design standards have been revised, the revised standards shall prevail. 
(3)  Approval of a final plan of a major subdivision, the planning board shall grant such approval if the detailed drawings, specifications and estimates of the application for final approval conform to the standards established herein, the conditions of preliminary approval and other standards prescribed by law: 
a.  Final approval shall be granted or denied within forty-five (45) days after submission for such approval, unless extended with the consent of the applicant, and failure of the planning board to act within this prescribed period shall constitute final approval of the major subdivision, if acceptable guaranties required herein are furnished by the developer, in which case the planning board secretary shall issue a certificate as to the failure of the planning board to act, and it shall be sufficient in lieu of written endorsement or other evidence of approval herein required and shall be acceptable to the county recording officer for filing of subdivision plats. 
b.  Whenever review by the county planning board is required, any approval given a major subdivision shall be conditioned upon the timely receipt of a favorable report from the county planning board or approval by its failure to act within the prescribed time period. 
(Code 1992, § 208-45; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979; Ord. No. 733, 9-19-1995) 
State Law reference- Effect of preliminary plat approval, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-49; final approval of major subdivisions, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-50. 
Sec. 113-296. - Exceptions. 
    The planning board, when acting upon applications for preliminary approval of major subdivisions or for minor subdivisions, shall have the power to grant such exceptions from the requirements for subdivision approval as may be reasonable and within the general purpose and intent of the provisions herein for subdivision review and approval, if the literal enforcement of one (1) or more provisions of this chapter is impracticable or will exact undue hardship because of peculiar conditions pertaining to the land in question. 
(Code 1992, § 208-46; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-297. - Simultaneous consideration of subdivisions; site plans and conditional uses. 
    The planning board shall have the power, where a site plan or conditional use might be involved in a particular subdivision, to act simultaneously on the subdivision, site plan and conditional use, without the applicant having to prepare and submit a separate application for the site plan or conditional use; and where a site plan or conditional use is to be considered simultaneously with a subdivision, any notice for a required public hearing shall contain reference to the site plan and/or conditional use, as well as to the subdivision. 
(Code 1992, § 208-47; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-298. - Reservation of public areas. 
(a)  If the master plan or the official map provides for the reservation of designated streets, public drainageways, flood-control basins or public areas within the proposed development, before approving a subdivision or site plan the planning board may further require that such streets, ways, basins or areas be shown on the plat in locations and sizes suitable to their intended uses. The planning board may reserve the location and extent of such streets, ways, basins or areas shown on the plat for a period of one (1) year after the approval of the final plat or within such further time as may be agreed to by the developer. Unless during such period or extension thereof the municipality shall have entered into a contract to purchase or institute condemnation proceedings according to law for the fee or a lesser interest in the land comprising such streets, ways, basins or areas, the developer shall not be bound by such reservations shown on the plat and may proceed to use such land for private use in accordance with applicable development regulations. The provisions of this section shall not apply to streets and roads, flood-control basins or public drainageways necessitated by the subdivision or land development and required for final approval. 
(b)  The developer shall be entitled to just compensation for actual loss found to be caused by such temporary reservation and deprivation of use. In such instance, unless a lesser amount has previously been mutually agreed upon, just compensation shall be deemed to be the fair market value of an option to purchase the land reserved for the period of reservation, provided that determination of such fair market value shall include, but not be limited to consideration of the real property taxes apportioned to the land reserved and prorated for the period of reservation. The developer shall be compensated for the reasonable increased cost of legal, engineering or other professional services incurred in connection with obtaining subdivision approval or site plan approval, as the case may be, caused by the reservation. The municipality shall provide by ordinance for a procedure for the payment of all compensation payable under this section. 
(Code 1992, § 208-48; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-299. - Developer contributions for certain improvements. 
    The governing body may by ordinance adopt regulations requiring a developer, as a condition for approval of a subdivision or site plan, to pay his pro rata share of the cost of providing only reasonable and necessary street improvements and water, sewerage and drainage facilities, and easements therefor, located outside the property limits of the subdivision or development but necessitated or required by the construction or improvements within such subdivision or development. Such regulations shall be based on circulation and comprehensive utility service plans pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40:55D-28 and shall establish fair and reasonable standards to determine the proportionate or pro rata amount of the cost of such facilities that shall be borne by each developer or owner within a related and common area, which standards shall not be altered subsequent to preliminary approval. Where a developer pays the amount determined as his pro rata share under protest, he shall institute legal action within one (1) year of such payment in order to preserve the right to a judicial determination as to the fairness and reasonableness of such amount. 
(Code 1992, § 208-49; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Contribution for off-tract water, sewer, drainage, and street improvements, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-42. 
Sec. 113-300. - Open space preservation and maintenance. 
(a)  An ordinance pursuant to this article permitting planned unit development, planned unit residential development or residential development or residential cluster may provide that the municipality or other governmental agency may, at any time and from time to time, accept the dedication of land or any interest therein for public use and maintenance, but the ordinance shall not require, as a condition of the approval of a planned development, that land proposed to be set aside for common open space be dedicated or made available to public use. 
(b)  An ordinance pursuant to this article providing for planned unit development, planned unit residential development or residential cluster shall require that the developer provide for an organization for the ownership and maintenance of any open space for the benefit of owners or residents of the development, if said open space is not dedicated to the municipality or other governmental agency. Such organization shall not be dissolved and shall not dispose of any open space by sale or otherwise, except to an organization conceived and established to own and maintain the open space for the benefit of such development, and thereafter such organization shall not be dissolved or dispose of any of its open space without first offering to dedicate the same to the municipality or municipalities wherein the land is located. 
(c)  In the event that such organization shall fail to maintain the open space in reasonable order and condition, the municipal body or officer designated by ordinance to administer this section may serve written notice upon such organization or upon the owners of the development setting forth the manner in which the organization has failed to maintain the open space in reasonable condition, and said notice shall include a demand that such deficiencies of maintenance be cured within thirty-five (35) days thereof and shall state the date and place of a hearing thereon, which shall be held within fifteen (15) days of the notice. At such hearing, the designated municipal body or officer, as the case may be, may modify the terms of the original notice as to deficiencies and may give a reasonable extension of time, not to exceed sixty-five (65) days, within which they shall be cured. If the deficiencies set forth in the original notice or in the modification thereof shall not be cured within said thirty-five (35) days or any permitted extension thereof, the municipality, in order to preserve the open space and maintain the same for a period of one (1) year, may enter upon and maintain such land. Said entry and maintenance shall not vest in the public any rights to use the open space, except when the same is voluntarily dedicated to the public by the owners. Before the expiration of said year, the designated municipal body or officer, as the case may be, shall, upon its or his initiative or upon the request of the organization theretofore responsible for the maintenance of the open space, call a public hearing upon fifteen (15) days' written notice to such organization and to the owners of the development to be held by such municipal body or officer, at which hearing such organization and the owners of the development shall show cause why such maintenance by the municipality shall not, at the election of the municipality, continue for a succeeding year. If the designated municipal body or officer, as the case may be, shall determine that such organization is ready and able to maintain said open space in reasonable condition, the municipality shall cease to maintain said open space at the end of said year. If the municipal body or officer, as the case may be, shall determine such organization is not ready and able to maintain said open space in a reasonable condition, the municipality may, in its discretion, continue to maintain said open space during the next succeeding year, subject to a similar hearing and determination, in each year thereafter. The decision of the municipal body or officer in any such case shall constitute a final administrative decision subject to judicial review. If a municipal body or officer is not designated by ordinance to administer this section, the governing body shall have the same powers and be subject to the same restrictions as provided in this section. 
(d)  The cost of such maintenance by the municipality shall be assessed pro rata against the properties within the development that have a right of enjoyment of the open space in accordance with their assessed value at the time of imposition of the lien and shall become a lien and tax on said properties and be added to and be a part of the taxes to be levied and assessed thereon and enforced and collected with interest by the same officers and in the same manner as other taxes. 
(Code 1992, § 208-50; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-43. 
Sec. 113-301. - Required findings for planned developments. 
    Every ordinance pursuant to this article that provides for planned developments shall require that prior to approval of such planned developments, the planning board shall find the following facts and conclusions: 
(1)  That departures by the proposed development from zoning regulations otherwise applicable to the subject property conform to the zoning ordinance standards pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40:55D-65(c). 
(2)  That the proposals for maintenance and conservation of the common open space are reliable, and the amount, location and purpose of the common open space are adequate. 
(3)  That provision through the physical design of the proposed development for public services, control over vehicular and pedestrian traffic and the amenities of light and air and recreation and visual enjoyment are adequate. 
(4)  That the proposed planned development will not have an unreasonable adverse impact upon the area in which it is proposed to be established. 
(5)  In the case of a proposed development which contemplates construction over a period of years, that the terms and conditions intended to protect the interests of the public and of the residents, occupants and owners of the proposed development in the total completion of the development are adequate. 
(Code 1992, § 208-51; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Planned developments, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-45 et seq. 
Sec. 113-302. - Required guaranties. 
(a)  Before the recording of final subdivision plats or as a condition of the issuance of a zoning permit pursuant to zoning requirements herein of certain physical improvements, the planning board shall require, and shall accept subject to the approval of the borough solicitor, the following for the purpose of assuring the proper installation and maintenance of required improvements: 
(1)  The furnishing of a performance guaranty, approved by the borough solicitor, in favor of the borough, in an amount not to exceed one hundred twenty percent (120%) of the estimated cost of required improvements, as verified by the borough engineer, which improvements shall include but not be limited to streets, grading, pavement, gutters, curbs, sidewalks, street lighting, and surveyor's monuments, as shown on the final plat as required by the Map Filing Law (N.J.S.A. 46:23-9.9 et seq.), as well as water mains, including laterals to the street rights-of-way lines, culverts, storm sewers, sanitary sewers, all drainage structures and erosion control and sedimentation control devices, and including such other on-site improvements as may be required by the site plan or zoning requirements herein. 
(2)  The posting with the commissioners of a maintenance guaranty for a period not to exceed two (2) years after final acceptance of any particular improvement, in an amount not to exceed fifteen percent (15%) of the actual cost of the improvement, as verified by the borough engineer; provided, however, that in the event that another governmental agency other than the borough or a public utility company will automatically own utility lines once satisfactorily installed or that the streets are covered by a performance or maintenance guaranty to the other governmental agency, no performance or maintenance guaranty shall be required by the borough for such utilities and improvements. 
(b)  The amount of any performance guaranty may be reduced by the commissioners by resolution as portions of the improvements have been certified by the borough engineer to have been satisfactorily completed, and the time allowed for installation of the improvements, for which the performance guaranty has been provided, may be extended by the commissioners by resolution. 
(c)  If the required improvements are not completed or corrected in accordance with the performance guaranty, the obligor and surety shall be liable thereon to the borough for the reasonable cost of the improvements not completed or corrected, and the borough may, either prior to or after the receipt of the proceeds thereof, complete such improvements or the correction thereof, as applicable. Such completion or correction of improvements shall be subject to the public bidding requirements of the Local Public Contracts Law (N.J.S.A. 40A:11-1 et seq.). 
(d)  When all of the required improvements have been completed, in the opinion of the developer, the obligor shall notify the commissioners, by certified mail, addressed in care of the borough clerk, and shall send a copy thereof to the borough engineer. Thereupon, the borough engineer shall inspect all of the improvements and shall file a detailed report, in writing, to the commissioners, indicating his recommendation of approval, partial approval or rejection of the improvements, with a statement of reasons for such rejection; if partial approval is recommended, he shall include his estimate of the cost of the improvements rejected. A copy of the borough engineer's report shall be furnished to the developer. 
(e)  If any parts of the required improvements are rejected by the commissioners, they may require the obligor to complete such improvements, and upon completion the same procedure of notification as set forth in subsection (d) of this section shall be followed. 
(f)  Nothing herein shall be construed to limit the right of the obligor to contest by legal proceedings any determination by the commissioners or opinion of the borough engineer. 
(g)  The obligor shall reimburse the borough for all reasonable inspection fees paid to the borough engineer for the foregoing inspection of improvements, which schedule of fees shall be made a part of the guaranty or surety documents before approval by the borough solicitor. 
(h)  The commissioners shall either approve, partially approve or reject the improvements and notify the obligor within sixty-five (65) days. 
(Code 1992, § 208-52; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Guarantees, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-53 et seq. 
Sec. 113-303. - Recording and filing requirements. 
(a)  Final approval of a major subdivision shall expire ninety-five (95) days from the date of signing of the plat, unless within such period the plat shall have been duly filed by the developer with the county recording officer; however, the planning board may for good cause shown extend the period for recording for an additional period not to exceed one hundred ninety (190) days from the date of the signing of the plat. 
(b)  No subdivision plat shall be submitted to the county recording officer for filing until it has been approved by the planning board as indicated on the instrument by the signature of the chairperson and secretary of the planning board or a certificate has been issued in accordance with section 113-295(b)(1), for minor subdivisions, and 113-295(b)(3), for major subdivisions. Neither the issuance of a certificate by the planning board secretary, nor the signature of the chairperson and secretary of the planning board shall be affixed until the developer has posted the guaranties pursuant to section 113-302; and, if the county recording officer should record any plat without at least one (1) of such methods of approval, such recording shall be deemed null and void, and, upon request of the borough, the plat shall be expunged from the official records. 
(c)  A certificate of recording, blank copies of which are available from the secretary of the planning board, shall be duly signed by the county recording officer and returned by the developer to the secretary of the planning board within seven (7) days of the filing of any plat, as evidence of official recording thereof. 
(Code 1992, § 208-53; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, N.J.S.A. 40-55D-54. 
Sec. 113-304. - Sale or transfer prior to final approval unlawful; violations and penalties. 
    If, before final subdivision approval has been granted, any person transfers or sells or agrees to transfer or sell, except pursuant to an agreement expressly conditioned on final subdivision approval, as owner or agent any land which forms a part of a subdivision for which borough approval is required by this chapter, pursuant to the Municipal Land Use Law (N.J.S.A. 40:55D-1 et seq.) such person shall be subject to a penalty not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), and each lot disposition so made may be deemed a separate violation. In addition to the foregoing, the borough may institute and maintain a civil action: 
(1)  For injunctive relief. 
(2)  To set aside and invalidate any conveyance made pursuant to such a contract of sale, if a certificate of compliance has not been issued in accordance with section 113-305. In any such action, the transferee, purchaser or grantee shall be entitled to a lien upon the parties of the land that remains in possession of the developer to secure the return of all deposits and other expenses as prescribed by law. Any such action must be brought within two (2) years after the date of recording of the instrument of transfer, sale or conveyance of such land or within six (6) years if unrecorded. 
(Code 1992, § 208-54; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-55. 
Sec. 113-305. - Certificate of approval. 
(a)  The prospective purchaser, prospective mortgagee or any other person interested in any land which forms a part of a subdivision or which formed part of such a subdivision three (3) years preceding the effective date of the Municipal Land Use Law (N.J.S.A. 40:55D-1 et seq.) (July 1, 1976) may apply, in writing, to the planning board secretary, in this instance, for the issuance of a certificate as to whether or not such subdivision has been approved by the planning board. Such application shall contain a plan showing the location and street address of the land to be covered by the certificate and the name of the owner thereof. 
(b)  The planning board secretary shall make and issue such certificate within fifteen (15) days after the receipt of such written application and the fee which must accompany such application, in accordance with the borough schedule of fees adopted and amended from time to time by the commissioners. The planning board secretary shall keep a duplicate copy of each certificate, consecutively numbered with notation of the fee paid, in a binder as a permanent record of his or her office. 
(c)  Each such certificate shall be designated a certificate as to approval of subdivision of land, and shall certify: 
(1)  The existence of the borough planning board and the number of this chapter controlling subdivisions under the Municipal Land Use Law (N.J.S.A. 40:55D-1 et seq.). 
(2)  Whether the subdivision, as it relates to the land shown in said application, has been approved by the planning board, with the date thereof, including any extensions and terms, showing that subdivision of which the lands are a part is a validly existing subdivision or, if the subdivision predates the Municipal Land Use Law's effective date by more than three (3) years, with no record of dates of planning board approval available to the planning board secretary, and such subdivision duly appears on the tax duplicate of the borough, this fact shall be stated in the certificate as the best available document as to the legality of the subdivision in question. 
(d)  The administrative officer shall be entitled to demand and receive for such certificate issued by him a reasonable fee not in excess of those provided in N.J.S.A. 54:5-14 and 54:5-15. The fees so collected by such official shall be paid by him to the municipality. 
(Code 1992, § 208-55; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Certificates of approval, N.J.S.A. 40-55D-56. 
Sec. 113-306. - Condominiums and cooperative structures and uses. 
    This chapter and all development regulations pursuant thereto shall be construed and applied with reference to the nature and use of condominiums or cooperative structures or uses without regard to the form of ownership. No development regulation shall establish any requirement concerning the use, location, placement or construction of buildings or other improvements for condominiums or cooperative structures or uses unless such requirement shall be equally applicable to all buildings and improvements of the same kind not then or thereafter under the condominium or cooperative corporate form of ownership. No approval pursuant to this chapter shall be required as a condition precedent to the recording of a condominium master deed or the sale of any unit therein, unless such approval shall also be required for the use or development of the lands described in the master deed in the same manner had such lands not been under the condominium form of ownership. 
(Code 1992, § 208-56; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, N.J.S.A. 40:55D-58. 
Sec. 113-307. - Valuation, assessment and taxation of land. 
    With regard to valuation, assessment and taxation of land in various stages of approval as a subdivision or site plan, the provisions of N.J.S.A. 40:55D-59 shall prevail. 
(Code 1992, § 208-57; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-308. - Authority of zoning board of adjustment to grant subdivision approval. 
    The zoning board of adjustment shall have the power to grant, to the same extent and subject to the same restrictions as the planning board, subdivision approval whenever the board of adjustment is reviewing an application for approval of a variance; provided, however, that: 
(1)  Such subdivision application shall be referred by the board of adjustment to the planning board for its review and recommendations; 
(2)  Such reference to the planning board shall not extend the specified time within which the board of adjustment shall act; and 
(3)  Such action by the board of adjustment shall require an affirmative vote of at least two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the full authorized membership of such board. 
(Code 1992, § 208-58; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-309. - Effect of certificate of approval. 
(a)  Any person who shall acquire for a valuable consideration an interest in the lands covered by any such certificate of approval of a subdivision in reliance upon the information therein contained shall hold such interest free of any right, remedy or action which could be prosecuted or maintained by the municipality pursuant to the provisions of N.J.S.A. 40:55D-55. 
(b)  If the administrative officer designated to issue any such certificate fails to issue the same within fifteen (15) days after receipt of an application and the fees therefor, any person acquiring an interest in the lands described in such application shall hold such interest free of any right, remedy or action which could be prosecuted or maintained by the municipality pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40:55D-55. 
(c)  Any such application addressed to the clerk of the municipality shall be deemed to be addressed to the proper designated officer, and the municipality shall be bound thereby to the same extent as though the same was addressed to the designated official. 
(Code 1992, § 208-59; Ord. No. 455, 4-10-1979) 
Sec. 113-310. - Subdivision design standards. 
(a)  Streets (major subdivisions only). 
(1)  Location. A proposed street shall not be centered upon a boundary line of a tract to be subdivided, unless the adjoining owner shall enter into joint or simultaneous application for subdivision of his land, and the location of a proposed street abutting and parallel to a boundary line of a tract to be subdivided will be discouraged. 
(2)  Alignment. 
a.  Relative to surrounding residential streets. Where a dedicated residential street dead-ends at the property line of a proposed subdivision, whether such street is in this or an adjoining municipality, the proposed subdivision shall make provision for extension of such dead-end street for a distance of at least one (1) lot depth. 
b.  Relative to surrounding collector streets. A proposed subdivision shall make provision, by means of a collector street, for continuation of the width, gradient, general alignment and direction of traffic flow of a collector street which dead-ends at a common property line or is proposed in the adopted master plan. 
c.  Sight distance. A minimum sight distance at the centerline and at a driver's eyesight of four (4) feet shall be provided as follows with respect to horizontal and vertical alignment: 
1.  Major streets: in accordance with the minimum standards of the state department of transportation, but in no case less than five hundred (500) feet. 
2.  Collector street: two hundred (200) feet. 
3.  Residential and commercial street or cul-de-sac: one hundred (100) feet. 
d.  Horizontal curves. Horizontal curves shall have a minimum radius on the centerline as follows: 
1.  Major street: in accordance with minimum standards of the state department of transportation. 
2.  Collector street: three hundred (300) feet. 
3.  Residential and commercial street: one hundred fifty (150) feet. 
4.  Cul-de-sac: one hundred (100) feet; and, in addition, reverse curves shall be separated by tangents of not less than one hundred (100) feet. 
e.  Vertical curves. Vertical curves shall be used at changes in gradient of more than one percent (1%), and the length of such curves shall be not less than the required distance to produce a design speed of thirty-five (35) miles per hour. 
f.  Gridiron street pattern. While most of the streets in the borough follow an established gridiron pattern, the use of a curvilinear street alignment will be encouraged where a saving of existing trees, a reduction in grading or an improved appearance would result in greater compatibility with the surrounding environment. 
g.  Gradients. Gradients shall be measured on the centerline of all vehicular ways, and maximum and minimum gradients shall be as follows: 
Type of Street or Area Maximum Gradient Minimum Gradient Residential streets and Cul-de-sacs 8% 1% Driveway entrances within street right-of-way 5% 1% Collector streets 7% 1% Commercial streets 5% 1% Intersections, and 50 feet on each side 5% 1%  
(3)  Right-of-way and paving widths. The minimum widths shall be not less than those for an existing street of which the new street is to be a continuation, but in no case less than as follows: 
Type of Street Minimum Width of Right-of-Way (feet) Minimum Width of Cartway (feet) Major streets New Jersey Department of Transportation Collector streets 60 36 Commercial streets 60 40 Residential streets 50 34 Cul-de-sacs 50 26  
(4)  Cul-de-sacs. Cul-de-sacs shall not be approved: 
a.  Wherever a through street is practicable, unless the cul-de-sac is clearly the basic principle for design of the subdivision. 
b.  Which are more than three hundred fifty (350) feet in length, measured from the centerline of the street to the center of the turnaround. 
(5)  Private street or driveway. A private street or private driveway shall not provide access to a public street for more than two (2) lanes. 
(6)  Crosswalks. Crosswalks, where required by the planning board in excessively long blocks, shall have a right-of-way of ten (10) feet in width and shall have a paved way not less than four (4) feet in width. 
(7)  Intersections. 
a.  Right-of-way lines, if projected to points of intersection, shall intersect at ninety (90) degrees wherever possible, but in no case less than sixty (60) degrees and shall meet intersecting right-of-way lines by means of a tangential arc having a radius not less than ten (10) feet in length. 
b.  Curblines shall intersect by means of a tangential arc having a radius not less than twenty (20) feet in length, and the grade lines of tops of intersecting curbs shall, if projected, meet at a common point. 
(8)  Street names and signs. Street names and signs shall be as approved by the commissioners, and duplication shall be avoided unless as a continuation or projection of an existing street name. The subdivider shall install one (1) street standard and sign, approved by the commissioners, at each intersection and, in addition, a standard "dead-end" sign shall be installed at the entrance to all cul-de-sacs. 
(9)  Obstructions. Obstructions, such as fences, hedges, freestanding walls or plantings, other than street trees, shall be prohibited within the street right-of-way. 
(10)  Streetlights. Streetlights shall be installed by the developer at all street intersections and at such other locations as may be directed by the planning board. 
(11)  Curbs. Curbs shall be installed along all streets. 
(12)  Street trees. Street trees, of a type and size approved by the planning board, shall be planted by the developer within the street right-of-way and, where possible, between the lot line and the sidewalk and not between the sidewalk and the curb, spaced not less than forty (40) feet nor more than sixty (60) feet apart in the row and staggered along both sides of residential streets. 
(13)  Fire hydrants. Fire hydrants, of a type approved by the fire companies, shall be installed at such locations that any dwelling shall be within a radius not greater than six hundred (600) feet from such fire hydrant within the subdivision, or as otherwise directed by the fire companies. 
(b)  Sidewalks (all subdivisions). 
(1)  Paved sidewalks shall be provided along all dedicated streets serving all improved lots fronting or siding upon such streets, unless otherwise directed by the planning board. 
(2)  The location of sidewalks shall be between the street right-of-way line and the curb and shall be three (3) feet away from the right-of-way line. 
(c)  Blocks (major subdivisions only). 
(1)  Length of blocks greater than one thousand six hundred (1,600) feet shall not be permitted in the absence of special conditions deemed by the planning board to warrant greater length. 
(2)  Width of blocks, wherever practicable, shall be two (2) lot depths in width, and, except at street intersections, no single lot shall abut more than one (1) street. 
(3)  Crosswalks, at or near the middle of blocks longer than one thousand (1,000) feet, shall be provided where deemed by the planning board to be necessary for the public safety or convenience. 
(d)  Lots (all subdivisions). The minimum area, width, coverage and setback lines for lots shall be as prescribed in the area, width, yard and coverage provisions of the zoning regulations contained in article VII of this chapter and: 
(1)  Depth of lots shall be so designed as to avoid excessively deep properties, and a proportion of depth equals two (2) times the width shall be considered desirable but shall not be required. 
(2)  Lot frontage. All lots within a subdivision shall front upon a public street, and the length of such frontage shall be adequate to provide, but need not be equal to, the minimum lot width at the building line as prescribed in the zoning regulations of article VII of this chapter.
